IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance Statement) Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of irreversible blindness among elderly Americans, which has a devastating socioeconomic burden, particularly since there is currently no cure. Our proposed studies are designed to (1) mechanistically determine the interaction of two risk factors, complement factor H (CFH) and lipoproteins in AMD, and (2) establish if augmenting CFH and/or targeting high density lipoproteins are viable approaches for treating AMD. The proposed research is relevant to the National Eye Institute high priority research area, Intersection of Aging & Biological Mechanisms of Eye Disease, as well as to the National Institute on Aging research goal to Improve Understanding of Healthy Aging and Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A significant subset of pancreatic cancer patients harbors gain-of-function mutations and amplification of GNAS(GÎ±-s), however the function of mutant GNAS has remained elusive. The goal of this proposal is to understand how mutant GNAS driven signaling couple the core transcriptional and metabolic circuitry to propel tumor growth. Here we will use advanced organoid models, genetically engineered animals, patient-derived xenografts combined with global transcriptomics, isotopomer-based metabolic labeling and advanced microscopy to decipher oncogenic network of mutant GNAS in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is relevant to public health because it identifies the trajectories, risk factors, and outcomes of functional impairment that develops in middle age. This study will help inform prevention of functional impairment in middle age by providing data to support next-step development and testing of interventions to improve functional outcomes, and will inform policy planning to mitigate the projected burden of functional impairment and associated adverse outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Even when successfully cured with antibiotics, tuberculosis patients often suffer from permanently impaired lung function, necessitating the advent of new therapeutic strategies to ensure better outcomes. The use of host directed therapies that limit non-productive inflammation represents a promising approach, but development has been complicated by the substantial degree of heterogeneity observed in individual immune responses to Mtb infections. The proposed research seeks to define the contribution of the unfolded protein response to immune response heterogeneity and inflammation during Mtb infection, and to assess the feasibility of targeting specific unfolded protein response pathways to improve TB outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Current treatment options for neuroendocrine prostate cancer (NEPC), a highly aggressive subtype of prostate cancer, are only palliative, and most patients die within several months. It is therefore critical to identify therapeutically exploitable vulnerabilities for the preclinical testing of new drugs and drug combinations against NEPC. Our work will provide novel insights into the contributions of RB to ferroptosis as well as the preclinical data regarding efficacy, safety, and biomarkers required for the rationale design of future clinical trials that combine ferroptosis inducers and BCL2 inhibitors to treat lethal NEPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the field of nanomedicine, there are many laboratory studies that have shown nanoparticle-based new drug formulations are effective in treating cancer in mice, but the translation of animal results to clinical success in humans is limited, in part, due to low delivery efficiency of nanoparticles to the tumor and lack of a robust computational model that can predict the tumor delivery efficiency of nanoparticles and extrapolate the results from animals to humans. This project is relevant to public health because the knowledge gained from the proposed research will improve our understanding of the key determinants of tissue distribution and tumor delivery of nanoparticles, which are essential for the design of effective nanomedicines. In addition, the proposed research will create a publicly available web-based interface that allows researchers to predict organ and tumor delivery efficiency of nanoparticles, thereby reducing or eliminating animal experimentation in nanomedicine studies and to accelerate clinical translation of nanoparticle-based anticancer drug formulations to benefit cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Matrix vesicles, small extracellular vesicles released by osteoblasts and anchored in the extracellular matrix, are enriched with microRNA and other cell signaling molecules that may mediate bone development and regeneration. The role and mechanism of action of these matrix vesicles in mature bone remains to be elucidated, but may translate into therapeutic potential for orthopedic pathologies, including critical size bone defects and chronic nonunions. This study investigates the physical and chemical characteristics of matrix vesicles and their function with regard to cellular signaling pathway activation and new bone formation, with the ultimate goal of a novel therapeutic application to improve bone healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Increases in the number of biomedical PhD graduates from underrepresented backgrounds has not resulted in more diversity at the faculty level. Departure from academic paths at the postdoc level is partly responsible. The Yale Ciencia Academy will ensure that students from underrepresented backgrounds persist in academic paths by providing peer and role model communities of support connected across geographic distances and by training students in career planning, mentoring, and communication skills with a focus on the PhD to postdoc transition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Circulatory shock is a major cause of morbidity and mortality among critically ill patients. Early identification or forecasting of shock would be clinically actionable and improve prognosis, but no personalized prediction model for shock has been presented yet. We propose to develop physiologically and clinically relevant machine learning-based prediction models and therapeutic strategies that could guide personalized diagnosis and treatment of circulatory shock.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Legionella pneumophila (Lp) causes a potentially fatal form of pneumonia known as Legionnairesâ disease and is an intracellular parasite of amoebae when it is in water systems or macrophages when inhaled into the lungs. The Cianciotto lab has determined that a type II secretion system (T2SS) is required for Lp growth in amoebae, human macrophages, and the murine lung. The protein substrates that are secreted by the T2SS are important to our understanding of pathogenesis and potential targets for disease diagnosis or prevention, and hence, this proposal aims to determine how a novel T2SS-dependent deacetylase that is well conserved within the Legionella genus promotes the persistence and spread of the Lp pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: This is a novel study focused on designing and testing an implementation strategy bundle, Rapid Adaptation to Prevent Drug use (RAPD). RAPD will help optimize the capacity of schools respond to emerging drug use issues by reflecting on gaps and best practices from previous responses (e.g., vaping), including inequities in responsiveness. This research will enhance the public health impact of existing evidence-based interventions, enhance equity and enable similar adaptations of future emerging drug use issues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Carcinogenesis Program provides a diverse group of exceptional pre-doctoral students at Northwestern University with the conceptual foundation, laboratory experience, and operational skills they need to establish careers dedicated to improving cancer diagnosis, prevention, and treatment. Preceptors (mentors) bring interdisciplinary expertise ranging from fundamental cancer biology to cutting edge strategies for drug delivery. The training program integrates a dynamic didactic and career development curriculum with training at the laboratory bench to prepare students for cancer research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mast cell activation by IgE antibodies is a central factor in allergic disease. Our data show that the ATP receptor, P2X3, amplifies mast cell responses to IgE. This previously unknown pathway is selectively active in females and could help explain female-biased asthma disparities. Importantly, P2X3 can be targeted with available drugs, including the antidepressant, fluoxetine (Prozac). This study will therefore uncover basic and translational aspects of allergic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The human gammaherpesviruses Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and Kaposiâs sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) are linked to the development of a wide range of B cell lymphomas. The differentiation of infected B cells into memory B cells occurs in the lymphoid structure termed the germinal center (GC). We have recently demonstrated that a gammaherpesvirus noncoding RNA manipulates the GC to establish infection. In work here, we will determine the mechanism by which the manipulation occurs and define its importance in virus biology and the host immune response.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance The immune system is one of our best guards against developing cancer and when this system fails, cancer is allowed to grow and thrive. Over the last several decades it has become possible to isolate a patientâs own immune cells, expand and reactivate them in the laboratory, and use them to fight an existing cancer, termed cancer immunotherapy. We will utilize a specific immune cell, termed Natural Killer cells, and modify their genetic code to enhance their ability to treat a pre-existing osteosarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among women, incidence of metabolic syndrome (MetS) increases in midlife. This study will examine the role of exposures to endocrine-disrupting chemicals found in foods and personal care products and their interaction with health behaviors such as diet, sleep and physical activity on the development and progression of MetS. The research will also consider inflammation and epigenetic changes as possible mechanisms that underlie the associations of exposures with cardiometabolic health; and can provide new knowledge to aid in prevention and management of MetS in women as they age.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Infectious complications of surgery (surgical site infection, pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and sepsis) are common, occurring in about 8% of major surgical procedures, and are costly. Currently used surveillance techniques require extensive human participation, resulting in delays of at least six months before the data are available to care providers, and the data represent only a small sample of all operations. We propose to develop a machine learning-based, near real-time recurring audit and feedback system for identification of postoperative infections that will inform providers about infectious outcomes of their patients.

PROJECT_TITLE: Automated Surveillance of Postoperative Infections (ASPIN)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In the US, approximately 1 in every 2-3 individuals will develop cancer, a disease of uncontrolled cellular proliferation that can be fatal. The TP53 gene is the most commonly mutated gene in human cancer, reflecting the fact that p53 plays an essential role as a tumor suppressor. This research aims to elucidate the mechanisms by which p53 acts to suppress cancer, with the ultimate goal of improving early detection and treatment of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is a frequent diagnosis in the emergency department (ED); ED cancer diagnoses are more common among minority and low income patients and result in poor outcomes, including lower survival. Evidence about emergency diagnosis of cancer in the United States (U.S.), and how to prevent it from occurring, is limited. This study will generate much needed evidence about this important problem, including who is affected, where, and why, illuminating a largely unrecognized issue to help identify modifiable drivers of disparities in patients with the poorest prognoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The proposed research examines neurodevelopmental mechanisms underlying the powerful association of stressful life events (SLEs) with internalizing and externalizing psychopathology during adolescence. We use a novel methodological approach that permits examination of dynamic changes in emotion, cognition, social behavior, and neural function and connectivity following SLEs at a sufficiently fine grained level of temporal specificity to identify mechanisms underlying the link between SLEs and adolescent psychopathology as they unfold in real time. Elucidating these mechanisms will not only build knowledge of how environmental experience shapes development in ways that increase risk for psychopathology, but will also suggest possible targets for interventions to prevent the onset of stress-related psychopathology in children and adolescents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Because not all listeners process speech in the same way, it is important to understand how variation in the types of information (cues) that individuals tend to rely on to interpret speech relates to experiences with age-related hearing loss. This proposal tests the hypothesis that individual differences in cue use explain variation in speech comprehension in older adults with mild age-related hearing loss above and beyond just their hearing abilities. Understanding the mechanisms behind different experiences with emerging age-related hearing loss will help inform treatment plans and improve quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Nuclear Pore Complex (NPC) components (Nups) been shown to play a role in tissuespecific development and in several human pathologies, including cardiac disorders and hematologic malignancies, but how Nups contribute to development and to these serious conditions remains poorly understood. We have identified a function of Nups as scaffolds for genome organization, which helps direct appropriate gene expression. The goal of this proposal is to define molecular mechanisms, by which Nups set up genome organization and regulate genes, which will provide new avenues for understanding pathologies and developmental processes linked to the NPC.

PHR: Despite substantial efforts aimed at increasing faculty diversity, the proportion of faculty at academic institutions from underrepresented groups is well below their proportional representation in the U.S. population. The San Diego Leading the Advancement of Underrepresented Neuroscientists for Change (LAUNCH) program aims to enhance the diversity of the biomedical workforce in neuroscience. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Cognitive memory deficits are highly debilitating symptoms in schizophrenia. We propose the first attempt to comprehensively describe and understand cellular, molecular and microcircuit pathomechanisms of schizophrenia risk mutation-related episodic memory deficits in a genetic mouse model of schizophrenia. We will use cutting-edge, high-resolution recording and manipulation technologies in the hippocampal circuitry of behaving mice. These approaches are likely to yield major insights into the principles by which cellular, molecular and microcircuit alterations lead to cognitive memory dysfunctions associated with schizophrenia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maternal mortality and severe maternal morbidity (SMM) continue to rise in the United States, and women from low-income communities, minoritized racial/ethnic groups, and those with Medicaid or who are uninsured face increased risk. This study will combine quantitative Medicaid claims and qualitative key informant analyses to examine the potential impact of preconception care in reducing maternal SMM, particularly for women at highest risk.

PHR: Narrative Predictive personalized healthcare and precision medicine based on both traditional physiological information and modern clinical spatial imaging biomarkers would provide an accurate disease prediction and personalized treatment plan. This proposed project will develop a personalized spatial data-driven computational modeling framework to analyze these clinical biomarker data and will also validate this approach on various diseases. The successful research will have a huge impact to reveal a more comprehensive disease assessment and a new therapeutic approach to optimize the available treatment plans for each individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system provides humans with critically important protective responses to infectious pathogens such as viruses and bacteria, as well as to tumor cells; but inappropriate immune responses can also cause inflammation and autoimmune diseases. Studies that advance understanding of immune responses, and how to apply this knowledge to preventing and treating human diseases have great potential to reduce the disease burden and promote the health of the nation. The Predoctoral Training Program in Immunology is designed to provide rigorous training in a supportive environment for graduate students to pursue multiple approaches to understanding the mechanisms underlying immune responses, and apply this knowledge toward the treatment of human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE â Overview The Washington University Center for Diabetes Translation Research (WU-CDTR) supports research on the root causes of diabetes inequities informed by the social determinants of health. The Center includes five novel Translational Research Cores: Dissemination and Implementation in Diabetes Research; Policy and Systems Science Analysis; Health Communication and Social Needs; Health Informatics in Diabetes Research (Regional Resource); and Solutions to Diabetes in Black Americans (National Resource); and sponsors a Pilot and Feasibility Program and an Enrichment Program. The WU-CDTR enhances efficiency, productivity, and rapid research translation across a national network of investigators while fostering collaborations to achieve diabetes health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Early music and language experiences produce structural and functional changes in the brain, however, the impact of such experiences, especially the interaction of the two has not been fully explored in children. The proposed research uses the combination of a music neurophysiological paradigm and a lexical tone neurophysiological paradigm to examine the influence of early music training, early tonal versus non-tonal bilingual acquisition and dialect experience on different aspects of music feature processing, as well as to determine the complex interaction between music training and language acquisition on the neural network for music and speech processing. Findings may lead to the development of new approaches that utilize music to treat developmental language disorder and neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Patients surviving critical illness acquire impairments in muscle and physical function that can persist for years after hospital discharge. The planned study will identify cellular and physical function outcomes that contribute to failed muscle regrowth in the recovery phase of critical illness. My training will entail statistical analyses for basic and applied science and the experiments to assess human skeletal muscle to determine cellular mechanisms that drive impairments in muscle and contribute to sustained physical functional deficits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Data on cardiac function following treatment for relapsed pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML) are poorly captured on frontline treatment trials and thus the natural history of cardiotoxicity in pediatric AML is incompletely understood and the impacts of early toxicity on treatment selection upon relapse and subsequent impacts on outcomes have not been evaluated. The proposed project will establish a unique data resource by merging Children's Oncology Group clinical trial data, electronic health record data, longitudinal standard of care echoes, and administrative data from the Pediatric Health Information System that will allow us to address these significant knowledge gaps. Given that nearly 50% of AML patients experience relapse, and relatively poor prognosis of recurrent disease, a better understanding of the toxicity risks associated with salvage therapies and the impact on effectiveness is critical for improving AML outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural biology is an area of research that seeks to understand the physical architecture of biological macromolecules, providing important information about how those molecules operate in health and disease states. The primary tool used for molecular structure determination is X-ray crystallography, but progress in crystallography is limited by the difficult obstacle of coaxing biological molecules into crystalline forms. We propose a national crystallization resource, the HTX Center, that builds on our existing crystallization center and infrastructure at HWI, with enhanced capabilities in computing, experimental pipelines, and user engagement that are geared to not just continuing to offer state-of-the-art macromolecular crystallization services to the scientific community, but also to expand access to advanced instrumentation and expertise to help researchers overcome this primary bottleneck in macromolecular crystallography.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Arterial thrombosis, which results in acute ischemic stroke (AIS) affects ~15 million worldwide each year, and although rtPA reduces morbidity and mortality, AIS patients treated with rtPA develop restenosis, poor recanalization, and symptomatic hemorrhage. We developed an RNA aptamer (DTRI-031) that binds to and inhibits Von Willebrand Factor (VWF), critical in thrombus formation AND designed a specific reversal agent DTRI-025, that provides a critical measure of safety currently lacking in AIS treatment. This work will establish the importance of VWF as an optimal target in AIS patients, demonstrate that DTRI-031 rapidly and efficiently lyses arterial clots formed from AIS patient blood that is readily reversed by DTRI-025, and show that DTRI-031 improves recovery in a pre-clinical model of AIS with a favorable safety profile compared to rtPA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Retinal ischemia-reperfusion (IR) injury is a common clinical condition, which results in necrotic and apoptotic retinal ganglion cell (RGC) death. However, significant attention has been given to IR-induced apoptosis, which can be regulated, but not to necrosis, because it had been viewed as an accidental and unregulated cellular event. We now know that this viewpoint was incorrect and programmed (as opposed to accidental) RGC necrosis can significantly contribute to IR-induced retinal injury through signaling cascades, which will be investigated in detail in the proposed study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative. Protein allostery, in which a perturbation at one site in a protein causes a functional change at a distal site, is fundamental to biological information transfer but challenging to engineer. This proposal establishes a platform that combines high-throughput biophysical characterization of perturbation-driven dynamics with precise computational design to discover disease mechanisms and design new allosteric therapeutics and drugs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bile duct paucity can be cured by liver transplantation, but this therapy is hampered by a shortage of donor organs and by potential side effects of long-term immunosuppressive therapy, especially in children. The proposed preclinical studies examine whether enhancing the biliary system in a mouse model of a pediatric liver disease can rescue bile duct paucity, setting the stage for developing a therapy to avoid or postpone liver transplantation in patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the widespread use of combination antiretroviral therapy, the prevalence of chronic kidney disease and end-stage kidney disease continues to remain high in patients living with HIV, suggesting that HIV predisposes patients to increased risk for chronic kidney disease. The current proposal will explore how HIV-1 accessory protein Vpr causes kidney tubular cell injury and promotes kidney disease progression in HIV-infected individual, and knowledge gained will allow for development of more effective therapies for HIV-associated kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE An important goal in psychiatric neuroimaging is to identify brain-behavior associations for the purpose of identifying biomarkers that are indicative of illness trajectory or inform our biological understanding of psychiatric disorders. The goal of this project is to develop a statistically robust framework to address the limitations of existing inference methods, which have highly inflated false positive rates in many situations. This study will impact public health by improving the rigor and replicability of statistical inference for neuroimaging studies so that results can more accurately inform our understanding of the biological underpinnings of psychiatric illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cochlear hair cell loss is a leading cause of noise-induced and age-related hearing loss worldwide. Although surrounding supporting cells show the capacity to produce hair cells in neonatal mice, this plasticity is lost by postnatal day 5. This grant proposes to examine transcription factors hypothesized to be important in maintaining supporting cell fate, with the goal of establishing a gene therapy strategy to regenerate hair cells in vitro.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: Project Narrative Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS) Maintenance and the Enhancement of Current Good Manufacturing Practices (cGMP) and Preventive Controls for Animal Food (PCAF) Regulatory Activities Funding under this Cooperative Agreement Grant, âDevelopment and Maintenance of the Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards with Optional Coordinated Preventive Control Regulatory Activities and Capacity Building (U18) Clinical Trial Not Allowed,â the Louisiana Department of Agriculture & Forestryâs (LDAF), Office of Animal Health & Food Safety, Feed Program Division will be able to maintain full conformance with the Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS) and support the FDA Preventive Controls Initiative. The overall goal of this project is to develop the capability to maintain conformance to the AFRPS and conduct comprehensive feed inspections covered under 21 CFR Part 507, independent of but in coordination with the FDA. Maintaining full conformance with the AFRPS will assist both Louisiana and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to better direct their regulatory activities toward preventing feed manufacturing compliance issues and increasing food safety and Public Health within the United States.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PA Department of Agriculture Project Narrative- PAR-20-132 Advance efforts for a nationally integrated food safety system by strategically enhancing our state feed safety program through the maintenance funding of the Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS). By maintaining implementation of these program standards, the PA feed regulatory program can direct regulatory activities toward preventing animal feed safety hazards and responding to animal feed consumer complaints, recalls, investigations, and strategic risk planning surveillance. By maintaining the AFRPS, the animal feed program will be positioned to both lead or assist federal and other state agencies with emerging or present food safety issues. Project will be managed by Erin Bubb and David Dressler, both, full-time management.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: JAMES J PETERS VA  MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Suicidal behavior and schizophrenia (Sz) spectrum disorders are major public health problems affecting Veterans. Recent studies indicate that Veterans exhibit higher suicide risk compared with the general U.S. population. Recent figures estimate the VA treats ~100,000 schizophrenia (Sz) patients each year, accounting for nearly 12% of VA healthcare costs. The PIâs ongoing clinical cognitive neuroscience research at the VA focuses on elucidating the neurobiology of suicidal behavior and Sz using neuroimaging and psychophysio- logical approaches. Suicide prevention and identification of promising new targets for intervention in Sz are critically important goals of the VA. The PIâs track record of federal funding and peer-reviewed publications in these two areas has helped advance the field and her VA-funded grants may identify biomarkers which aid in prospectively identifying Veterans at greatest risk for suicide. This RCS Award will allow the PI to continue and expand her highly collaborative VA research and mentoring of promising VA fellows and clinician-scientists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: A Continuous Flow-Based Approach to Automated Microbial Oligosaccharide Synthesis.  This research will result in an inexpensive and predictable approach for the automated construction of biologically important carbohydrates. This proposal is relevant to public health because it will provide a method for the rapid synthesis of carbohydrate libraries to aid in developing next-generation therapeutics and diagnostic tools. The chemistry developed through this proposal is relevant to the part of the NIH's mission that pertains to basic biomedical research.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Isoniazid-resistant TB (INHr-TB) is the most common form of drug-resistant TB worldwide, and is a precursor to multidrug-resistant TB. INH resistance is rarely diagnosed leading to major gaps in our understanding of this disease. This project will provide critical insight into the epidemiology of INHr-TB including sentinel populations for the emergence of INHr-TB and congregate settings outside the household where INHr-TB is transmitted.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The central goal of this research program is to understand the molecular and cellular mechanisms that direct the assembly of of direction selective circuits in the mammalian visual system. These experiments will advance our understanding of visual system circuit development and function that are critical for mediating appropriate responses to image motion. This work may also aid in developing strategies for reestablishing functionally precise connectivity in the visual system following neuronal injury or degeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Artificial heart/lung machines used to treat patients with severe lung and heart conditions can be lifesaving but can also result in potentially fatal blood clots and inflammation-driven organ damage. Evidence suggests that a blood protein called factor XII plays a major role in driving both blood clots and inflammation-driven organ damage in patients requiring heart/lung machines. This proposal seeks to define the potential of factor XII as a therapeutic target for patients needing heart/lung machines, identify additional targets, and understand how factor XII drives blood clot formation and organ damage in these settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Inflammation is a protective process that must be terminated in a timely manner by the processes of resolution to achieve organ system health. We have identified a new mechanism by which the lipid mediator sphingosine 1-phosphate (S1P) acts on neutrophil S1P receptor-1 to induce resolution processes and achieve organ health after viral and chemical insults. This proposal will help clarify this poorly understood mechanism and develop new therapeutic approaches to control tissue damage of various organ systems.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: HIV exposure influences metabolomic pathways important to the development of cardiometabolic disease starting in early life. HEU children are at high risk for comorbid infections in early life, which may lead to systemic inflammation and contribute to cardiometabolic risk in early adolescence. Using novel metabolomic data, this study seeks to understand the impact of HIV exposure, early life infections and inflammatory response, on cardiometabolic outcomes in early adolescence in order to inform future screening and intervention strategies to improve cardiometabolic health among HEU and HU children.

PHR: NH PATH C PAR-21-174  PROJECT NARRATIVE The New Hampshire Department of Agriculture, Markets and Food (DAMF) project titled: Continued Development of the NHDAMF Produce Safety Program under Path C for the Implementation of the FDA Produce Safety Rule is intended to support and build upon the current Produce Safety Program (PSP) in the state of New Hampshire. The DAMF PSP Mission is to: Ensure the safe production of quality produce; assure producer competitiveness in the marketplace; and establish a unified partnership with FDA to achieve an integrated food safety system. DAMF will utilize federal funding to support this project and facilitate the success of achieving the mission goals. Through continued program development, education and training, along with enforcement and compliance, we anticipate that NHâs stakeholders will have the tools to safely produce, harvest, pack or hold fresh produce, which in turn, will build public confidence in the safety of NHâs food systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Comprehensive cardiac rehabilitation (CR) programs have repeatedly demonstrated efficacy in reducing morbidity and mortality while improving symptoms and quality of life for patients living with CVD; unfortunately, enrollment, adherence, and completion of CR programs are particularly low and thus patients are not receiving these known benefits. We aim to determine the effectiveness of delivering patient-centered individualized CR programming through a mobile health (mHealth) remote case management system in an effort to a) increase participation in and adherence to CR programming, b) improve known modifiable CVD risk factors, and c) improve near- and mid-term patient-centered outcomes including re-hospitalizations and mortality. Ultimately, this type of enhanced clinical service will provide patients with additional/alternative strategies to engage with clinical care teams and improve healthcare outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Suicide is a leading cause of mortality, and suicide deaths have increased substantially in the US over the past two decades. Loneliness is a prevalent risk factor for suicide that has worsened following the COVID-19 pandemic, yet there is a paucity of effective primary care interventions to address loneliness. This study will develop and pilot test two primary care interventions, each utilizing complementary mechanisms, to improve loneliness and reduce suicidal ideation within a model of collaborative care to enhance intervention effectiveness and implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (RELEVANCE) The manifestation of gastrointestinal (GI) motility and functional bowel disorders is caused, in part, by alterations to the function or survival of neurons that control GI muscle. The proposed studies investigate how glial cells that surround these neurons regulate their function and how altered glial regulation contributes to dysmotility. A detailed understanding of the role of enteric glia will lead to new therapies to treat GI motility and functional bowel disorders.

PHR: Transplantation of therapeutic cells to replace damaged tissues holds great potential in treating or providing relief to various illness, such as type 1 and advanced type 2 diabetes, kidney failure and heart disease. At present, cell transplantation is hindered by short-term survival and function of implanted cells and rejection by the patientâs immune system. We propose to develop an adjuvant system using extracellular vesicles (EVs) derived from mesenchymal stem cells to address these impediments in cell transplantation while enabling monitoring of EVs using magnetic particle imaging for adjustment and customization of the adjuvant treatment as needed by individual patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative As current resuscitation methods only provide 25-30% of cardiac output and are limited by the inability of clinicians to deliver CPR effectively up to 50% of the time, developing methods to improve cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is essential to enhance patient survival and reduce brain injuries after cardiac arrest (CA). A promising method to enhance CPR is through a physiological feedback system incorporating measures related to brain oxygen delivery and circulation quality. This grant aims to a) identify the optimal physiological resuscitation target using regional cerebral oxygenation (rSO2) or end tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) or combination; b) explore the mechanisms by which the optimal physiological resuscitation target leads to improved survival and neurological outcomes; c) conduct a pilot trial to compare the impact of real-time physiological feedback CPR vs. non-physiological feedback CPR on the ability to restart the heart and achieve improved survival and neurological outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term efficacy of adeno-associated virus (AAV) based therapies have been limited in their utility to treat chronic neurological diseases. This is increasingly important as more investigators plan to use AAV to treat various disorders in addition to some therapy protocols finishing clinical trials and receiving FDA approval for patient use. Identifying possible problems with long term efficacy of AAV therapy, as well as alternative approaches to avoid those problems are vital and significant aspects of gene therapy and key for the overall mission of NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Under a multi-PI leadership with a strong track record of scientific and mentorship collaboration, we propose a comprehensive regional interdisciplinary graduate and postgraduate training program (Kidney, Urologic, and Hematologic-Advanced Research Training or KUH-ART) to prepare trainees for long-term productive careers in advanced research in benign nephrology, urology and hematology. The overarching goal of the program is to recruit outstanding KUH trainees from diverse backgrounds and prepare them to lead multidisciplinary teams that produce KUH research with high impact on medical science and clinical outcomes. We benefit from exceptional resources: 1) our location one of the most creative and diverse metropolitan areas in the world, 2) UCLA, the top public University and its affiliates, and 3) relationships to elite research institutions including Caltech and RAND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atopic dermatitis is the most common childhood chronic illness and is often a lifelong disease posting a major public health burden. The role of IgE antibodies has been controversial in atopic dermatitis, but our combined studies demonstrate for the first time that IgE is a key factor in acute itch associated with atopic dermatitis and that certain sugar molecules cause IgE to be more like enhance IgE potency. This project seeks to elucidate the role of IgE glycosylation as a trigger for itch and supports the NIH mission by providing a foundation for novel biomarkers and therapeutics in the management of itch.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Millions of stroke survivors have difficulty walking due to weakness on one side of the body; many individuals adopt sedentary lifestyles, worsening their health and quality of life. In the short-term this study will determine preliminary efficacy of a device for significantly improving mobility and independence after stroke while defining techniques for implementation. Long-term, this should result in a clinical intervention that substantially improves walking speed, reduces fall risk, increases activity levels and overall health, and facilitates community access and independence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Kidney disease and hypertension affect more than 30 million and 70 million adults in the United States, respectively. There is an acute need to train dedicated scientists who will form the future workforce empowered to make discoveries, which lead to the reduction in death and disability from kidney disease and hypertension. The Division of Renal Diseases and Hypertension at the University of Colorado Anschutz Medical Campus T32 Training program provides state-of-the-art research training for MD and PhD scientists in both laboratory-based and clinical studies, with the goal of training the next generation of leaders in the field of nephrology research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The potential for triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) to relapse and/or spread to other sites after therapeutic interventions depends on the ability of the tumor cells to reactivate growth and motility signals. In this study, we will determine how Annexin A6 promotes TNBC invasiveness and whether the increased expression of Annexin A6 following chronic tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) treatment underlies the poor response of TNBCs to these drugs. Data from this study will improve our understanding of how TNBC cells circumvent the effects of chronic treatment with TKIs to become even more aggressive and/or invasive, key attributes which are associated with TNBC patient mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Structural Basis of APOBEC Functions and HIV Restriction  The APOBEC (Apolioprotein B mRNA-editing enzyme catalytic polypeptide) family of cytidine deaminases have diverse important biological functions that include (but not limited to) innate and aquired immunity against HIV/AIDS and other viruses such as HPV and HBV, cholesterol matabolism, heart and skeletal muscle development. Such divserse biological functions are excerted though their ability to interact with nucleic acids (RNA and DNA) and other proteins, either without or with the cytidine deamination activity that may also lead to accidental mutations that can lead to human deseases including immune defficiency and cancer. We propose to study the structure/function of the important family of APOBEC enzymes with focus on their functions related to virus (HIV-1) restriction, which will be valuable for for developing new effective therapies for HIV/AIDS and for the APOBEC-associated diseases and multiple cancers.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative Approximating justice in solid organ allocation when balancing the competing goals of equity and utility remains an urgent public health challenge. By applying natural- and quasi-experiment design with causal inference framework using data from a well-established registry-based nationwide transplant cohort, this study elucidates the causal effect of the existing liver allocation policy related to geographic boundaries and particular age group (children and elderly) in the United States on liver transplant candidates and recipients, which will be critical in evaluating (health) policies in contexts where randomized trials are most often unrealistic. The findings and career development strategy will help prepare the applicant for an independent investigator with expertise in integrating health care policy and health services evaluation, epidemiology, and causal inference frameworks/econometrics with specific strengths in chronic liver disease and solid organ transplantation that addresses multiple sources of health disparity.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Estimating the Causal Effect of Liver Allocation Policy Reflecting the Heterogeneity from Age and Geography

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trauma and post-traumatic stress disproportionately burden orphaned children in low-resource settings, and mental health services are often unavailable. While scale-up of interventions through lay counselor delivery of evidence-based treatments is promising, there is very limited knowledge on sustaining interventions after they are implemented or equipping leaders with information about potential effectiveness in other communities. This proposal, âSustaining and Generalizing Evidence-based Mental Health interventions for children (SAGE-MH)â will innovatively expand an implementation effectiveness trial in western Kenya to examine strategies for continuation during sustainment and to assess generalizability to all orphaned children in Kenya.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mitochondrial dysfunction is involved in the pathogenesis of the major blinding retinal diseases such as diabetic retinopathy and age-related macular degeneration, but study on mitochondria in retinal vasculature is limited. We will employ genetic, biochemical, cell biology, microscopy imaging and single cell transcriptome analyses to define the common angiogenic and metabolic pathways regulated by three mitochondrial proteins with distinct functions. Successful completion of the proposed aims will facilitate our understanding of the molecular mechanisms and pathogenesis involved in vascular diseases in the eye, and help in defining more effective therapies. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the availability of highly effective HBV vaccine and HCV treatment, their infections are still among the leading causes of chronic liver disease worldwide. We propose to utilize an innovative platform to address several clinically important but understudied questions including a continued disease progress following cure of HCV infection, an accelerated disease progression with HBV/HCV co-infection, HBV reactivation following cure of HCV, and how genetic variants affect the course of disease and treatment. These studies will not only provide new insights that could inform development of effective diagnostics and treatments for HBV/HCV infection, but also lead to technology advance that open up new avenues for future studies focusing on other liver diseases.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE. Determining whether Animal-Assisted Therapy (AAT) could serve as a low risk, efficacious approach for managing dental anxiety and providing positive dental experiences in children would allow for rapid implementation of canine therapy in dentistry. We will evaluate whether short and long AAT interventions alleviate stress and improve perceptions during preventative pediatric dental care, to guide AAT protocol development and use to improve lifelong oral health with broad public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kinase plus LSD1 inhibition is a new treatment approach for patients with AML, in whom kinase inhibitor monotherapy has not historically provided a large clinical benefit. In this proposal, we will investigate the mechanism of action of FLT3 plus LSD1 and MEK plus LSD1 inhibition in FLT3- and NRAS-mutant AML respectively. These studies will provide a pre-clinical framework for the clinical translation of kinase plus LSD1 inhibitor therapy for patients with AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because identifying pathological alterations to the brain glia- lymphatic pathway (i.e. perivascular spaces) is expected to aid in Alzheimerâs disease diagnosis and disease monitoring. It is also expected to fill the gap in knowledge regarding the role of the perivascular spaces in Alzheimerâs disease and its pathological neuroimaging signature. Thus, this proposal is relevant to the part of NIA's mission that pertains to fostering aging research and further characterizing the aging brain in Alzheimerâs disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in children, adolescents, and young adults (AYA) is characterized by highly prevalent transcription factor fusions and RAS pathway mutations with the first of these genetic alterations hypothesized to promote a transcriptional signature that is permissive for AML development and the latter playing a central role in driving leukemic growth. Our data revealed that targeting these pathways simultaneously results in potent synergistic effects that converge upon key survival programs. This K08 application proposes to extend these studies to pediatric AML patient-derived xenografts and to define the molecular basis of drug synergy and resistance with the goal of translating this new knowledge into better treatments for pediatric AML.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Maintaining health depends on the ability of the body to sense changing internal and external environments, which is accomplished by nerve cells called afferents. The gut uniquely has a class of afferents called intrinsic primary afferent neurons or IPANs that reside within the wall of the bowel and endow the gut with autonomous nervous activity. This project will determine the range of different functional IPANs and their detailed modes of activities and thereby pave the way for better diagnostic procedures and drug targets for digestive diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This K23 application aims to develop and validate artificial intelligence tools to aid in determining the microbiologic etiology of infectious keratitis, which is a major cause of blindness worldwide. We intend to develop two artificial intelligence systems, one to determine the cause of infectious keratitis from clinical photographs and the other to read microbiologic smears in an automated fashion. These systems will allow more rapid initiation of directed antimicrobial therapy, particularly in medically underserved areas, and improve visual outcomes in infectious keratitis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The skin is a highly innervated organ and contains numerous sensory afferent neurons that respond to a diverse array of stimuli. There are also many skin-resident immune cells that make direct contact with sensory neurons. We have previously shown that one subset of neurons that sense pain are necessary and sufficient for cutaneous innate Type-17 inflammation and host defense. We now propose to test the immunologic potential of other subsets of sensory neurons. The overall goal of this proposal is to understand the unique contribution of individual sensory neuron subsets in the modulation of skin immunity. Exploring this neuro-immune interaction will better define the cellular circuits driving inflammation and allow for the use of agonists/antagonists that target neuron subsets in order to modulate specific types of cutaneous immune responses without global immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The aim of this study is to understand T cells that are resident in the brain and their role in Alzheimerâs disease pathogenesis, both directly and in concert with other immune populations. There is a growing body of work indicating a role for neuroinflammation in Alzheimerâs disease, yet the impact of brain resident T cells, which can mediate potent immune activation and are well positioned to exert disease-altering effects in the brain, is unknown. Studying these cells in Alzheimerâs disease and has potential to provide insight into T cell functions in other neurological diseases and drive the development of novel immunotherapies for Alzheimerâs disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sensory neurons allow animals to detect and identify constantly changing environmental cues in order to make the appropriate behavioral and developmental decisions. Defects in the ability to correctly sense and process external signals lead to neurodevelopmental, behavioral, and cognitive disorders. This proposal uses the simple nervous system of the nematode C. elegans to explore how sensory neurons acquire and modify their specialized structures and functions, and how defects in these processes lead to disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE: Through the attribution of excessive motivational value, cues in the environment can gain inordinate control over behavior and result in unwanted outcomes, such as relapse in individuals with addiction. Using an animal model, we are able to elucidate the neural mechanisms by which such cues are transformed into powerful motivators of behavior. The proposed work aims to identify the point of intersection by which stress- and reward-circuits act to potentiate the value of environmental stimuli, in hopes of identifying potential targets for the treatment of cue- driven disorders such as addiction and post-traumatic stress disorder.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The risk-reduction strategy that a patient engages in for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease should be a shared-decision between the patient and their clinician. This study seeks to address that gap by implementing an evidence-based intervention to improve the SDM behavior of patients with low health literacy.

PHR: Weight loss is very important for overweight or obese patients with type 2 diabetes for reducing medication use and improving glucose control and other cardiovascular risk factors. However, weight loss has been associated with increased bone loss and fracture risk among these patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The University of Toronto Genetic Research Center, working within the NIDDK IBD Genetics Consortium, is proposing a series of studies aimed at transforming the knowledge gained through genetic studies in IBD into functional biology that can impact patient care in the near term. While ultimately the goal remains to prevent IBD from occurring, these studies aim to reduce the risk of relapse in ulcerative colitis, through better understanding of the biology of persistent inflammation in contributing to relapse and colorectal cancer risk and to elucidate the immune and cellular profile of treatment refractory Crohnâs disease. Through the insights gained, we hope to improve the quality of life of individuals affected by IBD in the near future while continuing our long-term goals to prevent IBD from arising in the first place.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE Early-life stress increases the risk of long-term language deficits in children with fluctuating hearing loss from chronic ear infections. While the potential mechanisms of this interaction are unexplored, our data suggest that early life stress on its own causes auditory perceptual deficits and alters sound-evoked responses in auditory cortex, a known locus of dysfunction in early hearing loss. This project will determine whether auditory perceptual deficits induced by early life stress, on its own and in conjunction with hearing loss, are explained by changes at the level of auditory cortex, and determine whether changes to inhibitory circuits are mechanistically involved in these perceptual deficiencies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Development of any species relies critically on spatially organized mRNAs. While mRNA typically become organized by RNA binding proteins, they can also self-organize into multi-transcript assemblies, a phenomenon observed in heathy cells across species as well as in human disease. The aim of this study is to determine the mechanism of mRNA assembly and its role in regulating post-transcriptional reactions during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Diabetic retinopathy is the leading cause of blindness in working-age adults with more than 190 million worldwide projected to be affected by 2030. This project will develop a computer model to predict initiation and progression of diabetic retinopathy based on changes in blood flow in retinal vessels that are caused by changes in the properties of blood cells and vessel structure due to their prolonged exposure to diabetic conditions. The detailed and accurate prediction from this model may provide novel insights on blood flow-mediated pathogenesis of retinopathy, and reliable metrics for early disease detection, thereby directly benefiting clinical diagnosis and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A devastating and deadly neurodegenerative disorder, Alzheimer's disease is a major health crisis that has its greatest impact on elderly populations and their caregivers; thus, identifying effective treatments that increase both the lifespan and healthspan of individuals who would otherwise succumb to the disease is a major goal of current research. Our experiments showing that decreased Kinesin-5 activity likely contributes to the pathology and symptoms of Alzheimer's disease is important to public health, as our findings reveal its potential as a novel target for developing therapeutic interventions. Identifying the cellular processes affected by changes in Kinesin-5 activity will lead to an increased understanding of neuronal processes in both diseased and non- diseased states, allowing the knowledge gained from our proposed project to be applied to studies of other neurological disorders beyond Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Arthroscopic partial meniscectomy provides no clinically meaningful benefits for certain patient groups even after physical therapy fails. Preoperative identification of this population can help substantially improve clinical treatment and management plans of these patients by reducing unnecessary surgeries and cost to the healthcare system. The proposed study will provide a novel outcome prediction model to achieve this goal by utilizing imaging findings from a deep learning based automated and consistent system for cartilage and meniscus segmentation and lesion detection on heterogeneous knee MR images collected from clinical routine practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: The comorbidity between substance abuse and mood disorders is an ongoing challenge for the mental health field, with a need for improved understanding of the mechanisms underlying these comorbid illnesses. The goal of this project is to identify the role of L-type calcium channels (LTCC) in mediating mood disorder phenotypes after repeated cocaine or repeated stress exposure. This work in rodent models will address a significant gap in current scientific understanding, will identify mechanisms by which LTCC blockade produces antidepressant and anxiolytic effects, and will provide a strong foundation for future clinical and therapeutic focused investigations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative A functioning retina is the result of an extraordinary orchestration of complex pathways responsible for its development and homeostasis; any deficits in these pathways may lead to disease and loss of sight. We have recently shown that a powerful and unbiased state-of-the-science forward genetics approach can be used to identify novel gene-phenotype associations that are crucial to retinal health, and we propose now to exploit this strategy to identify and characterize genes and pathways that regulate: 1) retinal development and homeostasis, 2) retinal immune surveillance, and 3) early diabetic retinopathy. Our long-term goal is to leverage our research results for the discovery of novel therapeutic targets for retinal diseases and in the development of new retinal regeneration strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  A delayed/missed response to falling in nursing facilities can result in adverse consequences and even fatalities. WARE-Care: mmWave based fall Assessment and pRevEntion system, is proposed as a complementary tool to existed motion detection sensors (such as wearables and cameras) to capture the fall events and evaluate fall risks for elders living alone especially during night. The system will be non-contact and non-obtrusive, adhere to privacy protections, operate at safe electromagnetic radiation levels and is small, easy and practical to deploy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) affects 30% of individuals over the age of 65 years and is the leading cause of vision loss in the Western World. Though the fundamental abnormalities occurring in retinal pigment epithelial cells (RPE) are not known, several pathogenic pathways altered in AMD have been identified including inflammation, lipid dysregulation, RPE barrier dysfunction, apoptosis among others. The objective of this grant is to investigate the role of the transcription factor, the Nuclear Receptor Related-1 protein (NURR1 or NR4A2) in RPE cells and development of dry AMD. Upon completion of this project we will have characterized the role of NURR1 in the RPE and tested the therapeutic potential of targeting NURR1 in mouse models of AMD. This will be the first demonstration of this novel signaling pathway in the posterior pole.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Millions of people are infected with Toxoplasma gondii and we need to understand how it causes disease. We discovered that polyphosphate (PolyP) synthesis is essential for the parasite survival. Our hypothesis is that polyPs interact with key proteins that are essential for the pathogenesis of Toxoplasma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Developmental disabilities (DD) present a major public health concern, especially in sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), where resources to diagnose and remediate them are severely limited. This proposal is aimed at establishing a large sample of children with DD in Zambia, providing a detailed characterization of the relevant phenotypes, studying the etiology of these diseases, documenting how they are regarded and treated within the community, to generate relevant recommendations for policy makers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Over 30% of pregnant American women are obese, which negatively affects fetal development with long-term consequences for offspring health. We found that maternal obesity leads to fibrotic and fatty infiltration (FFI) in offspring skeletal muscle and brown adipose tissue, which impair their metabolic function, and propose that maternal obesity enhances embryonic fibrogenesis to increase FFI in offspring. Knowledge obtained from proposed studies will provide molecular targets for therapeutics to improve embryonic development and subsequent metabolic health of offspring born to obese mothers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The discipline of nutrition touches on individuals of all nationalities and backgrounds, and indeed the most serious sequela of malnutrition are observed in the poorest and most under-represented sectors of society. In recognition of this fact, the IHN and this Training Program have long believed it was our responsibility not only to advance understanding of the underlying causes and consequences of malnutrition, both under-nutrition and increasingly, over-nutrition, but also to provide training to individuals from the communities most affected by the adverse health effects of poor nutrition. In this light, the IHN has for over 25 years maintained a vigorous PhD Training Program in nutritional sciences, renewal of support for which is sought in this application.
PROJECT_TERMS: nutrition;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Graduate Training in Nutrition

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Intestinal parasites, including soil-transmitted helminths (STH), infect over 1.5 billion people worldwide, resulting in a massive global burden of disease. Mass drug administration (MDA) to at-risk populations is the cornerstone of the global strategy for controlling morbidity associated with STH infections; however, varied MDA program success indicates that re-infection from environmental reservoirs is common. This proposal leverages a novel, sensitive and specific molecular assay to detect STH DNA in large volumes of soil within a multi-country community- wide MDA randomized controlled trial to define, for the first time, the impact of an MDA intervention on soil reservoirs of STH, and to evaluate the potential for using soil STH DNA as a non-invasive surveillance tool to monitor human infection prevalence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This research focuses on how to block the inflammation that strongly impacts the death of neurons, which leads to vision loss in many retinal diseases. We show that inhibition of macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) prevents neuronal death in excitotoxic damage models relevant to ischemia, including vein/ artery occlusion, sickle cell retinopathy, retinopathy of prematurity, and diabetes. This research will define the important functional relationships between MIF, signaling pathways, glia-mediated neuronal survival, and genome-wide transcriptional switches during retinal damage to set the stage for future studies targeting key molecular pathways to prevent and recover visual loss from retinal damage.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes mellitus causes progressive functional and structural damage of blood vessels and neurons in the retina of the eye that can lead to vision loss, and is the leading cause of blindness among working-aged adults in the United States. Our studies demonstrate that early diabetes can cause abnormal regulation of the retinal microvessels (arterioles and venules) leading to insufficient supply of oxygen and nutrients to the neural cells for proper function. Because effective therapies are lacking to treat vascular and neural damage during the advanced stage of diabetes, the goal of this proposal is to identify novel destructive proteins in the retinal microvasculature that can be targeted for therapy to improve blood flow and consequently the retinal function in early diabetes before the development of irreversible structural damage to the retina.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative  Small changes in acoustic features of communication sounds can dramatically alter their meaning; for example, in human language, the words âbatâ and ârat,â sound similar, yet they refer to two different animals. Furthermore, behavioral context aids sound discrimination, yet the neuronal pathways that mediate the effect of context on the discrimination of complex sounds with different semantic information remain difficult to study in human subjects, creating the crucial need for mammalian animal models that are auditory specialists. The proposed research, employing bats as model organisms, will investigate the mechanisms mediating auditory processing in the mammalian brain, and will contribute to knowledge that can help in the diagnosis and treatment of humans who suffer from communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative To return a 130 mph serve, a tennis player needs to prepare to strike the ball early, before it is actually in motion, and analyze the ball's trajectory very rapidly (within 400 milliseconds approximately). We propose a series of experiments to investigate how motor preparation and perceptual processing interact and determine the per- formance of a subject during an urgent decision-making task, and how the activity of nerve cells in the cerebral cortex contributes to these two crucial functions, i.e., analyzing visual stimuli and generating motor actions in response to them. The results will help us characterize the mechanisms that the brain uses to make choices, and this, in turn, will help us understand anomalous behaviors in which those mechanisms malfunction, such as risky decision making, proneness to distraction, and emphasis on instant gratiï¬cation over long-term gains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding what drives eating of highly palatable foods can help us understand why people develop obesity. In this project we will assess the impact of a medication that helps people lose weight while people are exposed to situations which they find stressful or in which they are exposed to highly craved foods. The study will help us to understand what processes may help in lowering craving and eating of highly craved foods to impact weight outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Gene expression is highly regulated by cells to allow for correct function and response to extrinsic signals. Despite protein synthesis being a fundamental process in gene expression, our understanding of the mechanisms of specialized mRNA translation remains limited. The proposed research will determine how translation initiation factors regulate cellular phenotypes, and has implications on rational design of therapeutics targeting gene dysregulation in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Shigellosis or bacillary dysentery remains a serious global public health problem, especially for children under the age of five. The ability for Shigella species to cause dysentery requires a functional type III secretion apparatus or injectisome which delivers host-altering effector proteins into the cells of the large intestine. This research will explore the assembly and function of the cytoplasmic portions of the injectisome by identifying key protein-protein interfaces and protein structural shifts that contribute to injectisome assembly, stability and function. These findings will lay the foundation for future development of small molecule inhibitors that will help in the treatment of bacillary dysentery.

PHR: NARRATIVE The development of a highly skilled diverse workforce that will impact all aspects of health related research efforts is essential to sustain the Nationâs research priorities, scientific and economic competitiveness. The UC San Diego Building a Respectful, Inclusive Culture Program will address this need by providing training modules that will catalyze changes in scientific, clinical and research training environments optimized for productive learning and research that are free from harassment, intimidation and discrimination. Creating a culture of respect, trust and safety in the academic environment is imperative for protecting trainees and learners, allowing them to learn and work in an environment conducive to the pursuit of excellence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Many anti-thrombotic agents are in use for prophylaxis, but therapy of thrombi is limited to lysis by plasminogen activators such as urokinase. Yet, no drug is safe and effective in conditions associated with combined acute high risk of thrombosis and bleeding. Treatment of thromboses in these patients, e.g., in the early post-surgery period, is an unmet medical need. To achieve this challenging goal, we pioneered coupling of these drugs to carrier blood cells, red blood cells and platelets. Our previous studies affirmed that this strategy works in animal models of thrombosis without provoking bleeding. In the present project, we will transform these prototypes into novel molecular and cellular antithrombotic agents testable in humans, and will define their mechanisms and appraise their benefit/risk ratio in pre- clinical translational studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: This proposal utilizes Drosophila (fruit fly) eye model to study the genetic mechanism of axial patterning (Dorso-ventral, DV patterning) and growth, a critical and a fundamental process required for the transition of a single layer of cells into a three-dimensional organ. Given the conservation of genetic machinery (genes) required for these fundamental processes, we propose to study the (i) molecular genetic function of DV patterning genes in patterning and growth (ii) and interactions of these DV genes with evolutionarily conserved growth regulatory Hippo signaling pathway with emphasis on discerning crosstalk between two core pathways that are known to act independently in regulating Wingless signaling and thereby determining positional fate and regulate growth during organogenesis. These studies will have significant bearing on understanding the genetic basis of organogenesis, cause of abnormal processes that lead to visual system birth defects, retinal defects, and therefore is of immediate relevance and importance to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Public health narrative: Movement related injuries and disorders will affect the majority of the population at some point in their lifespan, and treatments are difficult to develop because we have limited ability to predict how a proposed treatment will change the neuromusculoskeletal dynamics of a patient. Machine learning approaches have the potential to predict, simulate, and analyze human movements under different scenarios. Using these ML-based models to predict patient responses to hypothetical treatments would radically shorten the development time for novel treatments, but today we lack sufficient clean public data to apply these methods. By developing a set of new tools to automatically process and aggregate movement data, we will create a dataset of massive size, radically simplify sharing new data, and lead to a sea change in analysis of movement and prediction of treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE MDD affects women nearly twice as often as men, but the neurobiological underpinnings of this discrepancy are unclear. We have made the exciting discovery that a specific circuit in the brain is more excitable in female mice than in males and will investigate the mechanisms by which testosterone regulates the excitability of this circuit to uncover novel downstream targets critical for stress resilience. This work is relevant to NIMHâs high priority interest in research utilizing sex as a biological variable and investigating mental health disparities, and we utilize innovative techniques to uncover basic pathophysiology that may be exploited as novel sex-specific therapeutic interventions in MDD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative: Dying cells release several toxic components, including their bacterial-resembling power plants, mitochondria, a process known to promote inflammation and autoimmunity. However, we still do not fully understand how the released mitochondria contribute to inflammation and disease. In the current proposal, we aim to study how mitochondria are recognized and removed by our immune cells to avoid unwarranted inflammation, organ damage, and autoimmunity, with the ambition to identify novel pathways and biomarkers that could be targeted and monitored in mitochondrial-mediated diseases, in particular lupus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This research is aimed at understanding how immune cells that fight tumors can remain in skin, lymph nodes, and blood, and how they defend against cancer. Results from this work will help to explain what helps immune cells localize to places where cancer spreads to prevent metastasis. In addition to studying cancer in mice, we will also study tissues from patients with melanoma and lung cancer, therefore this work has broad relevance for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The incidence of type 1 diabetes (T1D), an autoimmune disease which affect millions of people worldwide, has been rising for the past half century. While both genetic and environmental factors contribute to the risk of developing T1D, recent studies indicate that early-life microbial interactions with the developing immune system offer a critical window of opportunity to influence the immune system development and prevent disease. Our study uses a new mouse model of the early-life microbiome, derived from a line of mice that are genetically protected from T1D, to identify immunomodulatory commensal bacteria and immune system pathways that can be used to develop effective preventative therapies for T1D.
