IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Millions of people experience general anesthesia each year in the United States, yet the mechanisms governing anesthetic actions are unclear. The period of arousal from anesthesia, termed emergence, is a particularly sensitive and dangerous time in clinical anesthesia care, and no therapeutic strategy currently exists for modifying emergence. This proposal aims to elucidate inhibitory cellular, circuit, and behavioral mechanisms of emergence from general anesthesia in order to inform the development of mechanistically targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Piezo1 mechanically-activated Ca2+ channels play critical roles in cellular mechanosensitivity, and Piezo1-me- diated mechanotransduction is implicated in various human health and disease. Previous research and our preliminary data suggest a previously unappreciated role of Piezo1 in regulating cellular morphology and mechanosensitivity under inflammatory conditions. We will use cutting-edge engineering and physiology ap- proaches to identify fundamental mechanisms of Piezo1-dependent mechanotransduction-inflammation coupling using chondrocytes as a model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to interrogate the interplay between diet, the gut microbiome-derived secondary bile acids, and colorectal cancer risk by conducting an observation study in four large prospective cohorts and a single-arm pilot clinical trial. The proposed research will enable unprecedented perspectives on how the gut microbial metabolism of bile acids mediates the dietary influence on colorectal cancer development and provide compelling data to develop a bile acid/gut microbiome axis-targeted diet for the prevention of colorectal cancer.

PHR: NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a heritable autoimmune disease that primarily affects young females. Genome-wide association studies have identified >190 loci associated with SLE but the genetic architecture remains elusive. Expanding the analysis to diverse human populations will further empower discovery, elucidate causal variants, and improve diagnosis and risk predictions, all of which have strong public health relevance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive control, also termed executive function, allows us plan, organize, and direct our thoughts and actions toward goals. A wide range of neurological and psychiatric conditions exhibit deficits in cognitive control, which devastates employment, scholastic achievement, and independence. The proposed fundamental research, that focuses on how the human brain represents the many combinations of task elements separately for control may eventually promote clinical applications that refine diagnosis and improve rehabilitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is a high-resolution imaging technology that is already commonly used to diagnose and monitor glaucoma, a leading cause of blindness. The proposed research will further improve this technology so that it can detect earlier stages of glaucoma, evaluate the location and severity of glaucoma damage, and provide more accurate monitoring of disease progression. Directional OCT technology will be developed to accurately measure nerve fiber layer reflectance; sensorless adaptive-optics OCT technology will be used to improve imaging of nerve fiber bundles and capillaries; ultrahigh axial resolution will enable imaging of detailed internal retinal structures such as the lamellae of the inner plexiform layer; and capillary perfusion measurements will be used to simulate visual field function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will be the first observational, longitudinal study to measure and compare over time biochemical measures in the circulation and skeletal muscle related to iron deregulation and mitochondrial dysfunction in both low-functioning and high-functioning older adults. The results from this study will help to identify cellular targets for future studies to improve iron homeostasis and mitochondrial function, which should ultimately slow the rate of progression of functional decline in older adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal diseases caused by enteric viral pathogens impose a significant global health burden and can be lethal in vulnerable populations. Interferon lambda (IFN-Î») is a cytokine with particular importance in the antiviral immune response of intestinal epithelial cells, and is stimulated by the bacterial microbiota. Through the studies of this research project, we will identify the mechanism of microbiota-stimulated IFN-Î» responses in intestinal epithelial cells, thereby advancing our understanding of antiviral immunity to enteric viral pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The survival of cancer cells after chemotherapy is a major barrier to clinical cures. Small cell lung carcinomas (SCLC) exhibit a general pattern of initial sensitivity to chemotherapy with almost invariable progression after treatment cessation. Herein, we show that SCLC tumors are highly adaptable to chemotherapy in large part because they undergo rapid cell state transitions. We posit that determining the form and function of SCLC's multi-faceted and mutable states will advance new therapeutic strategies in this recalcitrant disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE We will develop, deploy, and disseminate new informatics technologies that leverage existing single-cell transcriptomic atlases to assist and automate the design and analyses of multiplexed antibody-based cytometry experiments in cancer research. These computational methods will be instrumental in ensuring standardized, scalable, and reproducible cytometry analyses of tumors with increased phenotypic resolution. By facilitating accurate characterizations of tumor cell ecosystems, our research will impact advances in cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has the worst outcome among breast cancer types, and is common among women of African ancestry. Known differences exist between the genetic and epigenetic drivers of TNBC between tumors of different genetic ancestries, including some that affect therapy choice. We propose a pilot study of largely unstudied genetic regions in tumors from a diverse population to increase the patient population eligible for targeted therapy in TNBC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Spine pain is among the most common and disabling health conditions for both non-Hispanic whites (NHWs) and racial/ethnic minorities. Although Hispanics often report more severe pain than NHWs, they are less likely to consult a healthcare professional for pain management and health care providers are less likely to assess and treat pain in Hispanic patients. Consistent with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services National Pain Strategy, this proposal aims to mitigate ethnic disparities in access to and engagement in non- pharmacological treatment options for pain by addressing barriers at multiple levels of influence along the care continuum in a Federally Qualified Health Center serving diverse, low-income communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it improves the quality of care and patient outcomes during care transitions. The new and improved health information technology solutions proposed in this project can facilitate an integrated multi-disciplinary approach to improving care transitions by defragmenting information, improving communication, and assuring the care team has access to reliable and complete health information that may be located in other care settings or disparate systems. The proposed research is also relevant to the part of the NLMâs strategic plan that focuses on enabling interoperability of clinical systems and meaningful use of electronic health records, and effective translation of new knowledge into practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research study explores patient and caregiver dyadic factors that can influence the quality of end of life (EOL) care for patients with advanced cancer and their informal caregivers. This is a very unique study because it is looking at how close (or far apart) patients and their informal caregivers are in their assessments of the severity of patient symptoms, their understanding of the patientâs EOL values, and their understanding of the patientâs EOL preferences for treatment. The study is highly relevant as it will provide information that has not been obtained before that can help guide methods of providing information and support at EOL for patients with advanced cancer and their informal caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The spread of tuberculosis is a global health crisis leading to over one million deaths annually. The global burden of tuberculosis is a threat to the health of all Americans, and directly relevant to the mission of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, given the easy transmission of the disease through the air and the emergence of drug resistant strains that are difficult to treat. Infections with non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections are also a serious problem in the United States, particularly in individuals with underlying conditions such as Cystic Fibrosis or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

PHR: Dysfunction in how the brain uses feedback to guide future decisions is a primary mechanism for many public health problems (e.g., addiction). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Age-related deficits in auditory processing are associated with increased reliance on listening effort in comprehension of speech in complex acoustic backgrounds. This research will provide insights about the effects of age on relationships between different measures of effort, and between effortful listening and neural representations of speech. These findings will be an important first step towards characterizing the role of different cognitive processes within the language processing hierarchy and may inform development of novel diagnostic measures for speech perception deficits that are missed by traditional clinical tests.

PHR: Project Narrative  The following research proposal will develop broadly-applicable strategies for new synthetic-organic meth- odologies that are particularly suited for the preparation or late-stage modification of natural products and phar- maceuticals. These synthetic strategies all rely on electrical energy as a means to (i) promote challenging â but desirable â reactions, (ii) eliminate the need for expensive or hazardous reagents, and (iii) reduce the synthetic steps required to access the target molecules. As a result of streamlining synthesis, these findings will accelerate the identification of new therapeutics and allow their preparation on large scale with lower costs to the public.

PHR: Project Narrative Maternal health disparities, uterine dysfunction and childbirth-related morbidity are associated with maternal aging; however, individual morbidity linked to aging is better predicted by epigenetic age, a measure of biological age. My research will leverage a robust biomarker of aging, Epigenetic Clock, to understand how a womanâs epigenetic age relates to both uterine function/dysfunction during birth and her self-reported burden of psychosocial and socioeconomic stress during pregnancy. This work will shed critical light on the complex integrated relationship between social and physical environmental exposures and biological changes that underpin maternal health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Hopa Mountain, working in partnership with MSUâs WWAMI Medical School, proposes to develop a Medical Mentorship program that will provide near peer mentors to Montana high school students interested in becoming physicians or other types of health care professionals. The primary goal of the Medical Mentorship program is to help students learn more about medical careers and how to apply to and graduate from institutions of higher learning with a health sciences or biomedical research degree. Medical Mentorship will connect high school students with undergraduate and medical school mentors, including first and second year WWAMI Medical School students, who can help students prepare for careers in medicine and learn how to succeed in college while working toward a STEM degree. Some of the most powerful tools-- mentoring, role modeling, and career exposureâhave been shown to be effective in a variety of settings. Mentoring and support encourages engagement in science, math, and engineering careers. Given the vast distances between these high school students and those in a university setting, this near- peer mentoring program will take place primarily through peer-led group learning through collaborative learning technologies for students who are not co- located in a lab or work-based setting. . Hopa Mountain will develop innovative training and mentoring opportunities for low-income, first generation, and reservation-based Montana high school students to strengthen their STEM skills and prepare them for higher education and careers in health sciences. The overall project goal of Medical Mentorship is to support rural and tribal youthâs interest in and exposure to careers in the biomedical and health sciences while giving them the skills to play leadership roles in increasing healthy family practices in their homes and communities. Medical Mentorship will have meaningful impacts annually through three strategies: (1) Year-round mentoring and college preparation programs for 250 teens to explore health career options; (2) Medical Mentorship: Food as Health materials and programs for 2,000 children and families; and (3) Professional development for 200 educators, community members, and parents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Using a mouse model in which we can control the timing of mutant gene activation, we will determine the stage/s in which a known Parkinson disease (PD) mutation acts. Although clinical symptoms of PD arise later in life, we do not know whether the influence of known mutations are sustained throughout life, or at a discrete time interval. This question becomes critical in the search for more effective therapeutic strategies, the identification of the optimal window of therapeutic intervention, the discovery of mutations that contribute to PD, and the development of more accurate assays to measure their biological impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Therapeutic Targeting in EGFR-amplified Glioblastoma  Despite the established role of EGFR amplification as an oncogenic driver in glioblastoma (GBM) and continuous efforts to target EGFR for GBM treatments, our knowledge of the mechanisms involved in EGFR- driven GBM malignancy and clinical failures of EGFR-targeting therapies for treating GBM is incomplete. In this project, we propose to explore new therapeutic approaches for EGFR-amplified GBM by assessing the role of a largely uncharacterized gene that is co-amplified with EGFR in GBM biology and therapy response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The importance of germline predisposition to myeloid malignancies is now well-established in hematology, and the Myeloid Malignancy Variant Curation Expert Panel (MM-VCEP), co-chaired by Drs. Lucy A. Godley and David Wu, has developed, implemented, and revised RUNX1 curation rules, with similar rules to be completed for DDX41/GATA2 by Jan 2024, and ANKRD26/ETV6 by Mar 2024. In this renewal application, the MM-VCEP seeks to expand its gene portfolio to include CEBPA as well as SAMD9/SAMD9L, major drivers of pediatric MMs, and TERT/TERC, causes of telomere biology disorders and adult-onset MMs. The MM-VCEP seeks to classify variants whenever possible in the pathogenic/likely pathogenic range and will use innovative approaches to applying segregation codes at their strongest levels by incorporating: (i) three patient/family-focused organizations [ConnectMyVariant, the RUNX1 Research Program, and Team Telomere, Inc.]; and (ii) additional variant databases that complement the resources available in ClinVar [the St. Jude Childrenâs Research Hospital SAMD9/SAMD9L variant database and the Clinical Care Consortium for Telomere-Associated Ailment international registry].

By educating middle school and high school students about climate change, wildfires, and public health through research, we hope to raise awareness about these emerging crises within rural communities, as well as increase studentsâ interest in STEM careers and research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dysfunctions of sensorimotor behaviors are among the most common and devastating aspects of neurological disorders. Converging evidence from humans and animal models indicate that the cerebello-thalamocortical and basal ganglia-thalamocortico pathways play critical and complementary roles in sensorimotor behaviors. However, we do not have a coherent understanding of how these pathways support the basic building blocks of sensorimotor behavior including coordination, integration, and learning. In this proposal, we will combine large-scale multi-region electrophysiology and multi-region neural network modeling to tease apart the complementary roles of these pathways in sensorimotor behavior. This work will elucidate the computational principles, anatomical substrates, and physiological mechanisms of sensorimotor function, and promises to facilitate the development of diagnostics and treatments for victims of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Mobile element insertions, caused by retrotransposon insertion, are an understudied source of genetic variation that have been linked to numerous neurological disorders through their modulation of alternative splicing. This proposal seeks to use large genomic datasets to characterize the associations between mobile element insertions and neurological disease, with a heavy emphasis on SINE-VNTR-Alu (SVA) elements, a hominid- specific retrotransposon with unique patterns of variation. This work will leverage the utility of transcriptomic data and long-read whole genome sequencing data for establishing mobile element insertions as an important component of neurological disease genetics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is currently the 8th leading cause of cancer death in the United States and is unusual for its high frequency of epigenome regulator gene mutations, including a gene called SETD2 that when mutated, is associated with reduced survival and metastasis. SETD2 may regulate a novel mechanism that controls mRNA level and stability known as RNA methylation. This is exciting not only because it could represent a new way SETD2 loss drives cancer growth, but also because drugs are being developed to target RNA methylation that might be effective in treating SETD2 mutant renal cell cancer.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Forty-one million people die every year from non-communicable diseases (NCDs), accounting for 71% of all global deaths and premature deaths, defined as deaths occurring in persons aged 30-69 years, disproportionately impact low- and middle- income countries (LMICs) like Ghana. There is an urgent need to sustainably build NCD expertise in Ghana for cardiovascular, metabolic and pulmonary disease, with the ultimate goal of training experts who will generate research evidence that can advance public health policy and improve public health. The goal of this training program with experienced faculty from the Kintampo Health Research Centre and University of Ghana School of Public Health and US-partners at Columbia University and Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai is to provide mentored life course NCD and environmental epidemiology training to Ghanaian researchers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) is a complex neurological condition, and there are currently no FDA- approved treatments to directly treat cognitive deficits. The proposed study will delineate a novel mechanistic role of the epichaperome in the pathophysiology of experimental TBI and use systemic delivery of the epichaperome inhibitor, PU-AD, to evaluate its therapeutic efficacy in attenuating cognitive dysfunction and provide evidence for a role of the epichaperome in TBI pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Upper airway obstruction (UAO) in neonates/infants is a potentially life-threatening condition however, currently available modalities for diagnosing UAO are based on subjective assessments and do not provide quantitative measures of airflow disruption or anatomic resolution of the sites of obstruction over the course of the dynamic respiratory cycle. Our goal is to develop an innovative, anatomically precise, patient specific diagnostic modality for UAO via the integration of dynamic upper airway computed tomography scanning with computational fluid dynamics. This work has the potential to revolutionize the diagnosis and treatment decision making process for patients with UAO as well as to significantly improve clinical outcomes by tailoring a treatment plan to the individual patientâs specific patientâs airway pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An evolutionary expansion of the cortex, in particular corticospinal neurons, has long been hypothesized to underlie the exceptional dexterity of primates, but it is unclear how this expansion affects neural circuits and whether there is a causal link between corticospinal neuron number and dexterous behavior. Deer mice (Peromyscus maniculatus) are a uniquely advantageous system in which to address this problem as an experimentally tractable system with innate natural variation in motor skill that correlates with variation in corticospinal neuron number. This proposal thus aims to use deer mice to test the hypothesis that the expansion of specific corticospinal neuron populations results in changes in neural activity and dexterous behavior, thus fulfilling the seventh goal of the BRAIN Initiative by integrating across levels of understanding to contextualize cell types in circuit function, and circuit function in behavioral output.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Malaria parasites must cycle between their mosquito and mammalian hosts yet the role of parasite burden in the mosquito to ongoing transmission has not been investigated. We have recently found that highly infected mosquitoes are 7.5 times more likely to initiate malaria infection. The proposed study will investigate the mechanisms underlying the increased infectiousness of highly infected mosquitoes, the results of which will inform epidemiologic models and design of transmission-blocking strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fundamental advances in our understanding of the normal function of the human brain, and how this understanding can be used to combat brain disorders, will increasingly depend on researchers equipped with multidisciplinary technical expertise. This grant supports an advanced hands-on three-week summer course which provides a forum for in-depth evaluation of the emerging and converging research efforts linking ion channel biology, synaptic and circuit function to human brain physiology and disease. The course communicates fundamental concepts and cutting-edge experimental approaches to a select cadre of graduate and postgraduate trainees, who will immediately apply what they learn to their own areas of neurobiological research. This highly intensive course helps to embed the trainees in a motivated and collaborative network of like-minded scientists who are working to understand the fundamental operating principles of the central nervous system and the etiology of neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance Statement: The proposed research is relevant to public health because Planning Together intervention is an accessible contraceptive education program for economically marginalized families to improve consistent desired contraceptive use postpartum. Planning Together protocol targets multiple levels of factors impacting contraceptive use, including (a) reducing social barriers (i.e., harnessing existing social support by including the sexual partner and optimizing couple contraceptive communication using evidence- based techniques), (b) reducing structural barriers associated with structural drivers of health (SDOH) that can negatively impact consistent desired contraceptive use, via (c) providing a flexible delivery method (ie., synchronous and asynchronous components; online and in-person intervention access) to increase access and scalability. This innovative couple-based, multi-level intervention has the potential to redesign existing family planning education modes to improve consistently desired couple contraceptive usage, with the longer- term goal of reducing short interpregnancy intervals (SIIs).

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Drowning is a leading cause of unintentional death among 1-to-14 year olds in the U.S. and a source of permanent brain damage and other long-term impairments among individuals across all ages. Many drownings occur despite the presence of lifeguards, which rather than reflecting poor lifesaving skills or negligence is likely caused by fundamental limitations of human perception and attention. The goal of this project is to develop a set of tools through which the complex environment and task of lifeguard surveillance can be studied under controllable conditions in order to identify specific sources of surveillance failure which can then be used to guide the development of targeted training and operational procedures aimed at reducing the number of preventable drownings that occur each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pancreatic cancer (PC) is one of the most lethal forms of cancer in the United States (5-year survival rate below 10%) and is often treated with adjuvant chemotherapeutics (e.g., gemcitabine, 5-FU and oxaliplatin) known for their high off-target delivery and systemic toxicity. There is an urgent need to develop new therapeutic strategies consisting of delivery vehicles able to actively target PC cells, limit chemotherapy off-target toxicity and improve the overall anticancer response. To address this unmet medical need, we will leverage our experience in cancer-specific antigen discovery and validation, bio-nanomaterial engineering, and exosome biology to test the novel hypothesis that EMs engineered with a nanobody against ICAM1, an overexpressed PC surface protein, and loaded with gemcitabine, 5-FU and oxaliplatin can be used as a novel biological nanomedicine for precision PC therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Sensory neurons and immune cells play key roles in skin inflammation and disease. In this application, we seek to develop recombinant botulinum proteases that can penetrate into skin cells to inhibit the release of neuropeptides in neurons and cytokines in immune cells. When successful, these studies will identify topical therapeutic candidates that could be used to regulate inflammation for the treatment of a myriad of skin diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative. The mission of this SEPA grant at California State University San Marcos (CSUSM) is to foster thoughtful American Indian scholars of science by engaging motivated American Indian youth and their families in a culturally validated, comprehensive and layered science education, mentoring, and research program that will build the skills and confidence necessary for students to matriculate into and succeed in the biomedical and behavioral sciences. Youth will be provided mentoring from both program faculty and from near-peer mentors, will engage in interactive science activities, and will have the opportunity to both shadow in research labs and develop their own research projects to address substance use and opioid overdose in their communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative. This project is relevant to public health because it aims to identify a novel mechanism of Cannabis Use Disorder, a major public health concern in the era of increasing cannabis legalization. Stress- elicited cannabis use motivation is associated with worse Cannabis Use Disorder outcomes, but how stress impacts cannabis use motivation is not well-understood. This study seeks to identify a causal physiological mechanism driving stress increases in neural drug-cue reactivity in order to pave the way for rapid development and testing of targeted treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The biological determinants of Alzheimerâs disease and related dementias (ADRD) are established decades before clinical symptoms of cognitive decline, memory loss and functional decline are observed. As age is the most reliable predictor of ADRD, the proposed study will test whether biological age, as opposed to chronological age, predicts higher levels of preclinical AD biomarkers, as measured with a highly reliable plasma beta-amyloid (AÎ²) marker, and whether AÎ² accumulation contributes to cognitive decline in midlife in a well-established longitudinal twin sample, the Louisville Twin Study. The nature of this twin design will inform causal pathways between early life development, biological age, AÎ², and cognitive functioning at midlife, shedding light on genetic and environmental mechanisms that promote risk and resilience of preclinical AD.

PHR: Systemic sclerosis (SSc)-associated interstitial lung disease (SSc-ILD) is currently the most lethal complication of the disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The mammalian gastrointestinal tract combines a variety of influences to maintain intestinal homeostasis. We found that complement component 3 (C3), typically associated with innate inflammatory responses in circulation, was expressed in the distal small intestine (DSI) in enterocytes, Paneth cells, and fibroblasts in response to non-inflammatory commensal colonization. We aim to characterize the nature of C3 expression in the GI tract and identify novel functions of C3 by examining the role it plays in regulating bacteria and immune cells to facilitate intestinal homeostasis through non-inflammatory defense mechanisms.

PHR: Uterine fibroids are common noncancerous tumors that can cause women to have severe bleeding, pelvic pressure and pain, urinary dysfunction, and adverse pregnancy outcomes. How fibroids develop or how they can be treated without resorting to hysterectomy is not well understood, in large part because it is difficult to study in humans. Our goal in this proposal is to begin developing a better model system to study fibroid biology and test new therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal seeks to elaborate how DNA repair enzymes protect against mutations caused by damage (deamination) occurring to 5-methylcytosine (mC), a modified DNA base that has essential functions in regulating gene expression. A large fraction of point mutations in cancer and genetic disease are attributable to mC deamination. The studies will reveal how repair enzymes counter this threat and inform why these mutations are still prevalent in human DNA. The studies will also reveal how these enzymes contribute to regulating the levels of DNA methylation (mC), which is important because aberrant DNA methylation is implicated in diseases including cancer, and in ageing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to investigate the brain-body interaction between breath-by-breath O2-CO2 exchange ratio (bER) and brain activities as a mechanism of mindfulness meditation. We plan to compare the effect of mindfulness meditation with that of spontaneous breathing at rest without mindfulness and of paced breathing at six breaths per minute. We measure physiological outcomes and use functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to map the correlation between bER and blood oxygenation level dependent signal (BOLD) changes at brain regions and networks of interest including those at the brainstem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Although congenital cytomegalovirus (cCMV) infection is the most common congenital infection in the US, important questions remain regarding its long-term sequelae. To address this critical knowledge gap, we propose to leverage existing data on over 29 million neonates in order to generate high-quality evidence on the risks of long-term neurologic and non-neurologic sequelae of clinically recognized cCMV and on the benefits of available treatments for these outcomes.The findings from this research will not only inform the value of universal screening, early antiviral treatments and vaccines, but will also raise awareness among patients and clinicians for this important but underrecognized congenital infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disproportionately high incidence and rates of death from cervical cancer occur in populations where socioeconomic and geographical barriers limit access to routine gynecological clinical care. This proposal will demonstrate the feasibility of a novel screening approach for cervical cancer using a topically applied, disease- specific plasmid containing a secreted reporter protein that can be non-invasively collected in cervical fluids. If successful, this diagnostic approach is anticipated to enable highly specific, cost-effective, self-applied cervical cancer screening to facilitate targeted clinical follow up and treatment for individuals in high-risk settings associated with reduced access to routine gynecological care.

PHR: Project Narrative Heterotaxy (HTX) is a disorder of left-right (LR) patterning of the form and function of internal organs like heart, affecting 1 in 10,000 live births. We have established a collaboration between clinicians and basic scientists to recruit patients with HTX and identify candidate genes/variants using whole exome sequencing, followed by their experimental analysis to validate the genes as disease-causing and improve our understanding of the underlying disease mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Summer Healthcare Experience (SHE) in Oncology is a virtual, multi-institutional STEM enrichment program for high school students, with a mission to increase participation of women from underrepresented backgrounds in the cancer biomedical workforce. The curriculum offers hands-on research experience, career exploration, mentorship, and leadership training, drawing strategically from the unique strengths and resources of multiple cancer centers. This proposal details plans to expand SHE in fundamental ways including year-round programming, formalized support for program alumni, and rigorous evaluation to validate and strengthen the SHE program model for expansion to new institutional cohorts nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Although perinatal and early childhood infections are one of the greatest risk factors associated with neurodevelopmental disorders, we have a limited understanding of how systemic immune processes contribute to brain development or the etiology of these disorders. Notably, several genetic risk factors associated with immune function are also implicated in these disorders and there is increasing evidence that neuroimmune interactions between the peripheral immune system and brain during critical periods of development can have long term effects on brain function and behavior. This project seeks to elucidate the role of the adaptive immune system and inflammation in the development and function of the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) and its associated neurocircuitry, with the goal of understanding how they contribute to normal development, as well as the pathophysiology associated with neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Intervertebral disc degeneration affects nearly half of people over 40 years of age and contributes to pain and disability in affected individuals. Bone marrow stem cells delivered to the disc have can slow disc degeneration by secreting factors that help to repair the resident tissue and stave off inflammation, but current methods of cell delivery do not support the transplanted cells. We will develop gels that are tethered with small peptides that support the transplanted stem cells by promoting signaling through the insulin like growth factor receptor, and test their impact at repairing disc tissue in rats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Integrin adhesion receptors on the surface of epidermal keratinocytes have critical roles in controlling the cell microenvironment and in mediating aspects of cutaneous wound healing. Integrin Î±3Î²1-dependent wound processes that were established in young mice, such as (1) timely reepithelialization and (2) induction of epidermal factors that mediate immune cell infiltration, are known to be compromised in aging skin of humans and rodents. The goal of the proposed work is to assess these wound processes in young, middle, and aged mice that express or lack epidermal Î±3Î²1, in order to determine whether Î±3Î²1-dependent functions are diminished during intrinsic (chronological) aging thereby impeding the ability to heal wounds, towards the long term goal of exploiting integrin Î±3Î²1 as a therapeutic target to promote wound repair in the elderly.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetics and microbiome, and their interaction with a wide variety of exposures ranging play a critical role development and progress of non-communicable diseases (NCD) but there are limited genetic epidemiology research in Vietnam, due in part to a lack of existing infrastructure, an existing cadre of trained investigators, and funding. This proposed Vanderbilt University Medical Center (VUMC) and Vietnamese (Hanoi Medical University [HMU] and Vietnam National Cancer institute [VNCI]) partnership will expand upon our existing partnership to establish the new Vanderbilt-Vietnam Genetic Epidemiology (V2-GENE) Training Program focused on training student in the tools needed for genetic analysis of NCDs, across types of diseases. There is shortage of trained genetic epidemiologist in low-middle income countries (LMICs) trained in genetic epidemiology, our goals with V2-GENE are to equip educators and trainees with the skills in genetic epidemiology to engage in sustainable long-term research activities in genetic studies of lifecourse and non- communicable diseases and to further solidify the collaborations and partnerships across VUMC faculty within low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired kidney oxygenation is often identified as a common denominator of deteriorated kidney function in a variety of kidney diseases, such as acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and its transition to end-stage renal failure. Noninvasive measurement and quantification of renal tissue oxygenation is crucial for clinical management and treatment. This work will develop motion-robust, fully ungated free-breathing abdominal MRI for quantification of renal oxygen extraction fraction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this proposal is to determine the mechanism by which G protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) respond to neurotransmitters and hormones, and modify the function of cells by activating G proteins, kinases and arrestins. This information will facilitate the process of drug discovery for GPCRs, which are the largest family of membrane proteins in the human genome. Drugs acting on GPCRs can have an impact on a broad spectrum of diseases including neurologic and psychiatric disorders, Alzheimerâs disease, cardiovascular disease, pulmonary disease, inflammation, diabetes, and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The Scientist Spotlights Partnership Program: Engaging High School Students in Exploring Biomedical Science Careers by Connecting  with Counter-Stereotypical Scientists Project Narrative The Scientist Spotlights Partnership Program aims to promote high school studentsâ science identity, relatability to scientists, and interest in biomedical science careers by engaging them in interviewing biomedical scientists and authoring Scientist Spotlights, which are curricular supplements highlighting the stories of counter-stereotypical scientists that can be used to teach science content standards. To investigate the impact of engaging high school students in authoring Scientist Spotlights, we will partner high school teachers with near peer undergraduate student mentors from diverse backgrounds who will together guide high school students through the authoring process and collaborate on assessing the impact on studentsâ science attitudes and career interests. Over 5 years, we aim to collaborate with ~40 science teachers, ~80 near peer undergraduate mentors, and ~1280 high school students who will author ~640 peer-reviewed biomedical Scientist Spotlights that will be disseminated, along with research results, through the free, online, and open access Scientist Spotlights Initiative website. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The program, termed Walk IN Dental Oral Ways of Science (WINDOWS), builds upon our successes with recently funded undergraduate/postdoctoral research training programs, and is tailored to address the oral health disparities present throughout the state of Oregon. Through a variety of outreach activities, in class experiences, and research internships our program will further enlighten learners about dental, oral and craniofacial health and disease and bolster the competitiveness of our trainees as they pursue advanced education. The program will open the windows for students to see the many different possibilities for future careers in dentistry and dental, oral, and craniofacial research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative A significant correlation exists between inflammation, defects in chondrocyte proliferation, and cartilage repair in osteoarthritis (OA) patients and animal models. In this study, we will exploit the immunoregulatory mechanisms in play during the embryo development to develop a novel therapeutic to treat OA by utilizing multi-tissue organoid (MTO)-derived exosomes to regulate inflammation and promote chondrocyte proliferation, which will facilitate cartilage repair to alleviate the symptoms and arrest disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Precise connections between neurons in the brain are needed for understanding sounds and localizing their sources. Defects in brain circuits that process sounds can lead to language difficulties and problems with sound perception. This project will explore new mechanisms that help form these brain circuits during development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has claimed 6.9 million lives with 767 million people infected world-wide. While vaccines are generally effective to prevent viral infection, antiviral drugs provide an alternative and effective mean to treat COVID-19 and post-COVID syndromes including lung and kidney complications. In this study, we use a novel fission yeast and human cell-based system to discover SARS-CoV-2 ORF3a inhibitors with a goal to develop new antiviral drugs that can be used to treat COVID-19 and post-COVID complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: Narrative: Genetic mutations in ATP1A3 present with an extraordinarily wide range of symptoms, which is an obstacle to both diagnosis and the development of treatments. We are making two major shifts, one to use an unbiased gene-first approach to the discovery of ATP1A3 clinical consequences, and the other to move toward mechanism-based treatments. A shift towards telemedicine will broaden our reach; partnerships with databases that encompass gene and clinical records will give access to information on patients with or without diagnoses; and laboratory studies will investigate mechanisms of treating mutation damage with a pharmacological approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Memantine is a drug used for adult dementia patients that has been shown to decrease the changes in thinking and memory that occur after whole brain radiotherapy in adults with brain metastasis. Based on the mechanism of action and animal models we expect memantine will be effective and safe for reducing short and long-term changes in brain function for children receiving radiation for brain tumors. Reduction of specific brain volumes after radiotherapy are associated with memory and thinking changes and we also hypothesize that neuroprotection with memantine will result in a reduction in volume loss in critical regions of the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project studies the interaction with RNA and activity of a class of small molecules that feature the pharmaceutical properties of successful drugs. Their development into drug candidates with validated cellular activity would open up a large reservoir of untapped targets to treat human disease, but success requires a fundamental chemical and biophysical understanding of how these molecules bind to RNA so potently. This project will pursue fundamental studies of molecular recognition of RNA by drug-like small molecules and utilize this knowledge to discover new inhibitors of replication of the highly pathogenic Dengue and Zika viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TDP-43 is known to be critical to the pathogenesis of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) but now has also become an important player in the Alzheimer's disease neurodegenerative process. We have been studying TDP-43 in FTLD and in Alzheimer's disease for over a decade and have made significant discoveries that have contributed to better understanding and recent awareness of the importance of TDP-43 beyond FTLD. In this 3rd cycle we will expand upon our recent discoveries that there are two different types of TDP-43 deposition in Alzheimer's disease and that different molecular specie of TDP-43 are associated with different inclusions in FTLD, as well as develop a biomarker using [18F]-fluorodeoxyglucose PET scan to help predict the presence of TDP-43 in Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Communication between cells of gastric epithelial glands and surrounding stromal cells is indispensable for normal stomach function and misregulation of the signaling networks executing this communication can cause inflammation and precancerous lesions that can become cancerous. Helicobacter. pylori infection, the highest risk factor for gastric cancer, disrupts signals originating from stromal cells that maintain normal growth and function of epithelial glands and prevent inflammation. The current proposal will define how misregulation of protein kinase A (PKA) signaling causes inflammation and precancerous lesions via disrupting stromal-epithelial communication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The human cathelicidin peptide LL-37 is unique in our proteome, and is central to innate immunity as an antibacterial and antiviral defense molecule released from immune and epithelial cells. Based on Dr. Barronâs discovery that LL-37 binds the Alzheimerâs-associated peptide Ab, forming a stable nontoxic complex, halting Ab fibril formation, and abolishing Ab cytotoxicity to neurons, this project will determine whether chronic, oral P. gingivalis infection sets the stage for dementia via degradation of LL-37, and a subsequent crippling of the brainâs immune defense and regeneration mechanisms. In vivo studies will explore this novel innate immune etiology and mechanism for sporadic Alzheimerâs dementia, and test whether disease is prevented by early-life upregulation of LL-37 to disallow establishment of infections. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The prevalence of Alzheimerâs Disease is rising, but existing medications provide only modest control of cognitive decline and associated symptoms, and novel therapies are urgently needed. This randomized controlled trial will determine if an innovative low-risk neurostimulation at home can improve cognitive performance and symptoms in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimerâs Disease. If effective, this novel intervention can substantially enhance Alzheimerâs Disease symptom management at home, improve quality of life of Alzheimerâs Disease patients and their families, and reduce burden associated with this debilitating illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted disease (STI) with important public health ramifications; it has been associated with vaginitis, cervicitis, urethritis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Trichomoniasis also impacts upon birth outcomes, increased susceptibility to HIV infection and cervical cancer in women. Because of increased resistance to treatment and the important health consequences of infection, new research is needed to understand the mechanism the pathogenesis and to identify new drug targets within the parasite. We propose to analyze the role of DNA methylation in the regulation of gene expression and 3D genome architecture to understand how this mechanism contribute to T. vaginalis pathogenesis. The outcome of these studies will provide significant new insights into gene regulation and may lay the foundation for the basis for an attractive new drug targets against Trichomoniasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: NARRATIVE Justice-involved Black/African American female adolescents and their parents/caregivers are particularly vulnerable to post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) due to unique life histories and exposure to trauma. Unfortunately, few, if any, PTSD prevention interventions have been tested with this population to address their unique life experiences. The proposed project will use healing tenets to adapt and test a stress reduction intervention with justice-involved Black/African American female adolescents and parent/caregiver dyads to address the critical gaps in health and mental health disparities, interventions, and scientific knowledge to promote health equity and healing in this vulnerable, underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Many parasitic nematodes require insect vectors for transmission, but it is not well known how these species modify their host seeking behavior between insects and humans. We use a genetically tractable nematode model with insect host association to study which genes affect preferences for taste and smell during development. A comparison of how homologous genes control neuronal fates across different species could reveal important molecular regulators for wiring chemosensory behavior and thus improve preventive measures for interfering with host detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to establish general and flexible synthetic approaches and methodologies to enable access of bioactive natural products and other medicinally important molecules, which are otherwise very difficult to acquire due to their scarcity, structural complexity, and high cost. This research will also open new avenues toward chemical libraries featuring structurally novel small molecules that incorporate the key structural elements of the selected natural molecules for anticancer, antimicrobial, and anti-neurodegenerative drug discovery. The strategies and methodologies developed in this research will significantly enrich the toolbox of both synthetic chemists and medicinal chemists.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Although immune checkpoint inhibitors targeting the PD-1 pathway have transformed the management of advanced renal cell carcinoma, the majority of patients do not receive long-term benefit from these therapies, and the determinants of therapeutic response in this immunobiologically distinct tumor type remain largely unknown. By leveraging our expertise in immunogenomics and our unique access to large, clinically annotated, genomic cohorts, we aim to uncover the key genetic and immune determinants of effective, immune checkpoint inhibitor-mediated, anti-tumor immunity in renal cell carcinoma. Overall, this work will impact public health by revealing key mediators of therapeutic response and resistance and by identifying new therapeutic targets for immunomodulation in patients with advanced kidney cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative  The goal of this project is to develop an innovative drug development platform for antiviral precision medicine. By integrating molecular pattern matching, DNA-based nanotechnology, customizable high- throughput safe pseudoviral detection and inhibition assays, live virus binding and inhibition validations, along with an animal model of COVID-19, we program, synthesize, screen, validate and optimize designer DNA- based nanoconstructs (DDNs) that can directly recognize and block enveloped viruses through their distinct surface epitope distribution features. The designed DDNs exhibited super sensitive binding and potent antiviral effects, suggesting that this DDN designing platform may contribute to a rapid development of antiviral precision medicine against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants that are highly transmissible and/or resistant to convalescent sera, as well as other enveloped viruses such as influenza and HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents with Achilles tendon injury may suffer long-term health detriments and impediments to physically active lifestyles due to a poor understanding of the health and functional impact of heel pain in patients under 18 years old. This project will investigate the effect of heel pain on adolescent Achilles tendon health and lower limb biomechanics. Findings from this research will provide necessary evidence for establishing the pathoetiology of adolescent heel pain, as proper injury diagnosis will allow adolescents with heel pain to receive the appropriate clinical care and maintain physically active lifestyles into adulthood.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The function of the placenta determines life-long health because changes in placental function play an important role in the development of many pregnancy complications and increases the risk of developing diseases such as obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease and cancer in adult life. Our understanding of placental function is however limited, in part because there are currently few scientific meetings specifically focused on the placenta that brings together the best researchers from different disciplines to solve the most urgent questions. To meet this need, we propose to organize a unique annual meeting focused on the role of the placenta in causing diseases of profound public health significance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Osteoarthritis (OA) is a disease that affects 54 million people in the United States. Despite advances in therapeutics across medicine, there remains no disease-modifying OA drugs (DMOADs). While joint replacement therapy restores mobility and controls symptoms, it is the most costly hospital treated medical condition for Medicare patients in the USA. Thus, there is critical need for better understanding of OA and the identification of new targets for the development of disease modifying treatments. This proposal provides new mechanistic insights toward understanding the role of TGFï¢ (via TAK1) and Igf1 in regulation of chondrocyte homeostasis and glucose metabolism, especially glycolysis and HBP in OA. We expect to identify new targets and pathways as new strategies to treat OA.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Nearly 2% of youth in the United States identify as transgender and many seek treatment to block unwanted secondary sex characteristics and later start gender-affirming hormone treatments (testosterone or estradiol) so that their body aligns with their identity. The effects of these treatments on cardiovascular health and diabetes risk are significantly understudied in adults and adolescents. In this longitudinal, observational study, we will investigate effects of puberty blockers and estradiol on insulin resistance and vascular health in adolescent transgender females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Relapse and/or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (AML) display intrinsic resistance to targeted therapies. Venetoclax-resistant AML is functionally reliant upon MCL1 and consequently, vulnerable to MCL1 genetic or pharmacologic perturbation. This proposal aims to define the precise mechanisms by which MCL1 uniquely influences AML therapy resistance through a non-canonical role in regulating mitochondrial fission and Î²- oxidation, introducing novel pathways for further therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The SOMMA project is a large-scale trial designed to determine key biological properties of skeletal muscle that are related to incident major mobility disability, declines in mobility and declines in fitness in older adults (> 70yr) over the course of three years, while also collecting adipose tissue (AT) and blood. The experiments proposed in this ancillary study will examine the influence of AT structure and function on AT-secreted proteins that are related with mobility disability and can directly impact skeletal muscle function. The proposed work will also quantify the AT-secreted proteins in circulation that are found to directly affect skeletal muscle function, as well as contribute all excess biospecimens to the parent SOMMA project biorepository for future use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many genetic research studies have shown that a relatively obscure region on chromosome 2 is highly associated with human coronary artery disease, but how this region of the genome causes heart disease is unknown. This proposed study examines how this obscure region is linked with a gene associated with cancer, ZEB2, and shows how this gene can influence a personâs chance of a heart attack using a combination of state of the art tools including genome editing, cell and animal models, and genetic data at the level of single individual cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The protein SAMHD1 is of substantial medical interest because it functions both as a viral restriction factor and a modulator of the innate immune response. Numerous biochemical and cellular properties of SAMHD1 have been investigated, and some of these properties have been found to correlate with SAMHD1 antiviral activity. However, how SAMHD1 is regulated and the mechanisms by which SAMHD1 exerts its effects, both on viruses and the innate immune system, are not fully defined. Filling these knowledge gaps is crucial for both identifying novel antiviral targets and developing therapeutic approaches for the treatment of AGS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Tumor heterogeneity has been recognized as one of the leading determinants of therapeutic resistance and treatment failure, contributing to poor clinical outcomes. However, the non-genetic, cell intrinsic origins of tumor cell heterogeneity remain poorly understood particularly in gastric cancer. This project is relevant to human health because it focuses on identification of the origins, evolution, and mechanisms that drive cellular heterogeneity of metastatic gastric cancer as well as how to target this heterogeneity to improve therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) is a severe lung disease that occurs in 10% of all preterm births. About 15,000 BPD cases are reported per year in the US. The costs of caring for BPD patients in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) are over $350,000 each just in the first months of life. Such costs are over twice the amount required for NICU patients without BPD. This application aims to develop for human use a novel drug that improves lung development in animal models of BPD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: OREGON MUSEUM OF SCIENCES AND INDUSTRY
PHR: Project Narrative The Wildfire and Human Health in a Changing Climate project will develop a 1,400-square-foot bilingual (Spanish/English) traveling exhibition, accompanying website, and related educational resources to promote public understanding of the causes of, health impacts of, and resilient responses to large and severe wildfires. The exhibition will focus on current research in environmental and forest health, include diverse voices from communities directly and indirectly impacted by wildfire, and reach a national audience of family visitors at museums with a special emphasis on youth underrepresented in STEM ages 11â17. The project will draw direct connections between human health and healthy forests and promote collective strategies to mitigate and adapt to wildfires in support of positive health outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid use disorder and opioid overdose impacted many tens of thousands in the United States alone. However, the fundamental basic mechanisms by which opioids act in the brain to influence natural reward behaviors remain unknown. This proposal will isolate how endogenous opioid systems function in reward circuits within the context of natural reward seeking, providing new insight into how opioid systems natural states may be negatively impact in substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed training activities will investigate the overlapping and distinct psychological and neural mechanisms engaged by mindfulness meditation to induce pain and stress relief. This research will contribute to the optimization of mindfulness meditation as a pain and stress management intervention option for millions of people suffering from these ailments worldwide. My work on this project will equip me with a skillset that fully prepares me for a career as an independent cognitive neuroscientist at a research-focused academic institution, studying complementary approaches to treating pain and comorbid health conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE One of the most well-known hallmarks of human aging is cellular senescence; however the relationship between senescence and Alzheimerâs Disease (AD) is poorly understood. We hypothesize that soluble amyloids, but not fibrils or plaques, link the induction of cellular senescence in brain cells to neurodegeneration, yet it remains unclear which soluble amyloids modulate these behaviors. In order to test this hypothesis, we will utilize a combination of genetic and epigenetic measurements to compare the ability of synthetic and patient-derived amyloids to induce senescence in brain cells, thereby deducing the molecular and epigenetic overlap between senescence and AD.

PHR: Project Narrative There is a great need to improve the quality of dental care delivered to patients. Currently, dentistry does not have broadly accepted quality measures that inform the need for improvements in care. In this project we seek to first understand the reasons for suboptimal performance with regard to caries management at four large dental institutions, and then develop and evaluate system-level approaches to improve the quality of caries management.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The central goal of this proposal is to disseminate MAPseq and BARseq to the broader neuroscience community. The dissemination of these high-throughput methods for determining neuronal projections will enable many laboratories to use these methods to understand normal neuronal circuitry, and how this circuitry is disrupted in animal models of neuropsychiatric disorders like autism and schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative:  Autoimmune and inflammatory diseases affect tens of millions of people in the United States39 and are characterized by a significant reduction in IgG sialylation, although the mechanisms underlying this dysregulation remain unclear. Conversely, treatment with exogenous and sialylated IgG in the form of IVIg therapy reverses autoimmune inflammation and helps to restore homeostasis. This proposal seeks to elucidate the regulatory mechanisms underlying changes in endogenous IgG sialylation, which we believe will ultimately provide a novel therapeutic target for sufferers of chronic and autoimmune inflammatory conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Smoking cessation treatment for hospitalized patients must continue when they leave the hospital in order to achieve the best results. Most smokers, however, return to smoking soon after leaving the hospital. This research will develop and test interventions to engage smokers in post-discharge smoking cessation treatment which will positively impact the long-term health of more than 4 million smokers that are hospitalized every year in the U.S.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Mitochondria produce the essential energy needed for neurons to function properly. These organelles are dynamic and move throughout the cell during the lifetime of the neuron; however, little is known about the functional relevance of this movement of mitochondria and how it contributes to the function of the neuron. This proposal will elucidate the fundamental in vivo steady state localization of mitochondria in order to better understand how neurons maintain healthy distributions of mitochondria across their complex structures over their entire lifetime.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Synthesis of new protein is necessary for the long-term adaptations in synaptic structure and function that are required for learning and memory formation. CaMKII, an important neuronal protein, is synthesized after neuronal activity, but it is not well understood how this process is controlled, nor how it is coordinated presynaptically and postsynaptically. This project will build an understanding of these mechanisms and may provide insight into brain disorders linked to CaMKII dysfunction such as intellectual disability and Alzheimerâs disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Substance Use Disorder (SUD) and HIV-Associated Neurocognitive Disorder (HAND) are disorders for which we have an incomplete knowledge of pathobiological processes in the human CNS, hindering the search for new therapeutic targets. To address this challenge, we dissect the transcriptional and epigenetic changes associated with SUD and persistent HIV infection at single-cell resolution across seven human brain regions, generating a total of 28 million genome-wide single-cell maps across 2800 samples, integrate the resulting datasets to predict driver genes, in order to identify disorder driver genes, regulatory regions, variants, and pathways, and the cell types and brain regions where they act, and validate high-priority findings at the molecular level in human samples and in a mouse model of in vivo cocaine self-administration. The resulting datasets, computational inferences, and biological findings will provide an invaluable resource for understanding HIV, SUD, and HAND, and help guide the development of new therapeutic avenues against these devastating disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Primary Immunodeficiencies (PIDs) are inborn errors of the immune system, affecting 1:780 hospitalized children. Despite widespread incomplete penetrance leading to difficulties in the study and clinical management of these diseases, we have a very limited understanding of the factors that drive phenotypic variability. This proposed study will uncover PID genes that are regulated by monoallelic expression (MAE) and the impact the resulting transcriptional heterogeneity has on disease penetrance, setting the foundation for future work aimed at manipulating MAE to reduce the burden of PIDs on child health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Drug resistance to the most effective antimalarials â the artemisinin-class drugs â has established itself and become widespread in Southeast Asia, posing a serious global health threat should these parasites be imported into Africa. Here, we will use individual-based epidemiological simulation to propose and evaluate strategies for how countries can best prepare for the arrival of artemisinin-resistant genotypes. These strategies will aim to prevent, delay, and mitigate the detrimental effects of imported artemisinin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Atropisomerism is a dynamic type of chirality that is ubiquitous in modern drug discovery. Our research program revolves arounds exploiting the conformational space about atropisomeric axes to program target selectivity into promiscuous small-molecules, leading to compounds with fewer off-target effects as leads towards safer therapeutics and more precise tool compounds. Our research program also strives to develop enabling synthetic methodologies that allow for facile access to pharmaceutically relevant atropisomeric scaffolds in enantiopure form.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Relevance to Public Health: MÃ¼llerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS) is a member of the TGFÎ² superfamily which plays important roles during the development of both male and female reproductive systems. Aberrant MIS signaling in males is associated with Persistent Mullerian Duct Syndrome (PMDS). In women, MIS plays an important role in folliculogenesis. Our studies will bring to light how the MIS ligand interacts with its cellular receptors to activate signaling. We anticipate these molecular studies will open up new therapeutic avenues for modifying MIS activity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Targeted therapy for the treatment of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) has greatly improved patient outcomes compared to traditional chemotherapy. However, it is estimated that up to 20% of lung cancer patients receive first-line therapy prior to Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR) mutational analysis, necessitating the need for a rapid and cheap blood-based circulating tumor (ct) DNA test for efficient therapy selection. Additionally, ctDNA can be useful for âliquid biopsyâ and monitoring of response to therapy or acquired resistance to therapy. We have successfully developed a highly multiplexable magneto-nanosensor assay for the detection of âhot spotâ mutation panel for lung cancer targeted therapy monitoring and prognosis. This project is expected to result in clinical validation of a ctDNA EGFR magneto-nanosensor assay, expanding and multiplexing the existing EGFR assay to include Kirsten RAt Sarcoma (KRAS) mutation and certain gene-fusions, and utilizing the expanded assay [for efficient therapy selection and/or therapy response monitoring, and prognosis.]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative - Public Health Relevance  Bacterial biofilms are responsible for a large number of hospital-acquired infections, and currently used antibiotic and disinfection treatments are unable to cope with this epidemic. An integrated understanding of how individual bacterial cells act and interact with each other inside biofilms is necessary to inform new strategies for controlling biofilm growth. This project enables high-resolution, single-cell measurements inside living biofilms by developing new technologies for non-invasive biofilm imaging and computational tracking of thousands of bacterial cells in crowded environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This K12 Program trains scholars who are cancer-focused clinicians to effectively partner with laboratory scientists. Scholars will learn to communicate their research to diverse audiences and build successful research teams that leverage expertise in different areas. Scholars will be taught how to conduct innovative and impactful research that integrates the patient perspective and the latest scientific advances, with the overall goal of improving the care of individuals with cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Chromosomes are the foundation for organizing our genomes and vehicles for genetic inheritance. The goal of this project is to construct the first synthetic mammalian artificial chromosomes that follow Mendelâs laws, from minimal components. Success will transform our fundamental understanding of what comprises a mammalian chromosome and have wide-ranging applications in synthetic biology and biotechnology, such as creation of animal models for drug development and as sources of personalized organs for transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Proline uptake and metabolism via the proline cycle is a critical regulator of cancer cell survival and proliferation, however the role of proline uptake and the proline cycle during osteoblast differentiation and bone formation is unknown. Data generated by this proposal will: 1) establish the necessity and regulation of proline uptake and metabolism during physiological bone formation, and 2) eludicate the role of the proline cycle during osteoblast differentiation and bone formtation. Our findings will have broad implications in bone development and the maintenance and regeneration of bone mass.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Cardiac fibrosis contributes to structural and biological changes that ultimately lead to heart failure, a major cause of morbidity and mortality. We seek to develop new imaging agents to evaluate the process of fibrosis and validate them in mouse models of cardiac fibrosis. Ultimately, this should lead to better management of not only cardiomyopathy, but also a wide range of other fibrotic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment with radiolabeled antibodies targeting the cell surface protein CD33 holds great promise for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) but âon-target, off-tumor cellâ toxicity to normal CD33-expressing blood cells limits clinical use. To overcome this limitation, we will optimize a so-called base editor (BE) technology to efficiently remove CD33 from normal blood cells that we believe is safer and more precise than another technology (called CRISPR/Cas9 editing) that is now entering patient testing. We will conduct well-controlled preclinical studies to develop this BE method for patients at risk for recurrence/development of CD33-expressing neoplasms to enable safe treatment with radiolabeled anti-CD33 antibodies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Youth with type 1 diabetes (T1D) demonstrate insulin resistance when compared to their peers without diabetes, a feature that predisposes these individuals to diabetic kidney disease and cardiovascular disease, the leading causes of morbidity and mortality in T1D. Metformin, a widely-used insulin sensitizing agent, partially improves peripheral insulin sensitivity and cardiovascular function in youth with T1D; however, itâs effects in combination with innovative diabetes technologies including automated insulin delivery systems remains unstudied. In a randomized, placebo-controlled trial, we will expand our understanding of the effects of metformin used in combination with automated insulin delivery systems on alterations in renal vascular resistance, an early indicator of diabetic kidney disease, as well as whole-body and adipose insulin resistance and cardiometabolic function in youth with T1D to help direct future personalized diabetes care to limit diabetic kidney and cardiovascular disease complications.
