IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE There is an urgent public health need to reduce our reliance upon opioids for effective long-term pain management, particularly in knee osteoarthritis (KOA), where the effectiveness of recommended treatments to improve pain and functional limitations are highly variable and identifying clinical and patient-level factors associated with treatment response is a high priority. Central sensitization and sleep disturbance have potent influence in shaping pain and treatment response, but the hypothesized mechanistic action requires further examination. These results will inform scholarly activity and lead to optimized patient-treatment selection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell anemia (SCA) is the most common disorder identified on newborn screening, affecting one in 1000 individuals worldwide, with a mean life expectancy of 42 years. Among its complications, stroke and cognitive disability are prevalent in adults with SCA and who experience a > 50% unemployment rate. In this grant, we will perform brain MRI and cognitive testing in adults with SCA and age/race-matched controls to investigate new mechanisms (neuroinflammation and capillary flow heterogeneity) which likely contribute to stroke and cognitive disability in adults with SCA; if present, these mechanisms may provide new therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Over 30 million major surgeries are performed annually in the US alone. Delayed surgical recovery marked by persistent pain and prolonged functional impairment causes personal suffering, longer exposure to opioids, and decreased quality of life, contributing $8 billion annually to US health care costs. However, biological markers that allow us to accurately predict surgical recovery in individual patients are lacking. My research program will examine the human monocyte system in patients undergoing surgery to identify immunological mechanisms that predict a patient's recovery after surgery and point at modifiable targets for the development of immune- modulating interventions that will safely accelerate surgical recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Neurofibromatosis type 1 syndrome (NF1) is a common genetic disease and NF1 patients are predisposed to several kinds of cancer, especially nerve tumors that start benign but can become malignant. Unfortunately, treatment options for NF1-associated nerve tumors are limited. The goal of this proposal is to use careful genetic and chemical studies to find new drugs to treat and/or prevent the nerve sheath tumors in NF1 patients before they become malignant.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Anxiety disorders commonly begin during adolescence, and are characterized by deficits in the ability to inhibit or extinguish pathological fear. Recent research has provided new understanding of how fear is learned and can be regulated in the adolescent brain, and how the endocannabinoid system shapes these processes; however, these advances have not yet translated into improved therapeutic outcomes for adolescents with anxiety. The proposed project will leverage a multi-modal experimental therapeutics approach to test whether a behavioral intervention (i.e., acute exercise) modifies hypothesized targets that are relevant for the pathophysiology and treatment of anxiety in youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma is an aggressive, incurable type of brain tumors enriched in a subset population of glioma stem cells (GSCs) with self-renewal and tumor initiation capacities. We have established that the activity of a fatty acid desaturase enzyme is essential to maintain GSCs proliferation and tumor initiation in glioma mouse models. Our proposed studies will investigate regulations mechanisms and therapeutic targeting of this enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: With the advent of antiretrovirals, the infection with HIV has become a chronic disease and fortunately people with HIV live longer but diseases usually seen in old people such as stroke and dementia have also become more common in this population. It is not clear how aging with HIV influences or changes the risk of dementia or cerebrovascular disease compared with aging population without HIV. This project aims to investigate whether HIV poses unique challenges that may need to be treated differently than in people without HIV so that people aging with HIV live healthier lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE American youth are growing up in more contextually varied circumstances. While it is established that these circumstances profoundly impact development, little is known about how they become biologically embedded and how this interaction with biology influences trajectories of developmental and health outcomes. The proposed training program will prepare predoctoral and postdoctoral students to bridge research in the developmental science of context and human neurobiology, with cutting-edge quantitative techniques, in order to decipher how the social environment interacts with genomics and the brain to guide development.
PROJECT_TERMS: developmental psychology;Grant;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Developmental Psychology Training Grant

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is little published data on exposure to and evaluations of large-scale, online tobacco control campaigns. The proposed R01 project addresses this gap. Under 2 specific aims, we will identify the independent effects of varying levels of digital message exposure to promote anti-tobacco attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors among youth and young adults, first through a randomized experiment online, and second through a field-based evaluation. These studies will advance the science of digital health and have wide application to future campaigns.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibiotic treatment for tuberculosis (TB) is long and arduous and new therapies are urgently needed, especially for drug-resistant TB and HIV-coinfected persons. Host-directed therapies (HDT) that work in conjunction with antibiotic treatment are attractive for improving immunity to TB and anti-TB treatment. We aim to use novel multivalent synthetic nanoparticle antibodies (SNAbs) to specifically target immune cells that suppress immunity and explore their potential as targets for HDT for TB.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cell motility is a fundamental process that contributes to building and maintaining tissues as well as diseases such as cancer. PHR: Project Narrative Sickle cell disease is among the most common monogenetic diseases worldwide and chronic kidney disease, which occurs in more than half of adults with sickle cell disease, is associated with high mortality. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although HIV infection can be controlled by daily lifelong adherence to expensive antiretroviral ARV therapies, it cannot presently be cured. Reducing the reservoirs of virus that persist in a people on ARV therapy may lead to long-term remission without the need for ongoing medication. This proposal aims to meet this need by identifying mechanisms by which HIV infected cells are able resist elimination by the immune system, setting the stage for future clinical trials aimed at achieving remission or cure of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Bladder cancer, one of the most common genitourinary malignancies, is a highly sex-biased disease that disproportionately affects males. In this proposal, we aim to shed new light on the overlooked and largely undefined epigenetic basis of observed sex differences, as they remain largely undefined. Our expected findings will catalyze the identification of sex-biased genes and regulatory elements for the design of sex-specific bladder cancer screening and treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Both bladder and bowel distention have been identified as primary triggers of autonomic dysreflexia in individuals with spinal cord injury, a sudden sharp rise in blood pressure with intolerable symptoms such as pounding headache and/or chills. We have recently documented as part of our current R01 this massive unmodulated sympathetic reflex which causes widespread vasoconstriction (presenting as severe hypertension) as a limitation for bladder capacity in numerous research participants. The goals of the current multi-disciplinary study incorporating intersystem interactions are 1) to investigate in a controlled laboratory setting and then with mobile at-home monitoring the extent, severity and frequency of occurrence of autonomic dysreflexia with respect to daily bladder and bowel function, in conjunction with identifying potential underlying mechanisms by examining urinary biomarkers for several specific vasoactive hormones, and 2) to regulate cardiovascular function therapeutically as part of bladder and bowel management using spinal cord epidural stimulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research seeks to advance the search for direct acting antiviral drugs for use in combatting COVID-19 through analysis of the SARS CoV-2 RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to define the kinetics of incorporation of canonical and mismatched nucleotides and nucleotide analogs. In addition, the kinetics and mechanism of nucleotide excision by the 3'- 5' proofreading exonuclease will be measured to establish the contribution of the exonuclease to overall fidelity and discrimination against nucleotide analogs. These studies will provide the basis for evaluating the overall fidelity of CoV-2 RNA replication and for testing and advancing the clinical effectiveness of nucleotide analogs used to slow the rates of CoV- 2 viral replication, thereby addressing the pressing need to combat COVID-19.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esophageal diseases are major health problems in the U.S. and throughout the world. The cells that line the esophagus are exposed daily to irritants such as cigarette smoke and alcohol. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  When treatments intended to prevent and treat disease are approved by regulatory bodies, little is known about their potential harms; particularly concerning is the lack of information on the effects of such treatments in many patients who will ultimately receive them (for example, older adults with multiple chronic conditions taking multiple medications). While post-approval real-world evidence can fill this knowledge gap and support optimal treatment decisions, such studies must be designed and analyzed appropriately to avoid bias and erroneous conclusions. Here we propose to develop and evaluate novel methods to increase the validity of nonexperimental studies applying propensity score methods by using data from Medicare beneficiaries linked with a variety of sources including electronic health records and surveys evaluating trends in health and aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with an Inborn Error of Immunity live with uncertainly related to the correct diagnosis, their future, and best management for their condition. The purpose of this study is to provide resources to help physicians and patients make critical decisions regarding care. We will build a database of patient health information and use this as a nexus of efforts to improve patient outcomes by serving as a resource for gene-variant-phenotype in Inborn Errors of Immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE It is now possible to design and deliver treatments that work for as few as a single patient, i.e., as truly personalized ân-of-1â medicines. This project will examine the individual and societal challenges and the ethical implications posed by this disruptive new technology through the perspectives of socio/geo-demographically diverse stakeholders (i.e., clinician-scientists, bioethicists, social issues experts, and parents) and provide ethical guidance. We will develop a set of recommendations and points to consider that can guide the fair and just implementation of individualized genomic medicine as it evolves.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative As the availability of whole-genome sequencing data has grown, so has our appreciation for the role that structural variants (SVs) play in cancers and Mendelian disorders, yet it is still a struggle to determine if an SV observed in a patient is somatic or pathogenic. We propose a new strategy for SV interpretation that dynamically searches tens of thousands of whole genomes to recover any evidence supporting a candidate SV. Searches that return little to no evidence indicate a high-priority variant since SVs that drive cancers and rare diseases should be vanishingly rare in these samples.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative The progressive muscular dystrophy, facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD), is a caused by inappropriate expression of the DUX4 gene, but the disease typically does not progress in a smooth fashion, rather in episodes or stages that are thought to be associated with transient bursts of DUX4 expression, because direct evidence of DUX4 protein in muscle specimens has not yet been demonstrated. This project aims to understand whether transient DUX4 expression is sufficient to trigger degenerative processes or to set up a pro- degenerative state that together with injury will lead to a muscle dystrophic phenotype seen in FSHD patients. This research will advance our understanding of the molecular and cellular mechanisms of disease as well as contribute to our understanding of the external factors that participate in FSHD pathology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The initiation stage of standard buprenorphine treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD) involves risks of experiencing withdrawal, which acts as a major barrier to treatment uptake for many people with OUD. Microdosing initiation of buprenorphine has emerged as a method to avoid withdrawal, however there have been no clinical trials testing its efficacy in minimizing withdrawal or increasing treatment uptake. In a 4-week randomized controlled trial (RCT), we propose to pilot test a buprenorphine microdosing protocol versus standard treatment initiation at home, investigating efficacy, feasibility, withdrawal, stakeholder experiences, and mediators of initiation success.

PHR: Narrative Despite impressive advancements in treatment, cancer continues to be devastating. Tackling these interconnected pathways for new insights will guide future novel treatments and will benefit patient populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will create breakthrough stability for the blocking-layers used in aptamer-based biosensors, and use that improved stability to: (1) achieve at least 5-day operating longevity for the biosensors; (2) create new fundamental knowledge of biofouling kinetics and other sensor degradation mechanisms. With improved operating longevity, aptamer biosensors are then well-positioned to mirror the historical achievement for 10-14 day continuous glucose meters, but instead applied to new applications such as cardiac health and drug metabolism monitoring.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Nearly 38 million individuals worldwide live with HIV, a chronic viral infection associated with neuroinflammation. Chronic infection and neuroinflammation heighten the risk of neurodegenerative disorders linked to genetic mutations such as those in the Parkinsonâs disease gene, LRRK2, which modulates the bodyâs response to bacterial infection. The proposed research will determine the role LRRK2 plays in the immune response to viral infection and contribute to our understanding of the biological consequences of LRRK2 blockade during early stages of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative - Public Health Relevance  To speed the development of therapies for inherited or acquired disorders of hearing and balance, we need to better understand the patterns of cellular damage and molecular disorder associated with each different etiology. Because the ear cannot be biopsied, and non-invasive imaging cannot yet provide cellular or molecular level resolution, all of our insights into the pathologies underlying deafness and balance disorders derive from the study of post-mortem specimens of the human temporal bone, which houses the structures of the external, middle and inner ears. This proposal, to join a national network of laboratories devoted to the study of the human temporal bone, seeks to increase the relevant knowledge base by continued accrual and study of new autopsy specimens, distribution of these specimens to other collaborating laboratories, development of new state-of-the-art techniques to extract cellular and molecular information about temporal bone pathology, and train the next generation of researchers and technicians in the art and science of temporal bone study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall goal for our course is to deliver an intensive cutting edge hands-on training workshop on modeling human cancer in the laboratory mouse to a small group of select early career scientists/trainees (graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and new investigators). Participants completing the course will acquire a working knowledge of how to characterize and analyze mouse models of human cancer including brain, breast, lung, colon, prostate and blood. Additionally, the course will cover organoid culture, surgical techniques, imaging, immunology, ectopic and ortotopic xenografting including PDX, necropsy, pathology and histology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The extensive use of antibiotics has led to the evolution of âsuper bugsâ resistant to all current treatments despite medicine's best efforts to identify new antibiotics and, perhaps more importantly, new targets for drug development. One of nature's most successful strategies has been to inhibit enzymes in bacterial peptidoglycan biosynthesis and targeting this pathway has been historically quite successful in treating bacterial infections. The program proposed here aims to gain a detailed understanding of a critical membrane embedded players in the pathway providing new routes for designing novel broad-spectrum antibacterial agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Microbes require unique biochemical strategies to adapt to changing environmental conditions, such as oxygen limitation. We will define the chemical and biological functions of a new class of metalloenzymes abundant in commensal and pathogenic bacteria that inhabit oxygen-depleted niches in the human body. This work will achieve a fundamental understanding of anaerobic biochemistry in microbial pathogenesis to reveal novel targets for antibacterial therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative (Overall)  The kidney is a vital organ that maintains minute-to-minute regulation of blood composition, a process that occurs through a complex organization of cells and structures into functioning units. The goal of this project is to create a comprehensive spatial map of the various types of molecules using state of the art technologies that will provide a readable and integrated output spanning regulation of genes, gene expression, proteins, metabolites, lipid and extracellular mass at a single cell resolution. Through studying kidney tissue from a representative diverse population, this work will provide key understanding of the functions of the kidney and the changes that occur with aging and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There are no approved treatments to slow or stop the progression of knee osteoarthritis. Identifying individuals with a high risk of rapidly worsening disease who would most benefit from treatments is an important question to address. In this study, we will identify features on knee x-rays that predict individuals at high risk of rapid deterioration of their knee osteoarthritis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Mutations in Complement Factor H (CFH) that interfere with heparan sulfate (HS) binding are major risk factors for age-related macular degeneration (AMD), the leading cause of blindness in the developed world. Although, the roles of CFH and HS in AMD are not understood, preliminary data demonstrate that interactions between HS and a CFH homolog are required for cilia compartment organization in C. elegans sensory neurons and this function appears to be conserved in human photoreceptors. The molecular genetic dissection of these novel CFH and HS functions proposed here will provide substantial insight into a previously unappreciated mechanism for AMD pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Median survival after lung transplant is less than six years, largely due to a high incidence of chronic rejection affecting up to 50% of survivors by five years after transplantation. Donor tissue resident memory T cells (TRM) persist within the allograft after transplantation, and recipient TRM are generated; the ratio of these two populations is associated with short-term clinical outcomes. This proposal will test the relationship between donor TRM persistence and recipient TRM generation on the risk of premature chronic rejection after lung transplantation, with the goal of discovering new therapeutic targets in the pathogenesis of rejection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: Project Narrative The repeated administration of Gd(III)-based MRI contrast agents raises significant concerns due to the potential for in vivo deposition, hypersensitivity, and lethal systemic fibrosis. We propose to develop discrete (Ä = 1.0) brush polymer-based 19F-MRI contrast agents to overcome the longstanding challenges of dispersity, size, rapid renal clearance, and low signal-to-noise ratio of synthetic contrast agents. If the proposed study is successful, it will provide metal-free MRI contrast agents that are safer, selective, more reliable, and chemically versatile for the diagnosis and monitoring of damaged blood vessels, small tumors, and abnormal tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses a critical gap in knowledge regarding the relationship between historical and childhood trauma and health risk in an American Indian (AI) community. Using a community based participatory approach, gold-standard physiological reactivity methods, and comprehensive assessments of behavioral and biological risk for cardiometabolic disease and mental health, the findings will provide important knowledge on the relationship between trauma and disease risk in AIs. The study will provide the basis for future longitudinal work to track the impact of trauma on long-term trajectories in cardiometabolic and mental health risk and will provide foundational knowledge that can be applied to future health interventions aimed at reducing AI health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human regulatory genome plays a crucial role in the coordination of gene expression in health and disease but remains poorly understood. This application proposes a general framework for elucidating the organizing principles of the regulatory genome through large-scale data integration, from a common coordinate system for regulatory elements to their universal annotation and in-depth characterization. This work will generate insights and testable hypotheses for the study of basic gene regulatory processes, interpretation of genetic variation and synthetic biology efforts, which are all key areas contributing to the understanding and treatment of human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROTACs, bifunctional small molecules that bind to a ubiquitin E3 ligase at one end and a target protein at the other, degrading the bound target protein, are a promising new drug class. We describe methods for rapid development of tau PROTACs drugs. We have proposed strategies to discover novel PROTACs that will remove pathogenic (monomeric) tau proteins as well as aggregates through autophagic mechanism. Development of the technology that degrades tau aggregates can be directly applied to Parkinsonâs disease, Huntingdon disease, and Amyotrophic Lateral Scleroses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Humans can show tremendous flexibility in every day life, rapidly recognizing and responding to contextual cues with appropriate behavioral changes, even in unfamiliar situations where the appropriate behaviors could not have been learned through direct experience. Here we examine the neural basis of this flexibility, with a particular focus on how arousal signals elicited by perceived context changes might coordinate neural representations in the brain to facilitate appropriate behaviors in changing and unfamiliar situations. This work will provide an understanding of how the brain generates flexible behavior, and why it does so differently in different individuals, thereby serving as a foothold for future work seeking to understand what goes wrong in conditions characterized by failure to cope with uncertain and changing environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, an estimated 1.4 million Americans suffer from Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD), a chronic debilitating disorder that includes Crohnâs disease and ulcerative colitis. IBD ranks in the top 5 in prevalence for gastrointestinal disorders and represents a significant financial burden to society requiring a lifetime of medical care as there is no cure for this disease. This proposed research aims to determine the genetic variations that cause IBD which will aid in developing preventive measures, improving the quality of care with better treatment plans and educating patients through genetic counseling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The goal of this project is to develop novel activity-targeted approaches to catapult the human gut microbiome field into an era of single cell ecophysiology investigations. Specifically, mucosal biopsy samples will be analyzed by a combination of substrate analog probing, stable isotope probing, Raman microspectroscopy, and correlative microscopy approaches, which together will reveal the identity, activity, and function of gut microorganisms at individual cell resolution under close-to in situ conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) remains a highly lethal malignancy and immune-based therapies have been largely unsuccessful to date. This proposal utilizes advances in single-cell transcriptomics and highly multiplexed imaging, paired with recently developed preclinical models of neoantigen-expressing pancreatic cancer and co-clinical profiling of patient samples, to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms of immune evasion in pancreatic cancer. I anticipate that this work will nominate additional targets for immune-based therapy in pancreatic cancer and other cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Zn2+ has emerged as an essential neuromodulator, and dysregulation of synaptic Zn2+ has been linked to numerous neurological disorders, such as stroke/ischemia, epilepsy, depression, Alzheimerâs disease, and hearing disorders. This project aims to develop new technology for imaging synaptic Zn2+ secretion in awake behaving animals and study the roles of Zn2+ in cortical sound processing. This project will pave the way toward elucidating connections between Zn2+ signaling, information processing, and neurological disorders.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Cerebral ischemia in the form of cardiopulmonary arrest remains one of the leading causes of death and disability in the USA. A major pathological consequence of cardiac arrest is cognitive deficits. This proposal examines the molecular mechanisms by which physical exercise and its potential downstream pathways can ameliorate cognitive deficits following cardiac arrest. The goal is to find novel therapeutic agents that act synergistically with physical exercise that may benefit patients that undergo acute myocardial infarction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE People with diabetes have a higher risk of developing heart disease, even when they take medications to control their blood sugar and cholesterol levels. A metabolite called alpha-aminoadipic acid is higher in people who experience higher disease risk. We will measure alpha-aminoadipic acid in blood to learn whether it predicts heart disease in people with diabetes, and whether it can be controlled using medication.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Young adults involved in the criminal justice system are at an increased risk of substance use disorders and HIV-acquisition. Given the disproportionate number of racial/ethnic minority young adults, criminal justice settings provide an opportunity to reduce racial/ethnic disparities in HIV and substance use treatment engagement by linking these young adults with innovative biomedical HIV prevention strategies (e.g., pre- exposure prophylaxis) and substance use treatment services. We propose to examine the feasibility, acceptability, and impact of an eHealth enhanced, adapted navigator program designed to refer and link justice involved young adults (18 to 29 years) to substance use treatment and HIV-prevention services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: 8. PROJECT NARRATIVE Because there are no clear biomarkers for a cure for HIV â unlike CD4+ count and viral load as markers of the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy â people living with HIV in research are asked to pause their treatment to test the efficacy of potential HIV cure strategies. Moving forward, research teams will need to ensure that participants remain adequately informed and accepting of the clinical and psychosocial risks of pausing their treatment as part of HIV cure trials. We plan to investigate the quality of informed consent of participants in these trials, capture the psychosocial experiences of participants in these trials, and build and refine ethical considerations to help accelerate and expand promising HIV cure discoveries to populations carrying the greatest burden of HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This single-arm interventional trial seeks to evaluate the preliminary efficacy of menstrual cups on non-optimal vaginal microbiome (VMB), BV, and STIs of economically vulnerable women at high risk for STIs and HIV, assess safety profile, and understand implementation needs. Assessing preliminary efficacy signal in conjunction with implementation characteristics and adverse events, will generate a comprehensive and necessary foundation for definitive assessment of effectiveness of menstrual cups as a multipurpose intervention for MHM, and to reduce BV and STIs. This proposal advances global health and womenâs reproductive health, as the knowledge gained will support future policy and guidelines on menstrual hygiene education and management, and integration with sexual and reproductive health care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Healthy and consistent physical activity (PA) is crucial for our health and well-being; however, its use as a treatment option for alcohol use disorders (AUDs) remains undervalued and understudied. Therefore, the goals of this application are to 1) determine whether acute or chronic voluntary physical activity reduce binge-like ethanol drinking in a genetic risk model of drinking to intoxication, 2) characterize the neural circuits engaged during acute and chronic voluntary wheel-running, and 3) use a circuit-based approach to test the role of a known alcohol-related projection in driving acute and chronic wheel-running. These studies have the potential to provide a better comprehension of the neural mechanisms responsible for regulating alcohol use through continued engagement in physical activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor plasticity plays a key role in the development of tumor heterogeneity and a tumorâs resistance to chemotherapy. We discovered a high plasticity cell state that appears to drive tumor evolution and therapy resistance in lung adenocarcinoma. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses the neglected issue of how interactions among distinct, co-circulating pathogensâthrough biological, behavioral, or clinical meansâaffect their joint dynamics. IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Photoreceptor cells in the retina are highly compartmentalized neurons, and disruption of compartment-specific protein localization underlies various forms of inherited retinal degenerations. The proposed study is to understand i) mechanisms by which the compartment-specific protein localization is achieved in photoreceptors and ii) why/how photoreceptor cells die when these mechanisms are impaired. This study will build a foundation to develop novel treatments to preserve vision in related diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hospital acquired bacterial and fungal infections are a major threat to critically ill patients. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart attack remains a leading cause of death due to late recognition of people at risk, but genomic information present from time of birth promises to improve risk prediction. The applicant will derive and a new risk model that integrates genomic information with known lifestyle and traditional risk factors to predict risk of heart attack in individuals of diverse ancestries. Successful completion will lay the foundation for genome-based identification and treatment of people at risk of heart attacks.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative There are currently no approved medications for psychostimulant abuse. Phoenix PharmaLabs has put together a program to develop a novel, non-selective opioid compound (PPL-138) that blocks cocaine and methamphetamine self-administration in rats but is not self-administered in rats or non-human primates. This program will encompass chemical manufacturing, required safety toxicology and all pre-IND studies, filing an IND, and Phase I clinical trials to determine safety in humans. The ultimate goal is to develop PPL-138 as a medication to treat cocaine and methamphetamine use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In motor neuron diseases, neuromuscular junctions are lost and motor neurons degenerate resulting in progressive paralysis and death. Dysfunctional microRNA (miRNA) processing has been implicated in their pathogenesis and I previously discovered that a single miRNA, miR-218, is uniquely enriched and abundantly expressed in mouse motor neurons and regulates neuromuscular function. I will utilize a novel human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived model of cortico-motor development to investigate the gene regulatory and biological functions of miR-218 in human motor neurons to gain insights into this essential miRNAâs role in human neurodevelopment and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Although social isolation, loneliness, and social environment are increasingly recognized as important factors in Alzheimerâs disease and related dementias (ADRD), less is known about the biological processes by which these factors impact brain health and ADRD. We plan to study these relatively novel associations in detail by adding social isolation, loneliness, and social environment information to ongoing ADRD surveillance in the biologically well-characterized Framingham Study cohorts, relating these measures to extensive preclinical ADRD data from dementia-free Framingham participants of diverse racial/ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds (neuropsychological and state-of-the-art omics and brain imagingâamyloid/tau-PET and volumetric/connectivity/perfusion-MRI), and using advanced computational analysis to characterize the cumulative biological role of these factors in ADRD. This would complement studies of the COVID-19 pandemicâs long-term population health impacts, help us better understand observed trends between psychosocial determinants of health and ADRD risk, clarify the magnitude of change needed in these factors for a meaningful improvement in health, advance health equity by supporting quantitative methods development to address root causes of disparities in ADRD, and, if validated, identify new treatment targets that may also strengthen individual and group psychosocial functioning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Interstitial lung disease affects approximately 40-60% of adults with systemic sclerosis and is the leading cause of death in this population. Our goal is to understand how vasculopathy contributes to the development of interstitial lung disease in adults with systemic sclerosis. Ultimately, the results of our study will be used to identify new treatments to prevent the development and progression of interstitial lung disease in patients with systemic sclerosis.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Iatrogenic withdrawal affects up to 57% of children who receive sedative and analgesic medications in the pediatric intensive care unit (ICU), contributing to delayed recovery, patient and parental distress and prolonged hospitalization. Due to limitations in sample size and variable sets, studies on iatrogenic withdrawal in pediatric ICUs have primarily focused on the association of single risk factors, screening tools, and treatment regimens, without attention to early identification of at-risk children. This proposal will leverage a national, electronic health record derived database of over 200,000 pediatric ICU patients to investigate the full spectrum of risk factors associated with iatrogenic withdrawal and using both traditional biostatistics and machine learning will develop and test a predictive model enabling early identification of pediatric ICU patients before iatrogenic withdrawal develops.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project helps to build the capacity of the future health science workforce of the United States by providing meaningful, project-based learning that targets science and engineering in elementary classrooms through augmented reality, an interactive digital media approach. Students solve problems and design solutions through a novel hybrid digital and hands-on platform with synchronous supports for students and powerful dashboards for educators built through this research and development. Cultivating intuition and collaboration skills into health science topics such as bioengineering through interactive, collaborative game-based activities that are feasible for delivery in diverse educational settings nurtures a healthy, robust and critical-thinking future society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Opioid addiction (OA) is a deadly public health burden in the United States and across the globe, and it continues to worsen, with more than 70,000 U.S. deaths in 2020âthe highest on record. In spite of 30 years of research, we still do not have a clear understanding of why some people are more likely to become addicted than others, although we do know that a personâs genes are strongly related. Our proposed Integrative Omics Center for Accelerating Neurobiological Understanding of Opioid Addiction (ICAN) will coordinate a team of top genomics researchers from multiple institutions to conduct four interlocking studies that will put tools in the hands of researchers countrywide to make field-changing breakthroughs, which ultimately, will improve options for treating opioid addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A persistent challenge to the design of effective influenza vaccines and forecasting of viral evolution and epidemiology is uncertainty about the immune responses underlying protection from infection. Here we propose to apply advanced statistical and computational methods and multimodal single cell analyses to identify the correlates and drivers underlying protection from infection and individual heterogeneity in vaccine responses. The work leverages a dozen longitudinal immuno-epidemiological studies of influenza virus infection and vaccination in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Most cells contain protective quality control mechanisms that recognize and eliminate unstable toxic proteins. We discovered a red blood cell protein quality control pathway that can be manipulated to alleviate Ã- thalassemia, a chronic life-threatening disorder of the blood oxygen carrier hemoglobin affecting approximately 60,000 newborns each year. Our proposed studies will provide scientific insights into how normal red blood cell precursors produce massive amounts of hemoglobin safely and efficiently and identify innovative new treatment strategies for patients with Ã-thalassemia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed expansion and improvement of IPUMS-USA and support of the IPUMS database are directly relevant to the central mission of the National Institutes of Health. IPUMS data are advancing fundamental knowledge about health and population dynamics, and they directly support a vast body of research in one of the key priorities of the Population Dynamics Branch (PDB) of NICHD: Health and Disease across the Lifespan. IPUMS is a key source for research in each of the three PDB program areas: demography (including fertility, mortality, migration, population distribution, nuptiality, and family demography), reproductive health (including the long-run impact of fertility limitation), and population health (including basic measurement of morbidity and mortality among population subgroups).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While it is now accepted that cell-to-cell variability affects viral infection outcome, we currently lack mechanistic understanding as to the host factors and transcriptional programs that control it. To gain such mechanistic insights requires the development of new approaches that are able to connect the cellâs initial state with infection outcome. This project will develop and apply state-of-the-art single cell approaches to decipher the molecular mechanisms that control viral infection outcomes at the single cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative We hypothesize that the enzyme xanthine oxidoreductase (XOR) and oxidative stress from XOR-derived reactive oxygen species influence development and progression of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) in systemic sclerosis (SSc). This project examines XOR enzymatic activity and oxidative stress as potential contributors to PAH in SSc, and investigates associations between XOR, altered downstream metabolic pathways, and disease phenotypes and outcomes. Identifying XOR and oxidative stress as drivers of PAH pathogenesis would support XOR as a novel potential therapeutic target, thereby enabling more precise treatment of SSc-PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE Currently available synthetic grafts are unable to mimic the characteristics of vascularized bone or readily induce biomineralization. The proposed work develops oxygen-generating protein-based hydrogels to create highly vascularized and mineralized 3D constructs. These novel hybrid biomaterials represent a first step towards creating functional vascularized bone in physiologically-relevant sizes, therefore, they will improve regeneration of mineralized craniofacial tissues and enhance human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This research proposal seeks to develop transition-metal-free technologies that enable the modification and synthesis of molecules of interest to human health. Given regulatory requirements around the use of metals in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, the development of metal-free strategies has the potential of significantly reduce drug-manufacturing costs and increase their safety. The primary impact of this proposal will be a greater understanding of these transformations and the development of new synthetic methods that greatly improve access to compounds that benefit society.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the tens of millions of patients who receive general anesthesia every year, it is still unclear why some patients experience peri-anesthetic complications while other patients that receive seemingly identical anesthetics have an uneventful perioperative course. In order to be able to tailor an anesthetic to the needs of an individual patient, we plan to investigate individualized measures of response to anesthetics, and the neural pathways that can affect those individual differences. We propose to investigate how the major adrenergic center of the brain, the locus coeruleus, changes one of those individualized measures, how stable a patient is in the awake or anesthetized state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative: Vascular senescence due to DNA damage is an emerging characteristic feature seen in atherosclerosis and other chronic disease states, an effect that may promote disease progression leading to heart attack, stroke, or peripheral vascular disease. We identified an endothelial-enriched microRNA (miRNA) that is dynamically expressed with atherosclerosis in young and old mice, and may act to control lesion formation within the vessel wall by controlling DNA damage and cell senescence. The proposed studies will provide a detailed understanding underlying the function of this miRNA, its target genes and interactomes, and how to restore its expression therapeutically with the goal of developing novel miRNA-based therapies for the treatment of vascular senescence and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Stroke is a number one cause of long-term disability in the United States, affecting approximately 6.6 million Americans, with a total projected cost of $2.2 trillion from 2005 to 2050. Following a stroke, more than two-thirds end up with a disability in the upper limb that lowers the ability to perform many daily activities, including self-care, vocations, and leisure, thus diminishing the quality of life. This project aims to evaluate a new technology in enhancing hand functional recovery following stroke, thereby improving independence and quality of life, with a cost-effective method.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Selective and rapid transport of K+ ions across the cell membrane is controlled by potassium channels â trans- membrane proteins whose disfunction is linked to cardiac arrhythmias, epilepsies, and other channelopathies. Multidimensional ultrafast vibrational spectroscopy is a powerful technique for studying structure and dynamics of proteins. The proposed research will provide novel machine-learning-based framework for simulating vibrational spectra of proteins which will help interpret and design vibrational spectroscopy experiments aiming at elucidating the molecular underpinnings of activation, conduction, and selectivity of ion channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Several fundamental insights on how synapses of auditory neurons operate in the developing and mature mammalian brainstem will be obtained from the proposed studies. This information sheds light on cellular mechanisms for binaural hearing including sound localization and enlightens current and future treatment strategies of hearing disorders. These studies will lead to an improved understanding of directional hearing in maturing animals and in future studies of how deficits in auditory brainstem synaptic transmission contribute to hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative While treatment effect heterogeneity is a concern in research of substance use disorder treatments, analysis of treatment effect heterogeneity has been often conducted in a suboptimal manner using subgroup analysis, which could result in finding spurious differences in treatment effects by subgroup due to the performance of multiple statistical tests and random variability across patients. Another challenge of subgroup analysis is that most covariates have small moderating effects and their individual contribution to treatment effect heterogeneity is not meaningfully informative to treatment decisions. This study will apply a novel statistical method, causal forest approach, to data from 12 randomized controlled trials of psychosocial treatments in the NIDA Clinical Trials Network to estimate the expected effect of a treatment for each individual while taking into account multiple covariates simultaneously and to identify the most important covariates contributing to treatment effect heterogeneity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Severe alveolar epithelial damage is often observed in several types of human lung disease, including influenza infection, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), and COVID-19, however little is known about interactions within the cellular niche that contribute to aberrant or constructive regeneration. The purpose of this project is to leverage a biomimetic engineered lung tissue model to investigate the role of macrophages in alveolar regeneration. Overall, the findings of this work will identify mechanisms of epithelial repair governed by alveolar macrophages and their activation state, thereby suggesting possible routes for pharmacologic intervention for fibrotic lung diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biomarkers in the blood can be used to detect signs of certain diseases to guide treatment strategies aimed at preventing them, and in the case of this application, rejection and kidney injury in liver transplant recipients. This project will test if the biomarkers we developed in a prior CTOT study can predict rejection and kidney injury and therefore help us use anti-rejection medications in a more successful way. This study will also provide a deeper understanding of the pathways that lead to rejection and kidney injury and improve our ability to avoid these complications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health because it would implement a novel proof-of-principle experimental strategy to ameliorate Huntingtonâs disease (HD) onset and progression: innovative developmental cell transplantation approaches employing the wild-type counterpart of affected cortical interneuron progenitor cells to promote restoration of impaired cortico-striatal functions rather than traditional regenerative approaches to replace defective cell types during the active phase of the disease. Accordingly, this research addresses a knowledge gap that is relevant to the goals of the overall NIH strategic mission, namely the absence of understanding of the requisite HD developmental targets and mechanisms amenable to disease-modifying interventions for neurodegenerative diseases. By targeting early cellular maturational impairments that promote late-onset disease, this approach will enhance the restoration of neural network functions during the critical period of developmental plasticity and the pre-manifest phase of illness prior to the onset of irrevocable disease dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to determine whether estradiol directly impacts astrocyte signaling in the nucleus accumbens. This would ultimately impact synaptic neurotransmission and motivated behaviors. Recent studies have determined sex and hormonal effects within the nucleus accumbens, and estrogen signaling in astrocytes may underlie many of these observations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE In light of the positive impact of workforce diversity on innovation in biomedical research and addressing public health, achieving a biomedical workforce that reflects the increasing diversity of the US population is essential to meet growing science and technology demands; however, individuals from underrepresented groups comprise a small percentage of the doctoral level biomedical workforce. Towards the goal of increasing workforce diversity, the Bridges to the Doctorate (B2D) partnership between Towson University (TU), the University of Maryland School of Medicine (UMSOM), and Johns Hopkins School of Medicine (JHUSOM) will create a supportive minority-focused training program in which students gain critical research and professional experience while completing their Masterâs degree at TU. The TU-UMSOM-JHUSOM B2D training program will prepare students for the successful transition from MS to PhD programs and completion of the doctorate at UMSOM, JHUSOM, and other institutions nationwide, thus increasing representation in the biomedical profession and enhancing diversity in this workforce.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease is a major concern in post-menopausal women, and particularly post-menopausal women with HIV. Our study focusing on menopause, sex hormones, and the gut microbiome has the potential to reveal novel mechanisms of cardiovascular risk in HIV-infected and uninfected women. This research can ultimately lead to new therapies targeting the gut microbiome, to lower CVD risk in post-menopausal women with or without HIV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will develop new novel gene transfer strategies into bone marrow cells for more effective treatment of hemophilia A by optimizing lentiviral constructs, delivering the constructs by intraosseous (IO) or intranasal (IN) delivery to transduce bone marrow cells targeting platelet-specific expression of factor VIII, and examining the therapeutic effect following gene transfer. We demonstrated previously that IO delivery of lentiviral vectors will transduce human bone marrow cells efficiently and in vivo hematopoietic stem cell gene therapy will provide long-term therapeutic benefit in hemophilia A mice. In the current study, we would like to enhance the safety and efficacy of this new novel strategy in hemophilia A mice and dogs with or without pre-existing inhibitors; these comprehensive studies will pave the way for the development of this novel technology for human applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: HENRY M. JACKSON FDN FOR THE ADV MIL/MED
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE High-energy tibial pilon fractures have historically been associated with poor outcomes largely due to the elevated risk of severe post-traumatic arthritis. Intraarticular fractures result in a pro-inflammatory hemarthrosis that may further exacerbate the chondral damage that was sustained due to the original injury. This project will study the effect of joint lavage on the concentration of inflammatory cytokines in the ankle following a high-energy tibial pilon fracture and the resultant effect on short-term patient outcomes.

PHR: Project Narrative Identification of the synaptic loci that control critical periods of enhanced plasticity is required to improve the success of treatments for amblyopia. Here we propose a series of experiment to test a provocative new model in which the initial response to monocular deprivation during the critical period is a rapid, transient and synapse-specific elimination of local L2/3 PyrÃ ï PV INs synaptic connections. We propose that this early elimination of local L2/3 PyrÃ ï PV INs excitatory synapses is obligatory for subsequent changes in ocular dominance and spatial acuity induced by monocular deprivation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Since 10.7% of all maternal deaths are due to postpartum hemorrhage, a personalized prediction tool is essential for clinicians. Despite initiatives aimed at improving pregnancy outcomes, the rates of postpartum hemorrhage are still rising in the United States and new strategies to predict and prevent this complication are urgently needed. We propose to utilize machine learning and genetic risk score approaches, which will allow for transparent, accurate and unbiased prediction that would lead to a greatly enhanced ability to identify high risk patients and dramatically improve maternal health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative: Embryonic stem cells (ESCs) form the basis for transformative cell therapies for retinal blindness, which affects over 300M worldwide. Yet the time-dependent mechanisms by which ubiquitous chromatin modifiers and embryonic transcription factors (TFs) interact to direct ESC retinogenesis remain unknown: the proposed research focuses on how the chromatin regulator WDR5 interacts with p53 and MAX, broadly expressed TFs, to control retinal development. Successful completion of the research will advance key concepts related to birth defects of the retina in p53-associated syndromes, current clinical trials that transplant p53 mutant ESC-derived retinal cells in individuals with macular degeneration, and potential off-target effects of WDR5 inhibitors, which are currently in therapeutic development through a $1 billion effort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The lateral hypothalamus (LHA) orchestrates fundamental behaviors such as arousal, stress and reward, and disruption of neural circuits in this region is associated with disorders of sleep, feeding and motivated behavior, which profoundly affect our physiological well-being and mental health. This proposal will use new and informative cellular and behavioral techniques to dissect the circuits and signaling pathways through which specific LHA neurons shape physiology and behavior. In so doing, we hope to identify targets for therapeutic intervention in treating and improving the quality of life of patients suffering from neuropsychiatric illnesses, addiction, post-traumatic stress disorder, sleep and metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Impaired regulation of blood flow is linked to primary open angle glaucoma, a major cause of blindness worldwide. The goal of this project is to directly measure blood flow in the smallest blood vessels of the eye to identify precise and robust biomarkers for detecting early disease. This would allow for earlier intervention to reverse vision loss, provide future direction for developing new treatments, and aid in monitoring progression of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: The base of the mammalian forebrain is studded with clusters of cholinergic neurons that regulate arousal, environmental awareness, and memory consolidation. Here, we focus on an overlooked cluster of these neurons â the tail of the basal forebrain - that have unusual response properties and may regulate our ability to perceive and learn from environmental sounds. Research on the function of basal forebrain tail neurons could identify new therapeutic avenues for the rehabilitation of sensory disorders and illuminate the connection between hearing abilities, dementia, and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NarrativeÂ  Â  TheÂ goalÂ ofÂ thisÂ WellstoneÂ MuscularÂ DystrophyÂ SpecializedÂ ResearchÂ CenterÂ isÂ toÂ identifyÂ emergingÂ therapeuticÂ  targetsÂ  andÂ  therapeutics,Â  asÂ  wellÂ  asÂ  toÂ  developÂ  imagingÂ  toolsÂ  toÂ  monitorÂ  theÂ efficacyÂ  ofÂ  therapies,Â  thatÂ  controlÂ  inflammation,Â fibrosis,Â andÂ diseaseÂ progressionÂ inÂ aÂ numberÂ ofÂ muscularÂ dystrophies.Â WeÂ alsoÂ areÂ focusedÂ onÂ  understandingÂ theÂ mechanismsÂ andÂ unwantedÂ sideÂ effectsÂ ofÂ currentÂ therapiesÂ (e.g.Â corticosteroids)Â inÂ orderÂ toÂ  improveÂ uponÂ theirÂ efficacyÂ andÂ use.Â WithÂ theÂ dawnÂ ofÂ geneÂ therapyÂ forÂ DuchenneÂ muscularÂ dystrophy,Â weÂ feelÂ  itÂ isÂ imperativeÂ toÂ understandÂ theÂ deficienciesÂ ofÂ theÂ emergingÂ treatmentsÂ inÂ orderÂ toÂ improveÂ uponÂ themÂ beforeÂ  theÂ deficienciesÂ becomeÂ evidentÂ inÂ patients.Â  Â

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: The study of animal viruses has been critical for understanding basic disease mechanisms, including the origin and pathogenesis of related human viruses. In this career development proposal, Dr. Jager will use a novel hepatotropic equine parvovirus to study the role of the DNA damage response pathways in viral genome replication and the impact of exogenous DNA damage on viral hepatitis. These findings will have broad implications on the fundamental mechanisms of viral DNA replication and the synergy between toxins and hepatotropic viruses in humans and animals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social connectedness is a promising pathway to slowing the progression of Alzheimerâs disease (AD). The current project will advance our understanding of why social connectedness confers resilience by leveraging existing infrastructure, a multi-method approach, and an interdisciplinary research team. By increasing our understanding of the links between biological and social processes, this project may help identify novel targets for intervention to reduce the burden of AD on individuals, families, and the health care system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The population of older adults in the United States is expanding as is the understanding of the basic biology that underlies the many clinical changes that happen to older people. The overall focus of this proposal is to support efforts to continue the successful âGeriatrics Research: Bench-to-Bedsideâ conference series, focusing on elucidating of phenomena of resilience with aging and its multi-component dimensions in response to physical, cognitive, and social stressors. This series encompasses sharing of knowledge, exchanging new ideas,education, mentorship and exploring recent developments as well as defining knowledge gaps and priority future research directions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Poor recovery from orthopaedic injury, including severe pain and impaired bone healing, affects millions of Americans. Myeloid-lineage cells (peripheral macrophages and spinal cord microglia) are mobilized to resolve tissue damage, however, persistent activation of these cells can be detrimental by contributing to pain and delayed healing. This work aims to develop approaches to monitor dysfunctional myeloid-lineage cells and modulate specific targets for novel therapeutics that will improve post-injury recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Adolescent depression and cannabis use are concurrent major public health concerns, and both have been associated with long-term alterations in brain function and behavior. This research training fellowship utilizes non-invasive neuroimaging approaches to examine reward function in the co-occurrence of depression and cannabis use in adolescence, a critical and vulnerable period of brain development. By seeking to understand brain processes underlying these comorbid conditions early in life, this project has the potential to inform future preventive, diagnostic, and therapeutic strategies that may be employed in the care of this high-risk population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Airway protective disorders are a prevalent and progressive consequence of Parkinsonâs Disease (PD), and often result in aspiration pneumonia which is the leading cause of death in PD. Despite this, a large number of patients with PD do not access specialized services to address these critical deficits. We will examine the comparative effectiveness of a novel treatment paradigm delivered in-person versus via telehealth in persons with PD, as well as the role of patient burden and treatment adherence on outcomes; thus, the proposed research is relevant to public health and in line with NIHâs mission to identify novel, efficacious, and accessible rehabilitation strategies for short- and long-term improvement of dysfunctional airway protection in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Persistent Type I IFN signaling is a major driver for chronic inflammation and immune dysfunction during HIV infection. Major components of the cannabis (THC and CBD) may have anti-inflammatory properties but the individual effects and mechanisms of THC and CBD immune regulation remain unknown. In this project, we aim to elucidate the effects and mechanisms of THC and CBD on HIV associated immune cell activation/dysfunction and CNS inflammation, particularly type I IFN mediated inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The concise and efficient synthesis of complex molecules and their selective functionalization are exceptionally challenging aspects of therapeutic development. This five-year research program is to develop novel single-electron oxidation chemistry of aromatic N-oxides via the enabling technology of photoredox catalysis for 1) the innovation of new vinyl radical synthetic methods via hitherto inaccessible chemical reactivity for the synthesis of molecular complexity and efficient preparation of functional motifs commonly encountered in biologically active compounds; 2) the development of a new and readily tunable platform for site- and stereo-selective functionalization of unactivated C(sp3)âH bonds by catalyst control to enable the selective conversion of abundant petrochemical stocks into high-value chemicals and selective functionalization of complex molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Statins are the cornerstone in the treatment of coronary heart disease. However, the use of statins has been limited by myopathic side effects. In this proposal, I will employ patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cell- derived skeletal muscle platforms combined with genome-scale CRISPR interference technology. By doing such, the goal will be to discover the genetic determinants of statin induced myopathy and the molecular mechanisms underlying patient-specific differential susceptibilities to statin toxicity. This knowledge should be of significant value to improve prediction of at-risk subjects, optimize statin therapeutic benefit, and identify novel SIM therapeutic targets making precision medicine possible.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to discover the neural substrates that link perception and assessment of environment to metabolic and reproductive output. I will leverage the accessibility of the nervous system in Drosophila melanogaster to isolate neurons and signaling molecules that control fly reproduction and metabolism, which may uncover new circuitry linking brain and metabolic state. This work offers the prospect of discovery of pathways which may underly idiopathic metabolic disorders in humans and offer broad biological insights into how animals coordinate metabolism with environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section (The narrative contained no specific references to the in vivo mouse experiments and therefore is unchanged): Many proteins are modified by the addition of sugars, or glycosylation, which can alter their function. This proposal is aimed at understanding a specific type of glycosylation, termed O-GlcNAc, that plays important roles in protein aggregation. This work will uncover the specific role of O-GlcNAc on critical proteins in neurodegenerative diseases, a key prerequisite to the potential targeting O-GlcNAc as a therapeutic strategy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a novel structurally, compositionally biomimetic bone scaffolding system that possesses osteoconductive and osteoinductive characteristics for orofacial cleft reconstruction. We will utilize 3D bioprinting strategies to develop personalized bone scaffolds for long-term use that will adapt to the needs of growing children. This proposed study will explore the potential of clinically applicable 3D bioprinting workflow using clinically relevant surgical animal models and utilize NIR fluorescent imaging technique as noninvasive real-time monitoring to determine the new bone formation along with implanted scaffold degradation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our basic science research on dormancy will advance the NIH's mission of improving human health by finding methods of killing dormant fungal spores, many of which are infectious and cannot be readily killed by the existing antimicrobial drugs for reasons that are not well understood. The dormant spores of the baker's yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae, is a safe and an ideal model system because many of the basic biology of the baker's yeast also apply to infectious fungi such as those whose spores cause meningitis and histoplasmosis in humans. By revealing how dormant yeast spores age and the connections between gene expression and aging in dormancy, we expect to identify mechanisms that new drugs can disrupt to kill infectious fungal spores.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sarcoidosis is an understudied disease with significant morbidity and mortality that is a major health burden in the United States. This proposal will determine rates of medication adherence, evaluate the association between adherence and clinical outcomes in sarcoidosis, and identify which determinants are associated with medication adherence in individuals with sarcoidosis. It will also identify barriers and facilitators of adherence to inform the development of a behavioral intervention that targets knowledge gaps, improves coping, and addresses barriers to adherence in sarcoidosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative This study is designed to investigate the effects of structural inventions, such as equity-focused Medicaid polices, on severe maternal morbidity and mortality and maternal health. The proposed study will 1) estimate the effect of Medicaid healthcare quality interventions on SMM, 2) estimate the effect of Medicaid healthcare quality interventions + doula care, 3) Assess Medicaid beneficiariesâ experiences in receiving services and the potential impact of integration of doula services and equity practices. The long-term objective is to inform state and federal health policymakers considering structural policy interventions within Medicaid as a vehicle for addressing racial equity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: About 10 million humans infected with the pathogen Schistosoma mansoni develop pulmonary arterial hypertension (Sch-PAH), which is characterized by obliteration and remodeling of pulmonary vasculature in response to pathogen eggs. Currently there are no targeted therapies for treatment of Sch-PAH. Thus, the overall goal of this proposal is to determine the mechanism that promotes generation of a vascular inflammatory endothelial memory and uncover novel pharmacological targets to prevent irreversible vascular remodeling during Sch-PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Public Relevance Statement There is an urgent need for innovative approaches that support the use of Preexposure Prophylaxis (PrEP), a daily pill preventing HIV that is empowering and user-controlled. Using a participatory implementation science framework, I will test whether an adapted and community empowered group healthcare model, Centering PrEP+, is a feasible and acceptable health system intervention to improve the health of sex workers and their clients by increasing PrEP adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With current high-dose/intensity surgery/chemo-radiation therapy, the 5-year event-free survival for children and adolescents/young adults with advanced, relapsed, or metastatic solid tumors is less than 30%, with little improvement in outcome for over 30 years. In addition, for those patients that survive their cancer, life-long and life-threatening sequelae from therapy may afflict up to half. This competing U01 Ped-In Vivo-TP application aims at identifying and developing novel, effective, targeted, and nano-formulated agents in omically characterized patient derived xenograft models representing high-risk sarcoma, kidney cancers, and hepatoblastoma. The program will facilitate pediatric drug development as directed by FDA under the Research to Accelerate Cures and Equity for Children Act (RACE for Children Act).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Pesticides, fungicides and insecticides are established risk-factors for neuronal injury and neurodegenerative onset. Here, we develop and test whether Carbon Quantum Dots (CQDs), which are nano materials synthesized from bio-waste precursors such as fruit peel, lignin, used frying oil and recycled paper, can restore cellular and organismal-level deficits induced by pesticide exposure. The proposed work is important because, if successful, it defines novel candidates that mitigate pesticide-associated neurodegenerative disorders.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative: TPI Df is an untreatable metabolic disease. Although disease pathogenesis is known to result from inappropriate targeting of functional mutant protein for degradation, drug therapies do not exist for this disease. We have developed an optical cellular assay for compounds that stabilize mutant TPI, and will use the platform to screen a diversity compound library and identify starting points for development into the first in class TPI Df small molecule therapies. We will prioritize molecules using toxicology and metabolism assays, and validate the most promising compounds in TPI Df patient cells and in vivo using established Drosophila and mouse models. Overall, this project will discover initial therapies for development and test efficacy of our lead compounds in TPI Df models, including a newly validated mouse model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative One in 1000 people with epilepsy die every year due to Sudden Unexpected Death in Epilepsy (SUDEP). Identifying risk factors associated with SUDEP remains challenging due to the lack of large controlled datasets enabling rigorous analyses and development of comprehensive prediction models. Our study will address this critical unmet need by screening records of >40,000 patients from >85 epilepsy centers worldwide to obtain a nearly order of magnitude more cases and controls than any prior study, and applying innovative methods to test candidate biomarkers, leading to better understanding of SUDEP mechanisms and developing individualized risk models to better target patients for counseling and interventions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Individual and household debt has played an increasingly important role in the dynamics of economic inequality and insecurity in the United States in recent decades. However, limitations of current data impede scientific understanding of the role of indebtedness in reducing or exacerbating economic insecurity for low-income families. This project consists of a multi-pronged data collection and analysis effort aimed at building a stronger data infrastructure, more adequate and accurate measures of indebtedness, and best practices for analyzing various forms of indebtedness and their relation to economic hardship and financial strain for low-income families.
