IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The popularity of e-cigarettes and other electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS), especially among youth, is compelling policymakers to reengineer tobacco control policy and is reigniting the debate on whether to accept ENDS for tobacco harm reduction or to apply the precautionary principle to ENDS. The level of reduction in population level harms conferred by ENDS may depend on the policy context, and likewise, the presence of ENDS in the marketplace may alter the impact of tobacco control policies on population level harm. This study will develop the first state-level microsimulation model to estimate the health and economic impact of intensive tobacco control policies, under scenarios with and without ENDS in the marketplace, in order to: 1) estimate the magnitude of the effect that ENDS presence has on a policyâs effect in reducing population harms of tobacco and 2) estimate the variation in population level harms attributable to ENDS over alternative policy contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Identifying risk factors for persistent pain and disability in the context of acute musculoskeletal pain is key to preventing the development of chronic musculoskeletal pain in adolescence. Understanding neurobiological features and circuits that are underlying the risk for transition to chronic pain is particularly important in this developmental period, when brains are still developing and may be more amenable to intervention. The long- term goal of this research program is to identify risk and protective factors that contribute to chronic musculoskeletal pain, which will directly inform the development of preventative interventions for youth at increased risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT BUFFALO
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Culture-independent sequencing has revealed that strict and facultative anaerobic bacteria are both prevalent and abundant in in the CF airways, but their mechanistic contribution(s) to disease pathophysiology and long-term clinical outcomes are poorly understood. The focus of this project is to define how individual anaerobes interact with one another, the host, and traditional CF pathogens and to test our hypothesis that anaerobic microbiota set the stage for consequent disease trajectories. By understanding how anaerobes contribute to the development of early CF airway environment, we can identify new therapeutic strategies for more effective disease management and improved long-term patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Network for Excellence in Neuroscience Clinical Trials (NeuroNEXT) aims to improve the efficiency and quality of clinical trials in order to enhance the translation of neuroscience discoveries into effective treatments for patients. The Utah regional site (UR-NEXT) provides access to NeuroNEXT trials to the diverse and rural population of the 5-state Intermountain West region. UR-NEXT strengthens NeuroNEXT network by providing leadership and clinical trial expertise in rare neurological disorders and genetic therapies for both pediatric and adult disease as well as a broad spectrum of collaborative programs and centers that can support the larger network. A training component provides structured mentorship and skill development to early stage clinical investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. Patients with Alzheimerâs disease go through years of predementia disease stages when many biological processes in the brain become progressively dysregulated. It is critical to understand this complex pathophysiology that culminates in malfunction of Î²-amyloid and tau proteins that are believed to cause neurodegeneration and cognitive decline. Interestingly, these proteins normally participate in the function of the brain, and hence, we aim to study if specific disruptions in the natural patterns of neural cells performance and in the vascular maintenance for their activity may be the pathology that predisposes to mishandling of proteins in the cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Tumor heterogeneity and limited chemotherapeutic efficacy in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma underscores the need to find new targets and molecular interactions for PDAC diagnosis and therapy. In this proposal, we will determine the molecular interaction between a DNA repair protein, BARD1 and a cell cycle regulator, PLK- 1 using biochemical assays and determine if this interaction plays a role in regulating therapeutic efficacy of PARP inhibitors and platinums. Completion of this project would advance our understanding of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and provide new possibilities for targeted therapeutic interventions.

PHR: Alzheimerâs Disease is a significant threat to public health as it is the only one of the top 10 causes of death in the United States that cannot be effectively prevented, treated, or cured. This proposal aims to determine if infections due to fungi and bacteria can be implicated as causes of Alzheimerâs Disease and involves creating a mouse model of gut yeast infection that then spreads to the brain to cause Alzheimerâs-like disease. Success with creating this new model will allow us to further understand how Alzheimerâs Disease progresses and how to diagnose and treat this devastating illness.

PHR: This project investigates how human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) cloaks itself in a âsugar shieldâ to escape from antibodies and other immune defenses. HCMV causes life-threatening opportunistic infections in immune compromised people and is the #1 viral cause of birth defects that lead to permanent hearing loss and other neurodevelopmental disabilities in young children. ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: NARRATIVE When cells mature or respond to changes in their environment, they turn on some genes, turn off others, and destroy gene products that are no longer needed. When this process goes awry, cancer and other diseases can occur. This proposal focuses on identifying how cells destroy two classes of gene productsâmicroRNAs and circular RNAsâthat are important for controlling the expression of other genes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This early career development grant includes training in alcohol use disorder recovery research, advanced quantitative methods, and professional development by a strong mentoring team to help the principal investigator transition to an independent investigator in the alcohol field. Training and research activities are carefully sequenced to maximize knowledge gains.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity is paradoxically associated with improved survival during sepsis and other critical illnesses; however, the mechanistic basis for this protection is not understood. The obtained data will allow for future mechanistic studies to further understand the processes at play.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Previous studies of eosinophils, which are white blood cells that contribute to the regulation of immunity, have historically focused on allergic responses and parasitic helminth infections, and are found to be associated with type II inflammatory settings. However, our understanding of the role of eosinophils in persistent bacterial infections is incomplete. In this application, we will elucidate mechanisms of eosinophil control of persisting Salmonella within systemic granulomas, which will provide new insights into how to treat and irradicate chronic intracellular bacterial infections.

PHR: The goal of these studies is to understand how nerves in the nasal epithelium may detect fungal allergens and interact with other cells to initiate allergic inflammation. We think that nerves become activated by fungal allergens and secrete specific proteins that cause specialized cells in the epithelium to proliferate and initiate the early stages of inflammation. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The schizophrenia-associated copy number variants 3q29 deletion and 22q11.2 deletion produce strikingly similar clinical phenotypes, but it is not known whether these high-risk alleles have convergent effects at cellular and molecular levels. Our studies strongly indicate that 3q29 deletion produces mitochondrial phenotypes in the central nervous system, which aligns with previous reports of mitochondrial phenotypes in 22q11.2 deletion. This career development project is aimed at understanding the extent of these phenotypes in genetically controlled human iPSC and mouse experimental model systems, with the goal of testing the hypothesis of phenotypic convergence at mitochondria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Falls are a leading cause of injury and death and every year, nearly 25-50% of older adults fall. The vestibular system, part of the inner ear, is a known contributor to fall risk; however, recent evidence suggests that cognition and vestibular function may interact to contribute to falls as almost 2 out of 3 patients with Alzheimerâs disease (AD) fall and those with vestibular function exhibit changes in cognition. In this study, we will investigate multiple domains of vestibular function, cognition, and sensorimotor behaviors in patients with AD and vestibular loss to further understanding of mechanisms contributing to falls.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is incomplete penetration of proven-effective, evidence-based practices for the nearly 1 million Americans experiencing acute respiratory failure (ARF) every year. Empirical evidence to guide selection of implementation strategies with the greatest potential impact in critical care settings is urgently needed. This study will demonstrate how established multilevel modeling techniques can be used in innovative ways to analyze existing multicenter datasets to inform selection of implementation strategies for patients with ARF and evaluate their effectiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Since the start of the pandemic, patients, including very sick heart failure patients, are having to remain in the Emergency Department for hours or even days longer than necessary because there are no beds available in the wards where they need transfer for specialized treatment. Emergency physicians need new tools that help them keep up with these ever increasing demands on their time and attention. The novel tools proposed in this grant could help Emergency Department physicians rapidly re-examine heart failure patients every few hours, assess improvements in their lungs, and adjust their treatment as needed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brucellosis is one of the worldâs leading zoonotic diseases, and Brucella abortus, B. melitensis and B. suis strains are of additional public health concern based on their potential use as agents of biowarfare or bioterrorism. Completing the objectives of the proposed research will improve our understanding of how Brucella strains produce disease in their mammalian hosts. Such knowledge can be used for the development of improved strategies to prevent and treat brucellosis in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite an increasing number of therapeutic options for psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a chronic progressive inflammatory disease of the skin and musculoskeletal system affecting over half a million Americans, less than a third of patients respond to therapy. This is, in part, because PsA is studied and managed as if it were a single disease. In this proposal, we will use two unique real-world PsA cohorts to better understand clinical and genetic heterogeneity in PsA and to identify those who are more likely or less likely to respond to therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As one of the most prevalent behavioral voice disorders, phonotrauma (e.g., vocal fold nodules, polyps, etc.) can have devastating impacts on an individualâs ability to function in their daily life, but it continues to be unclear what factors cause and/or perpetuate these disorders. Thus, it is vital to determine factors related to the development and recovery of phonotrauma in order to prevent and adequately treat these disorders. The goal of this research is to longitudinally assess the role that psychosocial and behavioral factors play in the development and persistence of phonotrauma in a group of high-risk individuals with the long-term objectives of improving early identification of individuals at risk for phonotrauma and reforming treatment paradigms to improve outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Glioblastoma is a uniformly fatal disease afflicting over 12,000 new patients yearly with a poor prognosis despite maximal safe resection and chemoradiation. To improve outcomes, we are conducting a clinical trial using a virus to deliver gene therapy to gliomas and make them sensitive to chemotherapy. We are trying to use a novel biomarker to identify patients who would maximally benefit from this treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE: Lung infections affect billions of individuals and cause significant morbidity and mortality. Although lung macrophages are known to be necessary to clear infectious pathogens, our understanding of the mechanisms that regulate macrophage responses and how the activity of these cells influence subsequent infections remains poorly understood. This proposal will interrogate how infection history alters outcomes from heterologous infections via trained immunity of macrophage subsets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Building on the laboratoryâs longstanding interest in cancer metabolism, this project will examine the central role that mitochondria play in the regulation of nitrogen metabolism during cancer cell growth. The ability of mitochondria to generate a pool of glutamate from either glutamine or ammonia and utilize that glutamate for amino acid, glutathione, and polyamine biosynthesis will be analyzed. The insights gained will help shape new diagnostic and therapeutic strategies that exploit oncogene- and tumor suppressor-induced changes in tumor metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic testing is increasingly used in ill neonates and holds promise to improve care, but the uncertainty of many genetic results complicates their application to clinical practice and poses an important hazard. Uncertainty can lead both clinicians and parents to misunderstand or misapply findings, resulting in biased treatment plans. The proposed research is designed to identify the potential risks that emerge as neonatologists and parents interpret and apply uncertain genetic results, and to mediate these risks by developing a tool to improve the management and communication of results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inflammation is controlled by a cascade of signaling events which are initiated by the secretion of lipid mediators by leukocytes to recruit and activate additional immune cells to sites of infection. Our goal is to define how Y. pestis dysregulation of host lipid mediator synthesis contributes to the establishment of plague. Because the inhibition of inflammation is key to Y. pestis virulence, defining the role of host lipid mediators during plague is essential for us to understand the pathogenesis of this bacterium and provide new insights to improve current plague therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will test the hypothesis that a change in how attention is allocated forms the basis of sensory and perceptual processing differences in autism spectrum disorder (ASD). IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Interactions between pancreatic cancer cells and non-transformed cells in a tumor are essential for cancer growth and progression. Reprogramming these metabolic networks is a promising strategy for enhancing therapeutic efficacy in pancreatic cancer. I will use new mouse models and cutting-edge metabolomic techniques to determine how immune and nerve cells support pancreatic cancer growth through metabolic interactions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advanced aging is the most common factor associated with a diagnosis of adult glioblastoma (GBM) with wild- type isocitrate dehydrogenase; constituting 90% of all GBM diagnoses and made famous for its association with taking the lives of notable individuals including the late U.S. Senators Ted Kennedy and John McCain. Advanced aging is also associated with increased brain-resident dendritic cells (DCs), sentinel cells of the immune system, as well as a potently immunosuppressive factor, indoleamine 2,3 dioxygenase 1 (IDO1). Here, I will investigate the novel hypothesis that, advanced aging increases brain DCs expressing immunosuppressive IDO1, which enhances the incidence and decreases the responsiveness to immunotherapy of subjects with GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Treatment strategies for Alzheimerâs disease (AD) have been largely ineffective resulting in an increased focus on identifying effective prevention strategies. The goal of this project is to longitudinally investigate changes in 24-hour activity (sleep, physical activity, and sedentary time) with changes in cognition, structural neuroimaging, and fluid biomarkers of AD and concomitant injury prior to the onset of clinical dementia. This work will advance our understanding of how 24-hour activity behaviors contribute to AD, making a significant contribution to the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE I propose the development of a nanoparticle therapy-eluting gel that overcomes two critical challenges in myocardial drug delivery: (1) rapid diffusion away from the infarct zone due to the mechanically active heart and (2) delivery of a sustained therapeutic dosage that maintains its bioactivity. For this work, I propose the delivery of two emerging therapeutics, Anakinra, and Fresolimumab, as these two agents have been shown in clinical studies to prevent adverse remodeling of the infarct zone and would greatly benefit from controlled local delivery to avoid toxicity and off-target effects. The proposed platform is modular and can be easily tuned to deliver a range of therapeutics, allowing us to quickly adapt to new pharmacology advances and therapeutic approaches as they are developed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Evidence suggests that vaccination with standard and high-dose influenza vaccines are not effective or minimally effective in preventing influenza-related outcomes in dialysis patients. Using national healthcare data on patients with end-stage renal disease undergoing dialysis in the United States, we will evaluate the utilization, effectiveness, and safety of newly licensed adjuvanted and recombinant influenza vaccines in the dialysis population. Our findings will inform dialysis patients and their providers about the risks and benefits of different vaccines and influence vaccine policy, with the ultimate goal of reducing the burden of respiratory disease in this vulnerable population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Th17 cells are critical for maintaining gut homeostasis, but are also implicated in certain types of autoimmunity and inflammation. This proposalâs objective is to understand the cellular metabolic pathways in Th17 cells and how changes in mitochondria, the so-called powerhouse of the cell, impact Th17 cell function, as well as function in other T cell subsets. Defining the mechanisms that regulate T cell metabolism will be critical for gaining new insights into how to therapeutically target these cells in the context of autoimmune disease, infection, and cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescent social isolation stress coupled with alcohol drinking is a major public health problem that has been exacerbated by the current COVID-19 pandemic and can lead to lasting disruptions of brain functions. The proposed longitudinal experiments will characterize the synergistic and individual consequences of social isolation stress and alcohol exposure across the lifespan. By elucidating the endocannabinoid-related mechanisms underlying the long-term impact of social isolation stress and alcohol on adolescent and adult brain, these studies will also identify and validate potential therapeutic targets and drug candidates that can reverse and/or prevent stress and alcoholâs developmental effects on synaptic functions and behavior.

ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection causes fulminant hepatitis with high maternal and fetal mortality in pregnant women but the underlying mechanism is unknown. We will establish an in vitro placental barrier culture model that mimics the critical maternal blood- and fetal blood-facing layers in vivo to delineate the mechanisms of HEV-associated severe diseases during pregnancy. The information gained from this small R03 project will have important implications for devising effective strategies for the prevention and treatment of HEV-associated high mortality in pregnant women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Obesity and obesity-related metabolic diseases are a growing public health concern in the United States and around the world. The pathogenesis of these diseases is driven by excess nutrient intake, and thus, identifying and characterizing metabolic pathways that can be targeted therapeutically to increase energy expenditure and dispose of excess nutrients serves an important clinical need. Focusing on lactate metabolism, my studies will improve our understanding of fuel use and metabolic flux during brown adipose tissue thermogenesis and inform future efforts targeting thermogenic adipose tissue for the treatment of obesity and obesity-related disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies address the important research area of Alzheimerâs disease (AD) that is the most common form of age-associated dementia and neurodegenerative disorder, and becomes a major public health predicament. The proposed research has relevance to public health, because it seeks to dissect role of senescent T cells in the pathogenesis of AD and then to develop novel strategies to block T cell senescence for AD prevention and immunotherapy. Thus, the findings are ultimately expected to improve treatment of human AD and other neurodegenerative disorders as well.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Sex, Hormones and Identity affect Nociceptive Expression (SHINE) Project Narrative Sex differences in pain mechanisms and prevalence have been reported and studied to broaden our understanding of pain, but it is possible that gender identity plays a more significant role than sex assigned at birth or hormone level. Here we will collect a number of quality of life measures, measure pain sensitivity and examine immune cell populations in cisgender and transgender men and women (with/without current hormone treatment) to determine the impact of gender identity, sex assigned at birth and hormone level. The proposed study will significantly contribute to our understanding of the impact of various social and biological factors to pain expression and provide critical information with respect to the needs of this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative: The goal of this project is to increase our structural understanding of the peripheral membrane protein Kindlin-2 and the lipid membranes to which it binds. The details of how lipids in the phosphatidylinositol phosphate family control the activity of protein binding partners, like Kindlin-2, are a major unanswered question. Solid-state NMR is a unique tool for the atomic resolution characterization of the structure and dynamics of lipids, and I plan to develop NMR experiments for directly investigating Kindlin-2-lipid interfaces with high sensitivity and specificity.

PHR: As recruitment into clinical research has been a longstanding challenge for NIH funded multi- site studies, we will Catalyze and Harmonize Operational Innovation for Recruitment (CHOIR) which will be led by a long-standing synergistic partnership between Paul Harris, PhD, as PI responsible for informatics development, and Consuelo Wilkins, MD, MSCI, as PI of community and stakeholder engagement. Formal partnerships with 10 other CTSAs provide broad understanding of Hub needs, along with key areas of expertise. We will provide a national, disease agnostic home for sharing recruitment tools, training, materials, and best practices for diverse populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Herpes simplex viruses persists for life in neurons as a latent infection and can reactivate to cause disease. The aims of this study are to understand how gene silencing occurs in neurons to impact viral gene expression and the ability of the virus to reactivate. The long-term goals are to understand how to target the latent stage of HSV infection and develop therapeutics that prevent reactivation occurring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: Project Narrative New American Youth on the Rise (NAYR) is a pathway program for middle and high school girls from Chittenden County Vermont immigrant communities designed to prepare students for successful transitions into college careers in health sciences. The overarching mission of NAYR is to enhance health equity for Chittenden County, Vermont immigrant communities by 1) increasing representation in the healthcare workforce that reflects their racial/ethnic backgrounds and lived experiences, and 2) increasing collaboration and trust between the academic health center and the local community by demonstrating clear investment in the local community. With a three pronged approach focusing not only on the student, but also the family and the teachers and school counselors, NAYR âcocoonsâ the student with mentoring activities, courses for skills development, research experience, and outreach necessary to facilitate a smooth transition into the health sciences at the college level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Accumulating evidence suggests the relationship between tuberculosis (TB) and non-communicable diseases is bidirectional, with TB disease increasing the risk of stress hyperglycemia as well as long-term adverse metabolic outcomes such as diabetes. Key knowledge gaps exist about the host responses to TB that drive cardiometabolic disease risk, limiting our ability to develop therapies and interventions to reduce non-communicable disease incidence after TB. This research project will use combined high-resolution metabolomics, high-density cytokine profiling, and measurement of lipopolysaccharide and microbial sequences in plasma of patients with TB disease across glycemic trajectories to determine (1) immunometabolic responses associated with stress hyperglycemia at TB disease diagnosis, (2) whether immunometabolic abnormalities persist after TB treatment, and (3) whether differences in the immune-microbiota interface are associated with short and long-term metabolic sequelae of TB disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Public narrative Obesity disproportionally affects racial/ethnic minorities as consequences of complicated interactions between individual behaviors (e.g., physical activities, healthy food choices) and socioeconomic and environmental context (income, public infrastructure, neighborhood green lands). However, there is no accurate measurement to assess and explore the mechanisms of obesity disparities through the utilization of infrastructures related to physical activity, healthy and unhealthy food uptake. We propose to develop and test a novel measurement tool, visitation-based obesogenic environment measurement (VOEM), as a proxy assessment of three different dimensions of obesogenic-related behaviors: physical activity, healthy food choices, and less healthy food choices at multiple geographic levels using cellphone-based place visitation data for the US.

Hit compounds will be tested for efficacy in a murine non-invasive knee injury model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Impulsivity occurs when one's choices are over-influenced by immediate consequences (e.g., getting high) and under-influenced by future consequences (loss of health, wealth, and relationships). The proposed research will build on our successful experiments which illustrate a practical, low-effort method for reducing impulsivity, which is of substantial relevance to the public-health goals of the National Institute on Drug Abuse (Volkow & Baler, 2015). The findings will provide a roadmap for efficient and effective prevention research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative While maternal substance use (SU) rates in the U.S. have quadrupled in the past decade, with significant public health consequences, mothers with substance use disorders (SUDs) remain an understudied and underserved population; for Black mothers in the U.S., the lack of research on risks, protective factors, and effective treatment elements is even more pronounced. The objectives of the proposed study are to: 1) identify the contributions of specific risk factors, including experiences of racism-related trauma, to SUD outcomes in a sample of Black mothers seeking SUD treatment; and 2) to explore whether maternal mentalizing, an established maternal SUD protective factor and buffer against the effects of trauma, may serve as a potential protective factor in this sample. Knowledge gained from the study will help clinical researchers to develop culturally responsive, evidence-based assessment tools and intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE FOXP1 is an understudied rare disease gene that is associated with a complex neurodevelopmental disorder. Cerebellar hypoplasia is a prominent feature of FOXP1 syndrome, but the cellular and molecular mechanisms driving this anomaly are unknown. We will establish the cellular and molecular distribution of FOXP1 expression in the developing cerebellum as a foundation for investigating pathological development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Eye pressure and its effect on the eye wall are among the most important factors that cause vision loss and ultimately blindness due to glaucoma. The goal of this project is to use a new technology to determine the effect of eye pressure on the eye wall and to develop sensitive new biomarkers to detect and guide treatment for glaucoma. This would allow for earlier intervention to prevent vision loss, provide future direction for developing new treatments, and aid in monitoring progression of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE Contamination and fouling of surfaces by bacteria are critical problems in many healthcare settings and can lead to serious and substantial burdens that are costly in economic and human terms. Many materials have been designed to resist bacterial fouling, but these strategies ultimately fail when deployed in real-world scenarios. Fundamentally new approaches to the design of robust antifouling coatings that move beyond conventional materials design strategies are urgently needed and would have major and lasting impacts on human health.

PHR: Project Narrative Pre-existing immunity to one mosquito-borne flavivirus can affect the outcome of infection with other flavivirus- es in complex ways. PHR: Inclusive PreK STEM Playgroups: Empowering our Youngest Learners and their  Caregivers for Confidence and Competence in STEM Learning  Project Narrative The proposed R25 Science Education Partnership Award (SEPA) is a partnership between a research institution and an informal learning space to conduct STEM focused inclusive playgroups with a goal of empowering caregivers of young children to implement high quality learning activities within their daily routines and activities. The project will examine preliminary efficacy as well as caregiver perceived changes in confidence and competence related to embedding STEM learning opportunities. Findings may be used to inform a model for inclusive STEM playgroups in informal learning spaces that has potential to be widely adopted and increase access to STEM learning, contributing to closing STEM opportunity gaps.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the feasibility of implementing an algorithm so that each participant in a weight loss program will receive a different sequence of financial incentives for weekly weight loss and calorie logging. In a future trial, the personalized intervention will be compared to a uniform intervention in which everyone receives the same incentive amount and timing. The personalized intervention could maximize return on investment for payers by distributing a preset budget across a population to maximize long-term, population-level weight loss in real-world settings.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Though military-connected mothers experience high rates of trauma exposure and resulting mental health and parenting deficits, no culturally appropriate evidence-based interventions exist to address the associations between trauma exposure, mental health, and parenting in this population. This study adapts and preliminarily tests an innovative intervention, Parenting-STAIR (PSTAIR), which combines two existing evidence-based interventions (Skills Training in Affective and Interpersonal Regulation [STAIR] and Parenting-Child Care [PC- CARE]) to reduce mental health symptoms and improve parental functioning among trauma-exposed military- connected mothers. The adapted intervention will be brief and more targeted to the needs of individual mothers and will be further tested in a larger randomized clinical trial in a future study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Glia dysfunction caused by environmental factors or genetic mutations is implicated in the cause and exacerbation of neurodegenerative disorders. We currently lack effective methods to target glial cells for therapy, and although viral vectors are used routinely in preclinical CNS models, there are limitations with these technologies that prevent clinical translation. We will develop dendrimer-based nanoparticles that permit multivalent presentation of ligands for cell surface transporters that we have identified to be uniquely and highly expressed on different glial cells and evaluate glial cell delivery of mRNA using these nanoparticles in the mouse brain under healthy and neuroinflammatory states.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Forty percent of children with Cerebral Palsy have hemiplegia, characterized by impaired movement skills and muscle strength on one side of their body, leading to significant limitations in daily function and participation. This project proposes an innovative, child- and family-friendly, community-based training program using modified, commercially-available, joystick-operated ride-on-toys to promote self-initiated use and movement skills in the affected upper extremity in young children with hemiplegia between 3 and 8 years. Study findings have implications for the adoption of age-appropriate, highly enjoyable, and easy-to-operate modified toys by families as an adjunct to conventional therapy to increase children's functional use of their affected arm through goal-directed navigation through naturalistic environments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose the Ecosystem for Multi-modal Brain-behavior Experimentation and Research (EMBER), an accessible and versatile data archive for storage, processing, and curation of multimodal neurophysiological and behavioral datasets. EMBER extends established BRAIN Initiative data infrastructure, provides new data harmonization and synchronization capabilities, and supports scalable integrations for data coordination and AI driven batch processing to enable the goals of the Brain Behavior Quantification and Synchronization (BBQS) program. This resource, developed in close collaboration with BBQS consortia, will facilitate dataset sharing, cross-modality querying, and data mining to fundamentally transform our understanding of cognition and behavior and provide a foundation for improved health and clinical outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Alveolar macrophages are the first host cells to be infected when Mtb is inhaled, and until recently they have been regarded as a homogeneous, anti-inflammatory population that is permissive for Mtb infection. However, our recent work revealed subpopulations of AMs that are capable of pro-inflammatory responses and able to contain Mtb growth. In the proposed project, we will study the molecular mechanisms that cause CD38- AMs to be non-responsive to Mtb infection, which will advance our fundamental knowledge of the underlying AM biology and enable us to identify potential therapeutic targets for immune-mediated control of Mtb growth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Workforce diversification is essential to meet growing US demands in aging research, biomedical science and broader STEM fields. Older Americans are one of the fastest growing demographics in the country, yet geriatric educational training programs are lacking, particularly among younger students. The UMB RAMP program will fill this gap by providing West Baltimore high school students with foundational knowledge required to understand and translate concepts related to aging research while providing the skills to perform basic lab techniques and clinical skills that will be applied in a lab or research-based experience with UMB faculty conducting aging-focused research as a strategy to expose young students to the aging field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutation in GATAD1, a histone 3 trimethylated at lysine 4 (H3K4me3) interactor, is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) and heart failure, highlighting its importance for cardiac function. However, little is known as to the specific role of GATAD1 in cardiomyocytes, or molecular mechanisms by which GATAD1 loss- of-function results in cardiomyopathy. Proposed studies are aimed at understanding the function of GATAD1 in cardiomyocytes at the molecular, cellular, and physiological levels during aging and in pressure-overload induced heart failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blockages in the leg arteries are often treated with flexible but non-stretchable synthetic arterial substitutes called bypass grafts. These grafts tend to buckle and kink during limb flexion, promoting new blockages that require repeat interventions. We propose to develop a stretchy synthetic bypass graft that resists buckling similarly to healthy leg arteries and assess its performance during limb flexion using benchtop, human cadaver, computational, and large animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Fibrous dysplasia causes fibrotic bone lesions, full of immature bone forming osteoblasts, that result in pain, deformity and fracture susceptibility. Antibody that blocks the cytokine RANKL inhibits formation of bone eroding osteoclast cells and also improves bone lesions in fibrous dysplasia, but has side effects that limit use and thus alternative therapies are needed. These experiments proposed will help to reveal the mechanism by which anti- RANKL antibodies inhibit bone lesions with the goal of identifying alternative therapeutic targets.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies neural activities underlying social extinction of avoidance, a phenomenon that the behavior of avoiding an aversive object or place can be reduced by another social subject. ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: Project Narrative: AR Tech-DaSH is a technology and data science in health and medicine focused outreach exposure program for high school students, teachers and the community primarily in the northwest part of the state of Arkansas. The program incorporates imaging technologies and a data science curriculum focused on health and medicine in classroom outreach, a ten day summer camp, community outreach events hosted by the high school camp participants serving as STEM Ambassadors, and a virtual STEM and data science focused outreach to students and teachers across the state. The successful implementation of the Arkansas Tech-DaSH program will serve as a model for attracting students towards STEM and data science careers to ensure that the future STEM workforce better reflects the diverse population of the US.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The long-term goal of our research is to develop safe and effective therapies specifically for neonatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE). This would have an enormous impact on the burden that our society bears to rehabilitate and care for severely brain-damaged children. This project focuses on studying how cholesterol metabolism in microglia, the immune cells in the brain, affects their phenotype and behaviors, as well as the inflammatory responses following brain hypoxia ischemia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Free oligosaccharides represent an understudied set of bioactive molecules. We will use chemoproteomic mass spectrometry-based technologies to elucidate the interactome of Man(b1- 4)GlcNAc, a bioactive disaccharide implicated in autoimmunity. This interactome will lead to an enhanced understanding of the molecular mechanisms through which free oligosaccharides exert important biological activity.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Population-based cervical screening including self-collect cervicovaginal samples (SCCS) has resulted in reducing the cervical cancer burden in high-income countries and SCCS can help minimize the cervical cancer burden among women living with HIV (WLWH) in Ghana. However, the implementation and dissemination mechanisms to translate SCCS into Ghanaâs healthcare systems have not been developed. This proposal seeks to develop contextually appropriate adaptation and implementation toolkits to enhance the adoption of SCCS in healthcare practices in Ghana, increase CCS, and reduce the CC burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Human papillomaviruses are causative agents in a number of ano-genital and oral cancers; HPV causes 5% of all cancers. There are no therapeutics that target the virus to assist with the alleviation of this disease burden and the focus of this application is to enhance our understanding of the HPV16 life cycle and how it contributes to HPV16 oncogenesis. We have discovered novel host transcriptional regulation by the HPV16 E2 protein, and this proposal will investigate the mechanism of this regulation and the consequences for the viral life cycle and HPV16 positive cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microbial biofilm infections are a leading complication in healing of wounds arising in a multitude of settings, including severe burns, non-healing pressure ulcers, dog bites, surgical site infections, and gunshot wounds; the physical barrier of the biofilm makes it recalcitrant to traditional antibiotic treatment. A potential solution that shows activity against biofilms in vitro is the use of novel graft polyelectrolyte surfactants (PS) with the ability to encapsulate into nanoparticles and deliver cationic antimicrobial peptides (CAMs) across the biofilm barrier. In the proposed work, PS-CAM nanoparticles will be deployed in the wound infection environment, both for imaging and for treatment, by formulation into a ânanosprayâ that is able to achieve broad coverage within the wound bed, avoid rapid clearance of dyes or of active CAMs in the highly active regenerating wound environment, and penetrate biofilm barriers via the polyelectrolyte surfactant detergency.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative More than 30% of pregnant women receive oxytocin for induction of labor in the United States. Despite concern over an association between this practice and the risk of autism spectrum disorders (ASD), a thorough mechanistic understanding is currently lacking. Considering the importance of oxytocinergic signaling in ASD, this proposal will comprehensively investigate the impact of maternally administered oxytocin on the oxytocinergic system in the developing brain using a hi-fidelity pregnant mouse model for labor induction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A better understanding of the neural circuitry that control motivated behavior is critical to developing new strategies to treat and prevent drug addicition and other compulsive disorders. Dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) have been widely implicated as a common substrate of drugs of abuse, but other VTA neuron types also contribute and may represent new targets for future intervention. This research program will evaluate the contribution of novel VTA populations to behavioral reinforcement and opioid-induced behaviors.

PHR: Project Narrative: Bacteria of the genus Chlamydia cause serious infections including sexually transmitted diseases and the potentially blinding ocular infection, trachoma. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Craniofacial skeletal muscle is essential for basic life functions including chewing, swallowing, and speaking; therefore, understanding how this tissue regenerates in response to injury and disease will provide the basis for therapeutic advances in the treatment of craniofacial muscle diseases and disorders. Our group has demonstrated that craniofacial skeletal muscle has the ability to regenerate following damage, but to what extent remains unknown. The goal of this proposal is to comprehensively investigate the regenerative capacity of craniofacial muscle and its stem cell population to inform developments in treatment modalities for individuals suffering from craniofacial muscle injury or disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: OH STEM!: Narrative OH STEM! works with tribal partners to create educational opportunities centered in the unique culture and environment of Southeast Alaska for underrepresented rural and Indigneous students. We will bring courses, mentored research projects, and scientists to remote Alaska communities to meet students where they are, while supporting SE Alaska partners to grow their own capacity for STEM education. These culturally centered experiences in their hometowns will develop a foundation of student belonging and resilience as they continue on their science career paths.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: BRITE Project Narrative We propose the Biotechnology Research Incubator for Teachers (BRITE) program to provide middle school teachers in the Houston area with summer research opportunities, aligning with Next Generation Science Standards and bridging the gap between research experiences, AI- guided literature adaptation, and classroom instruction. With a cohort of 12 teachers in the first year and 16 teachers annually in subsequent years, BRITE aims to enhance science education, empower teachers, and inspire students to pursue STEMM fields, impacting approximately 7,000 middle school students over five years. The program's influence will extend further as trained teachers disseminate knowledge and influence their colleagues, amplifying its reach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The Biomedical Engineering Superheroes program is anticipated to foster interest in Biomedical engineering and Clinical research in young learners from underserved communities and underrepresented minorities. This program seeks to produce the next generation of STEM field professionals with the potential to contribute to science from diverse perspectives due to the emphasis on representation and inclusion. We will include curricular units that demonstrate how Biomedical Engineering Superheroes fight against four common conditions or diseases that align to four of the mission areas (the fantastic four) of the NIH Institutes and Centers- obesity, diabetes, heart disease, and kidney disease based on data that demonstrated how prevalent and thus culturally relevant these public health issues are to families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A diverse health workforce representative of the US population is needed to ensure that everyone has access to  quality and relevant healthcare. Increasing high school students' social capital, that is, their access to  information and resources about health careers and effective mentorship, will help reduce barriers to entering  health professional school and becoming a healthcare practitioner. This project will develop and implement a  problem-based, four-year medical curriculum and multi-level mentoring network for 70 high school students  to give them the essential skills for pursuing a career in healthcare.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Herpes simplex viruses (HSV) 1 and 2 cause lifelong infections in most of the human population and represent a heavy burden on human health. New curative treatments are critically needed, and we are developing a novel therapeutic strategy against herpesviruses, using engineered âgene driveâ viruses that replace wild-type viruses with an attenuated version and reduce viral levels. In this innovative application, we propose to test if our strategy can inactivate wild-type viruses and prevent viral shedding in mouse models of HSV-1 infection, paving the way toward new curative treatments for chronic HSV diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will use multiple methods to study how language discordance affects hospital nursing practice with persons with limited English proficiency (LEP) (approximately 20% of the US population and includes deaf persons) and may contribute to inequitable outcomes associated with hospitalization. The studyâs scientific premises are that a) communication barriers between clinicians and patients are a social determinant of health that contribute to health inequities; b) the sources of inequities in hospital-based outcomes for LEP patients are all nurse-sensitive; c) hospital nurses and their practices in relation to bridging language barriers are the most under- studied area of practice despite having the highest volume of contact with LEP patients; and d) practice guidelines for nurses and their employers about âessentialâ times to use language services are vague and not well specified. The findings from this study will help to reduce inequities in hospitalization associated outcomes amongst LEP persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Down syndrome (DS) is a developmental genetic condition caused by trisomy of human chromosome 21. DS occurs in approximately 1 in 600-1000 live births and is estimated to affect more than 300,000 individuals in the USA. Neuropathological and clinical features of Alzheimerâs disease (AD) present early in life through the sixth decade, and include amyloid plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, NGF dysmetabolism and cholinergic basal forebrain degeneration, CNS inflammation, and cognitive decline leading to AD dementia. Despite the molecular and genetic similarities between AD and DS, there exists a paucity of information on the biological mechanisms underlying the onset of cognitive decline in adults with DS. Responding to the INCLUDE initiative, the overall goal of this proposal is to investigate pathophysiological mechanisms and novel biomarkers in different stages of AD in DS. The proposed studies use a multidisciplinary and complementary approach, which includes biochemical analysis of plasma, CSF, and extracellular vesicles (EVs), neuropathological assessments, trancriptomics, proteomics, in vitro cellular/molecular analyses, and a well-characterized cohort of DS individuals to uncover the molecular pathobiological progression of AD in DS. This powerful combination of neuropathological, cellular, and clinical studies using the same biomarkers will lead to a detailed characterization of AD stages that will enable a precision medicine approach that will inform future preventive trials and assist in the prediction of the onset and evolution of AD dementia and in the identification of novel therapeutic targets in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Human craniofacial development is a complex process and requires suites of genes to be switched on and off at appropriate times and spaces during formation of the embryo. There is now a wealth of data available in public databases concerning which genes are expressed when and where during mammalian facial development, including for the transcription factors which are the proteins that regulate these critical expression programs, but we have not yet begun to connect this information together to derive logical predictions about the critical networks responsible for craniofacial development. This proposal will address that gap using both computational and laboratory-based methods to derive and verify transcriptional regulatory networks relevant to the genetic and molecular underpinnings of normal facial development as well as how these are disrupted to cause defects such as human orofacial clefting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Patients who have experienced a stroke or other brain injury frequently experience word finding problems - a condition that can affect daily activities, psychological well-being, and overall quality of life of those with the condition and their families. One major challenge in this area is the lack of efficient and precise metrics to support treatment research and clinical decision making. The primary goal of this project is to utilize novel computational tools to develop a computer adaptive assessment system that will reach high levels of precision while minimizing testing burden for both patients and clinicians, and will ultimately allow each task during a clinical session to be administered dynamically and tailored uniquely to each patient.

PHR: Project Narrative Candida auris is an emerging fungal pathogen responsible for healthcare-associated and fomite transmissible outbreaks worldwide. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Non-pharmacological cognitive behavioral interventions for chronic pain (CP), which seek to maximize physical, social, and occupational functioning, are increasingly relied upon for the overwhelming number of individuals suffering with this condition. Much CP research is limited by the use of between-subject designs and self-report measures that lack ecological validity and may be subject to bias. The proposed research will use an objective indicator of physical function (actigraphy), real-time, real-world measures of pain (i.e., ecological momentary assessment), latent growth curve modelling, and qualitative methods to address limitations in the understanding and conceptualization of functional improvement in CP, and thus will advance public health goals of improving and refining relevant complementary and integrative interventions for CP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Healthy relationships are a cornerstone of the human experience and benefit our physical and emotional wellbeing. To be successful and achieve shared goals, partners must organize their behavior via reciprocal action, but the vast majority of studies on pair bonding study only one member of a pair. Here, I will use pair bonding prairie voles to examine both bonded partners at the behavioral and neuromolecular levels, which will uncover how pairs organize their behavior to enable the emergent properties of relationships.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is aimed toward the development of ortho-dithioquinones as pseudometal organocatalysts, entirely metal-free small molecules capable of mimicking the redox processes and elementary steps of traditional transition-metal catalysts. The proposed strategy will not only provide a suite of organocatalysts to serve as complements and alternatives to transition-metal catalysts, but also it will provide new opportunities for the discovery of fundamental new reactivity in bond forming processes and for the development of novel methodologies capable of unlocking previously dormant catalytic pathways. Ultimately, this research will facilitate the expansion of sustainable and economical organocatalytic reactions as alternatives to traditional transition-metal catalysis, thereby enhancing the productivity of medicinal chemistry campaigns, increasing accessibility in pharmaceutical development and proliferation, and advancing fundamental aspirations in the pursuit of human health.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PAR-20-132: Washington State Department of Agriculture (WSDA) - Animal Feed Program Maintenance of Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards and Implementation of Preventive Controls Regulatory Activities and Capacity PROJECT NARRATIVE The Washington Department of Agriculture PAR-20-132 project intention is to maintain and improve our program with the Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards (AFRPS) and to expand our ability to implement the Preventive Controls for Animal Food (PCAF) Rule. Overall, our goal aligns with PCAF Rule to advance efforts for a nationally integrated food safety system by encouraging the safe manufacturing and processing of animal food and promoting understanding and compliance with the requirements of the PCAF Rule. This proposal explains how we will ensure AFRPS is sustained and increase the number of staff to meet the needs for all project deliverables, including for training and auditing. We also included in our proposal to assist the feed industry, particularly small and very small feed businesses through outreach to enhance and improve their understanding of the PCAF requirements and support them to successfully develop PCAF compliant animal food safety during manufacturing, packing, handling and holding of their animal food products as well as their monitoring systems.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Maintenance of Animal Feed Regulatory Program Standards and Implementation of Preventive Controls Regulatory Activities and Capacity

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Proposal Title: Multifactorial dynamic modeling of brain asymmetry in neurodevelopmental disorders FOA: PA-21-219 Joint NINDS/NIMH Exploratory Neuroscience Research Grant (R21 Clinical Trial Optional) Project Narrative This project is proposed to characterize the dynamic causal relationships between brain asymmetry, genetic and environmental risk factors as well as psychopathological behaviors for neurodevelopmental disorders in typically and atypically developed children and adolescents. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it seeks to reveal the neurobiological pathways through which the pathological brain structural abnormalities and clinical symptoms of neurodevelopmental disorders arise, and to elucidate etiological distinctions and overlaps between different neurodevelopmental disorders. Upon completion, our study will provide novel models and tools for assisting diagnosis and treatment selection for heterogeneous childhood mental disorders as well as the development of precision medicine approaches.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through regular epidemics and infrequent pandemics, influenza A virus causes mild to severe disease in a significant proportion of the population every year. By defining the mechanisms by which influenza A viruses evolve, our research supports efforts to control the spread of influenza viruses in the human population and the emergence of novel influenza A viruses from non-human reservoirs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diverse populations of memory T cells circulate throughout the body and protect us from re-infection by previously encountered pathogens, but our understanding of how these populations develop, compete, and are maintained is incomplete. A quantitative grasp of this complex ecosystem will reveal what determines the duration of T cell memory, and how to manipulate it; for example, to extend the protection given by vaccines, or to boost and sustain the activity of tumor-specific T cells. In this project we will integrate mathematical modeling and new experimental tools to quantify multiple aspects of circulating T cell dynamics in depth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lung cancer screening by chest CT can detect lung cancer earlier and make the disease less deadly; but even among nodules that are intermediate risk, a small minority are cancerous. We will develop and validate innovative biomarkers from nasal swabs, blood, and advanced imaging analysis for determining which intermediate risk lung nodules detected via screening, or detected incidentally as part of routine clinical care, are actually lung cancers to speed treatment while minimizing invasive tests and clinical uncertainty related to benign nodules. We will partner with two molecular diagnostics companies to refine and standardize these biomarkers so that useful biomarkers can quickly be put to use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will contribute to our understanding of how metabolic pathways regulate the differentiation and function of immune cells, as well as how metabolic conditions in the tumor microenvironment regulate the activity of tumor-associated antigen-presenting cells. It will also further elucidate how selective inhibition of glutamine metabolism can augment the efficacy of immune checkpoint blockade in order to more effectively treat malignancies that are resistant to the effects of immunotherapy. Lastly, it will seek to improve the treatment options available to treat late-stage soft tissue sarcoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lay Summary The number of obese people has increased dramatically during the past few decades, and many develop diabetes. More than half of diabetic patients develop cardiac dysfunction characterized by mitochondrial dysfunction. Although normal heart cells are capable of removing problematic mitochondria immediately, this mechanism is impaired in diabetic patients. We will investigate the molecular mechanisms by which heart cells remove dysfunctional mitochondria and how these mechanisms are altered in the presence of diabetes. Our study may lead to the development of novel interventions to improve the quality of heart cell mitochondria, which should, in turn, prevent cardiac dysfunction in diabetic patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Current in vitro assays and in vivo models designed to study the pathophysiology of opioid use disorder (OUD) and to discover potential therapeutic targets are useful, but there is a need for additional model systems. Our research strategy involves the use of induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived 3D brain organoids and single-cell sequencing technology to identify molecular signatures for OUD using two commonly prescribed synthetic opioids: oxycodone and fentanyl as molecular probes. This approach will make it possible to advance our understanding of both drug action and of disease pathophysiology at the single-cell level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The brainâs ability to accurately predict the sensory outcome of our actions is critical for many aspects of behavior in health and disease, but the cellular pathways that learn and implement these predictions are not well understood. This proposal will apply state-of-the-art behavioral, physiological, and computational techniques in concert with one another to understand how sensory-motor predictions are implemented mechanistically across multiple interacting brain regions. These experiments will provide critical insight into how distributed circuits work together to facilitate hearing and identify key circuit elements that may contribute to the dysfunction of flexible sensory processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Maintaining cognitive health represents a key priority for older survivors of prostate cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Thalidomide and its analogs have proven to be an extremely effective treatment for hematologic malignancies and over the last decade they have demonstrated their versatility in the development of new therapeutic modalities. Despite their therapeutic potential, the molecular mechanisms of their devastating teratogenicity remain ambiguous, which we will resolve through the proposed studies. This grant further aims to push the boundaries of these molecules to target new classes of undruggable proteins ultimately leading to novel cancer therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the hereditary genetics of Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC), a devastating cancer of the liver with well-defined environmental risk factors, but with an undefined inherited genetic component. Here, we will complete a genetic association study to determine whether patients with HCC harbor rare inherited variants in genes at higher rates than in control populations, which could guide clinical recommendations for genetic testing. We will also determine whether inherited defects increase cancer cell susceptibility to specific drug therapies, which could change clinical practice and improve survival.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Long-term use of sedative hypnotics is associated with dependence, falls, fractures, high-risk parasomnias (sleepwalking, sleep-driving), and cognitive impairment. Despite this and guideline recommendations limiting their use, these drugs are the most popular pharmaceutical insomnia treatment. The objective of the Study in Outpatient Medicine using NUdges to improve Sleep (the SOMNUS Trial) is to develop and test behavioral nudges in a randomized trial to deprescribe these drugs and encourage the use of evidence-based therapies for insomnia in everyday clinical practice.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite recent advances in anti-PD-1 immunotherapy, not all patients respond favorably and cancer remains the second leading cause of death in the US. Studying the inhibitory transmembrane protein Phosphoprotein Associated with Glycosphingolipid Rich Microdomains 1 (PAG), a downstream target of PD-1 signaling, will help us better understand the PD-1 pathway, and offer another, perhaps more nuanced target to improve response rates and/or avoid adverse effects. PAG links lipid-rich regions of the membrane to the actin cytoskeleton, and its study will illuminate crucial control mechanisms associated with T cell synapse organization, opening more methods to therapeutically target the immune synapse.

PHR: Project Narrative The EphB4-p120RasGAP signaling axis is critical for vascular development and mutations in both EphB4 and p120RasGAP are associated with vascular disorders including Vein of Galen Malformation and Capillary Malformation-Arteriovenous Malformation Syndrome. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The epidermis is a multi-layered tissue composed primarily of cells called keratinocytes, which undergo a specialized maturation process to continually regenerate the skinâs outermost layers to prevent dehydration and infections. Fully mature keratinocytes must degrade their nuclei and organelles to form these compacted, protective layers, however, this step is compromised in patients with rare skin barrier disorders like ichthyosis and Darier disease but also in those with common diseases including atopic dermatitis and psoriasis. This project will use gene editing and advanced microscopic imaging to understand keratinocyte maturation with the long-term goal of identifying new ways to improve the skinâs barrier function and treat dermatologic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Impaired function of ATP Binding Cassette transporters of the D subfamily underlies a wide array of serious metabolic and neurological diseases such as X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy, a rare genetic disorder caused by mutations in ABCD1 that can be fatal and for which no cure exists, and other defects caused by impaired fatty acid and phospholipid processing. This project focuses on detailed structure-function studies on the peroxisomal fatty acid transporters ABCD1, ABCD2, and ACBD3 to understand how they work at the molecular level to aid in future design and development of diagnostic and therapeutic tools to combat diseases stemming from their dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Sexual minority and gender minority (SGM) individuals are more likely to have poor physical health than their non-SGM peers. In this proposal, we will test if SGM people are more likely to have higher levels of cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors than non-SGM people and determine if stigma against SGM people contributes to increased risk for poor CVD outcomes in these populations at the intersections of race/ethnicity, sex, and socioeconomic status. As part of our larger goal to not only decrease SGM CVD but also to enhance SGM cardiovascular health equity, we will investigate if resilience promoting factors can mediate the harmful health effects of stigma to improve the health of diverse SGM populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE â  Malignant prostate cancer is a leading killer of men and new approaches to reduce tumor burden and extend life. PSMA-targeted molecular radiotherapy, in which cancer cells are irradiated with biological specificity, is a promising approach that is currently limited by background toxicity to radiosensitive organs including the salivary glands and kidney. We propose a potent strategy that eliminates non-tumor organ uptake of PSMA molecular radiotherapy while retaining tumoricidal effect; resulting in improved therapeutic response with reduced toxicities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Smooth muscle cells secrete exosomes, which are very small particles containing various bioactive lipids, microRNAs or proteins and if increasing may contribute to calcium deposition in the artery wall leading to arterial hardening and increasing risk for cardiovascular disorders. This grant application for the first time explores a molecular mechanism regulating exosome release at the DNA level and determines whether the deficiency of this regulation causes arterial calcification and hardening. Our findings will help answer an important question how arterial hardening starts within cells at the very early stage of patients with cardiovascular risk factor such as hyperphosphatemia and will help develop new strategies for treatment and prevention of cardiovascular disorders.

PHR: Mutations which alter chromosome structure and copy number can have profound consequences for human development and disease. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Human disease-causing mutations in connexin channels affect the transport of ions and molecules across the plasma membrane, causing deafness, blindness, as well as neurological and skin disorders. We seek to understand the molecular mechanisms underlying ion and molecule transport in connexin channels, with the goal of elucidating how human mutations alter these processes. This information is critical for the rational development of therapeutic approaches to treat the disorders caused by human connexin mutations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: We propose to study SERCA, the enzyme that controls calcium in muscle. Calcium misregulation leads to myopathies of skeletal muscle. Our evidence suggests that SERCA is regulated by proteins of the muscle cytoskeleton, and that contractions of muscle can transmit signals to SERCA through these proteins to modulate its activity. If we can verify this idea, we will gain important insights into the role that SERCA plays in maintaining healthy skeletal muscle, and how to manipulate its activity to combat myopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Streptococcus sanguinis is a common bacterium in the mouth, where it is associated with oral health; however, if it enters the bloodstream through periodontal disease, routine activities such as chewing, or dental procedures, it can cause a serious infection of the heart called infective endocarditis. We propose to perform an unprecedented search for factors required by S. sanguinis to cause this disease with the goal of finding targets for a new kind of antibiotic that prevents disease, but can also be taken daily without promoting antibiotic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Thorp Narrative Lay Due in significant part to limited therapeutic options and incomplete understanding of mechanisms of pathophysiology, diastolic dysfunction (DD) and Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF) encompasses approximately half of all heart failure cases. Our data implicate maladaptive metabolism of innate immune cells in the progression of DD during HFpEF. The studies outlined in this proposal are among the first to test the therapeutic proof of principle, mechanistic basis, and clinical relevance of immune metabolism during DD.

PHR: Project Narrative  Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and sustained conceptual as well as therapeutic innovation is needed to reduce disease burden. Thus, it is imperative to start training the next generation of cancer researchers as early as possible. We propose a comprehensive summer undergraduate research program that integrates mentored cancer research with educational initiatives in computational and public health-based approaches to provide research experiences and skills that will facilitate successful entry into oncology research careers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with B-cell mediated autoimmune lymphoproliferative diseases, including systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and those with indolent, pre-malignant B-cell clones are vulnerable to developing aggressive B-cell malignancies. Our proposed studies will delineate how the hormone, prolactin (PRL), by signaling specifically through the long and intermediate isoforms of the prolactin receptor (LF/IFPRLR), drives the evolution of high- grade B-cell malignancies in vulnerable individuals and sustains these malignancies. Our investigations will identify isoform-specific knockdown of the LF/IFPRLR as an effective, less-toxic, and affordable approach to treat a broad spectrum of B-lymphoproliferative disorders with widely divergent outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Epigenetic regulation and synaptic signaling emerged as convergent cellular and molecular pathways affected in multiple cohorts of patients with ASD, suggesting that epigenetic dysregulation during development might lead to dysfunctional neural circuits in autism. However, which neural cell types are affected by autism-associated epigenetic changes and how these changes influence formation and function of specific neuronal circuits is currently unknown. Dissecting cell type-specific epigenetic and neuronal circuitry changes is paramount to precise understanding of autism pathogenesis and selection of targets for precision medicine.
