IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a life-threatening disease of the immune system that primarily affects women in childbearing age with death rates approaching 10% in 5 years. The major causes of death include infections due to the toxicity of immunosuppressant medications. Therefore, a significant unmet need exists for non-toxic medications in SLE. Our research has been directed to develop safe and effective treatments that are focused on the very causes of lupus pathogenesis, such as the depletion of a natural antioxidant, reduced glutathione (GSH), which underlies inflammation in SLE through activating a regulatory protein called the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR). Along this line, we have initiated a clinical trial in SLE patients aimed at the replenishment of GSH with an amino acid precursor, N-acetylcysteine (NAC). As shown by our pilot study completed in 2011, NAC was tolerated by all patients at the 1.2 g/day and 2.4 g/day dosages, while 33% of those receiving 4.8 g/day had reversible nausea. Placebo and 1.2 g/day NAC did not influence disease activity. Although the 2.4 g/day and 4.8 g/day NAC dosages showed preliminary evidence for therapeutic efficacy, 4.8 g/day NAC achieved greater clinical improvements. NAC raised GSH, blocked mTOR, and expanded anti-inflammatory cells. Importantly, the safety of NAC has been widely confirmed and efficacy has been noted in follow-up case reports. While NAC is inexpensive compared to current therapies burdened with serious side-effects and widely accessible in health food stores, it is unavailable as an oral medication by prescription. Therefore, the proposed phase II trial will employ the SLE Responder Index (SRI), as a clinically meaningful primary outcome to evaluate the efficacy of NAC over 1 year. To minimize potential intolerance of NAC and subject withdrawal during the trial, the design includes an open-label dosage titration period. Patients who tolerate 2.4-4.8 g daily NAC for 3 months will be randomized or assigned 1:1 to continue treatment on their tolerated dosage of NAC or matching placebo for 9 additional months. Beyond the premise of validating clinical efficacy and durability of this therapy, the proposed studies will test the assumption that depletion of GSH and activation of mTOR predict clinical responsiveness to NAC in SLE. The proposed studies are expected to lead to the development of a novel, uniquely safe, and affordable medication with the potential to favorably alter the long-term outcomes of SLE.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE Bony fractures are very common during orthopaedic trauma. Approximately ten percent of the 16 million fractures occurring annually in the United States do not progress to timely union; especially in patients under inflammatory conditions, including diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The main goal of this study is to define Dnmt3b-mediated molecular and epigenetic changes to further elucidate a novel pathway in fracture repair. This work will enhance our understanding of mechanisms by which systemic inflammation (via the NF- ÎºB pathway) affects the fracture healing process through Dnmt3b and identify downstream targets of Dnmt3b (such as RbpjÎº) as novel candidates for therapeutic intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative Current influenza (flu) vaccines are not effective in protection against viruses with antigen drifts/shifts even after annual update. This, along with a constant threat of unpredicted emergence of a new virus with pandemic potential, urges the need to develop a âUniversalâ flu vaccine that can elicit heterosubtypic immunity against both seasonal and pandemic flu viruses. To address this unmet medical need specifically, this proposal is to develop a safe and potent mucosal adjuvant to vigorously stimulate heterosubtypic immunity of licensed flu vaccines against diverse flu A viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative  This project is relevant to public health because hysterectomies (i.e., surgical removal of the uterus) are a common surgical procedure performed in women over the age of 60. Ureteral injuries are a serious complication of hysterectomies due to poor visualization of the ureter (which needs to remain intact to preserve urinary func- tion) and nearby blood vessels (which need to be severed for uterus removal). Our aim is to establish a novel photoacoustic imaging technology that will enable surgeons to avoid the ureter and better target the uterine arteries while detecting surgical tool tips to mitigate a serious complication of hysterectomies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epilepsy is marked by paroxysmal seizures, and it can be extremely difficult to determine which brain regions are involved. Brain stimulation is a way that brain excitability can be probed and altered for the diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy. This project uses newly available brain stimulation technology to quickly and accurately localize patient-specific epilepsy networks to improve diagnosis and treatment of focal epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (from parent application) Nivolumab, a novel PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor, has shown unprecedented results in a phase II clinical trial in hepatocellular carcinoma, a tumor type that is refractory to other targeted therapies, and has been granted accelerated FDA approval. Unfortunately, the determinants of sensitivity and resistance to this immunotherapy have not been established yet. Here, by combining the use a novel mouse model of HCC immune surveillance, human HCC samples, and transcriptional and immune profilings, we will establish the tumor intrinsic signaling pathways that promote immune escape in HCC, the underlying mechanisms of immune escape, and their effects on response to anti-PD-1 therapy, providing the rationale for improved patient selection and strategies to overcome resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Bacterial lipopolysaccharide, also known as endotoxin, is an essential building block of Gram-negative bacterial cell walls and recognized by human antimicrobial protein GBP1. This project will determine how both intracellular and extracellular Gram-negative bacterial pathogens alter their lipopolysaccharides in order to avoid recognition by cytosolic and secreted GBP1. The characterization of these bacterial immune escape strategies may identify novel drug targets for the treatment of bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Allogeneic blood or marrow transplantation (AlloBMT) is the most effective consolidation strategy to prevent disease relapse in adults with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myeloid leukemia (AML) who achieve remission, but the risk of relapse following transplant remains unacceptably high and is now the most significant cause of post-transplant mortality. Newly developed therapies that stimulate the immune system to fight leukemia have proven successful in ALL and AML patients with relapsed disease. The focus of this application is to use these new therapies following alloBMT to prevent relapse of AML and ALL with a long-term goal of identifying the patients in whom such post-transplant therapy is most necessary and successful.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative - Toxin secretion and trafficking by Mycobacterium tuberculosis The ability to control the timing and mode of host cell death plays a pivotal role in microbial infections. Most pathogenic bacteria use toxins to evade and/or subvert immune responses, to survive and replicate in the host. In this project we investigate the novel molecular mechanisms, by which CpnT, the only known exotoxin of M. tuberculosis, is secreted, how the toxin is trafficked into the cytosol of macrophages infected with M. tuberculosis and which role these mechanisms play in virulence and pathogenesis of M. tuberculosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The two most prescribed biologics in Ulcerative Colitis are vedolizumab and adalimumab, however, efficacy for these advanced therapies plateaus at approximately 30%. Our data indicate that persistence of distinct neutrophil subsets in the intra-epithelial space results in ongoing intestinal stem cell (ISC) injury, negatively impacting the epithelial crypt microenvironment and treatment efficacy for biologics. Thus, proposed studies will identify new mechanisms of therapeutic resistance to biologics and identify molecular targets to optimize/improve responsiveness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Nef is an HIV-1 accessory protein whose function is essential for the virus to undermine host defenses, yet is not targeted by any existing antirtrovirals. Nef downmodulates many substrates, including CD3, CD4, CD8, CD28, CXCR4, MHC-I, SERINC3/5, and for HIV-1 group O and SIV, BST2/tetherin by hijacking a family of heterotetrameric adaptors known as the adaptor protein (AP) complexes. This proposal will use cryo-EM and biochemistry and biophysics to determine the mechanism by which Nef hijacks AP complexes and downmodulates so many different substrates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The removal of damaged cells from the sensory organs of the inner ear helps promote tissue repair and homeostasis. The proposed studies will examine the roles of inflammatory cells and epithelial supporting cells in this repair process. Additional studies will determine whether inflammatory cells are responsible for balance disorders caused by infection with cytomegalovirus and by cochlear implantation.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is relevant to Veteransâ health because it focuses on developing a new, non-invasive set of tools to identify the disease progression of multiple sclerosis (MS) before it becomes irreversible, thereby creating the potential for new treatments. More than 30,000 Veterans have been diagnosed with MS since 1998 and 17,000 are treated within the Veteran Affairs Healthcare System yearly.1 The high healthcare burden in the Veteran population, resulting from the physical and cognitive impairment caused by MS, has led the creation of the VA MS Center of Excellence Network.2  The results of our work are expected to have a positive impact because they will facilitate the monitoring of Veterans who have MS and other traumatic and non-traumatic pathologies of the central nervous system.  Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the VA ORDâs mission âto improve Veterans' health and well- being via basic, translational, clinical, health services, and rehabilitative research.â

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our Research Hub, which is called âINFORM Africaâ (Role of Data Streams In Informing Infection Dynamics in Africa), is to understand how we can use big data from the different sources on infections or disease in Africa, starting with Nigeria and South Africa, in order to explain better what we do daily as a community that puts us at risk of infection and the spread of the virus like with COVID-19 and HIV. If we know this, we may be able to prevent future epidemics and pandemics from happening or at least be better prepared for them so that the spread and deaths is reduced. Making all data that still protects the privacy of those that provided it easily available for all scientists to work together on the data will help us know what to do much faster.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE The liver is our largest metabolic organ. It filters the blood coming from the digestive tract before it reaches the rest of the body, and secretes bile, a digestive aid, back into the intestine. This controlled traffic of molecules in and out of the liver is mediated by epithelia. Epithelial cells act as sophisticated gatekeepers that form polarized membrane domains to restrict the transporters and gated channels responsible for the trafficking of molecules across the cell membrane to either the blood facing or the bile facing surfaces. This ensures that molecule transport is directional. Hepatocytes, the main epithelial cell type in the liver, organize these polarized domains with an architecture that is different from that of all other epithelia in the body. When this unique architecture is lost, as in fibrotic liver diseases, hepatocyte function is compromised. This proposal seeks to determine, on a molecular level, how hepatocytes acquire their distinct polarity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Different regions of the skin vary in their characteristics such as thickness, pigmentation, innervation, and presence, size and density of hair follicles and sweat glands, that are reflected in differential responses to injury and to diseases such as androgenetic alopecia and psoriasis that predominate in specific skin regions. We propose to identify novel mechanisms that establish and maintain skin heterogeneity. Improved understanding of these mechanisms has potential to reveal new therapeutic targets for diseases that affect specific skin regions and have a major negative impact on quality of life; data obtained in this project will also inform strategies for generating specific skin types, including hair follicle- and sweat gland-bearing skin, for reparative skin grafting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Acute myocardial infarction (AMI) remains a major cause of global morbidity and mortality. Current therapy for AMI focuses on rapidly restoring blood flow through an occluded coronary artery. However, reperfusion itself can cause myocardial damage, known as reperfusion injury. Use of veno-arterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) has grown exponentially and is the subject of several clinical trials in AMI. We have now identified a novel paradigm whereby VA-ECMO worsens heart damage by depleting critical regulators of mitochondrial function and further shown that targeting these mechanisms may reduce heart damage in AMI. By employing highly translational models and clinically relevant interventional approaches, these studies introduce new mechanisms involving VA-ECMO and myocardial reperfusion injury, provide penetrating insight into cardioprotection and generate proof of concept data for the development of new therapeutic approaches to limit LV injury in AMI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human microbiota produce a rich diversity of small molecules that fundamentally shape human physiology and have been linked to diseases including metabolic disease, neurodegenerative disorders, and cancer. This project will define a causal link between a class of prominent microbiome-derived molecules and the unfolded protein response, a stress response pathway that is important for protein homeostasis. Understanding how these small molecules influence health and disease may enable the development of novel biomarkers and microbiome- derived therapeutics to improve human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Multiple Myeloma (MM) is an incurable cancer characterized by the development of devastating lytic bone disease and accompanied by compromised immunosurveillance. We found that matrix metallopeptidase-13 (MMP-13) secreted by MM cells induces bone resorption resulting in lytic bone lesions, and discovered that MMP-13 binds to the novel immune checkpoint protein programmed death-1 homologue (PD-1H), which is expressed on osteoclasts, antigen presenting cells and T cells. This grant for the first time investigates the role of MMP-13/PD-1H interaction and their functions in linking bone disease and immunosuppression in MM, hence will form the basis for novel treatment strategies and help better understand the role of MM bone disease in the suppressed myeloma immune environment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimerâs Disease and Related Dementia (ADRD) spousal caregivers often endure a period of âliving bereavementâ before the death of their partner, putting them at risk for morbidity and mortality. Thus, the development of evidence-based interventions for ADRD spousal caregivers aimed at mitigating the negative health consequences associated with grief is a critical public health concern. The proposed project will (1) identify opportunities for targeted treatment and potential barriers to a tailored intervention, and (2) develop an internet-based cognitive-behavioral writing intervention for ADRD Spousal Caregivers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Centrosomes play a crucial role in the successful segregation of chromosomes during spermatogenesis. Mis- regulation of centrosome processes can lead to sperm aneuploidy and infertility. Using mouse mutant model systems, we aim to assess the process of centriole and centrosome biogenesis in order to better understand their roles in the context of spermatogenesis.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The RISE national patient registry has broken new ground in connecting rheumatology practices around the country in a large data network, measuring quality, and providing continuous feedback on clinical performance. The proposed study will generate scientific evidence to establish the impact of RISE on clinical outcomes, while at the same time helping us understand the mechanisms of its impact through the in-depth study of registry dashboard use patterns and qualitative studies with stakeholders. Data generated through this research will inform improvements to RISE that maximize its impact on health outcomes for people with rheumatic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Narrative Most melanocytic diseases arise in the skin epidermis (e.g. vitiligo and melanoma), but epidermal melanocytes remain drastically under examined because of the paucity of appropriate tools which specifically target these cells in preclinical mouse models. We have created a novel mouse model termed OCA2-creERT to solely target epidermal MC populations to reveal OCA2+ epidermal melanocytes are long-lived, capable of both self-renewal and differentiation and bear tumor-initiating potential, signifying that they are stem/precursor cells. The goal of this grant is to completely characterize the stemness of OCA2+epidermal melanocytes and begin to understand their molecular regulation with the ultimate goal of establishing new strategies to target epidermal melanocytes to prevent and treat pigmentation disorders including melanoma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This project seeks to overcome a widely recognized but also widely ignored challenge that has long plagued the study stuttering: the fact that stuttering behaviors vary greatly from task-to-task, from situation-to-situation, and from time-to-time. We will collect and analyze the largest-ever samples of stuttered speech in real-world situations, so that we can develop more accurate measures of stuttering behavior that can be used in clinical and research settings. Our improved understanding of why stuttering varies and how this variability affects people who stutter will directly support improvements in the assessment and treatment of the disorder and ultimately help to reduce the adverse impact of stuttering for the roughly three million individuals in the United States who live with stuttering.

This proposal will extend Dockstore to make it more robust and dependable, to allow it to store new content types, such as programming notebooks, and to build chains of trust between tool creators and users. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  While nearly 40 million women in the United States undergo mammography screening each year, 1 in 8 breast cancers are still missed due to the limitations of human radiologist interpretation even with the use of newer tests like 3D mammography. Recently, multiple promising artificial intelligence technologies for automated mammography interpretation have become commercially available but are unlikely to be widely adopted in clinical practice until they are shown to improve screening outcomes over radiologist interpretation alone. We will evaluate the performance of four leading artificial intelligence technologies for automated 3D mammography interpretation on a diverse national screening cohort and then leverage an established breast cancer simulation model to estimate the long-term benefits, harms, and costs associated with adopting AI tools for 3D mammography interpretation for the U.S. screening population to inform key stakeholders prior to their widespread clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although groundbreaking advances have enhanced the effectiveness of cancer treatment, many large epithelial tumors remain uncontrolled at the primary site and/or develop distant disease, which is almost always fatal. Our research could lead to the dramatic improvements required for the treatment of both local and systemic disease and in the overall cures of locally advanced and metastatic cancers. We speculate that activating cytotoxic CD8+ T cells and alleviating host immunosuppression are key to unleashing the full anti-tumor potential of both radiotherapy and radioimmunotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Diabetes is a major co-morbidity in pancreatic insufficient cystic fibrosis and associated with worse outcomes. While reduced Î²-cell mass contributes to the insulin deficiency that characterizes cystic fibrosis-related diabetes (CFRD), other modifiable determinants appear operative in the emergence and progression of abnormal glucose tolerance towards diabetes. Identifying 1) the contribution of insulin secretory defects and related modifiable and non-modifiable factors to the emergence and progression of abnormal glucose tolerance and 2) interventions to preserve Î²-cell function are crucial for delaying and potentially altogether preventing CFRD development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Eating behavior dimensions, including Food Approach, Food Avoidance, Food-Associated Self-regulation, Food-Associated Affect, and Liking for Sweet, are associated with dietary quality and growth in children and are therefore important to public health. The proposed study has the potential for high impact by establishing the predictive value of infant eating behavior traits and their moderation by maternal feeding practices for future health outcomes. The findings have a high likelihood of providing new intervention targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastroparesis is a chronic gastrointestinal motility disorder with no cure, which causes significant burden to patients and the healthcare system. The proposed research aims to identify the cellular mechanisms underlying this disease, by focusing our analysis on immune cells residing in the human stomach. Knowledge from this research is likely to result in the identification of novel cellular pathways that can be targeted therapeutically to treat, reduce symptoms, and cure gastroparesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: My research concerns the question of why drug use in adolescence is a strong predictor of lifetime abuse. To answer this, I study the effects of stimulant drugs on the molecular and structural changes that are ongoing in the brain during adolescence. This work is carried out in both males and females investigating the effects of therapeutic-like doses and excessive drug exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to establish routinely successful prolonged normothermic ex vivo heart perfusion (NEVHP) leading to organ banks. We have demonstrated routinely successful perfusion of hearts for 24-72 hours using plasma exchange with a paracorporeal animal, then fresh plasma alone, then continuous hemofiltration in ovine and porcine models. With this proposal, we expect to determine the factors responsible for prolonged NEVHP, demonstrate routine 3-day perfusion. In addition, the NEVHP protocols and systems will be tested to resuscitate hearts after prolonged periods of cold ischemia and hearts from DCD.This is a critical step to translate the animal models into clinical practice.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heart and vascular disease is a leading cause of disability and death in the United States. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Chemotherapy-induced cognitive impairment (CICI) is a major, severe long-lasting neurotoxic side effect of widely used chemotherapeutics that significantly impacts the quality of life of cancer survivors. The mechanisms are largely unknown and there are no FDA approved medicines. We present the first evidence that activation of the sphingosine 1-phosphate receptor subtype 1 (S1PR1) is germane to CICI and identify a novel therapeutic approach with S1PR1 antagonists already approved for other indications (fingolimod, ozanimod).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive metastatic breast cancer subtype with limited targeted therapies and poor prognosis. The molecular underpinnings promoting metastasis continue to be elucidated and include phenotypic and metabolic changes that support changing demands during the metastatic cascade. I aim to evaluate how the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition of tumor cells creates metabolic vulnerabilities that can be targeted therapeutically, with a focus on cholesterol uptake mechanisms.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Quick detection of emotion has been widely studied with adults but little is known about how this perceptual ability develops. The proposed study will document the development of emotion detection; specifically, the time course of emotion detection, potential preferential processing of threat-related emotions, how low-level visual features influence detection, how autonomic nervous system activity is differentially modulated by emotional content, and whether speed of processing on emotion detection tasks influences later social development. This research has implications for typically and atypically developing populations, in that emotion detection is severely impaired in individuals with autism spectrum disorder and has cascading effects, such as deficits in online perception of fluctuating emotional states, perceiving social cues, efficient mimicry of emotional expressions, and basic empathy processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Mutations in protein chaperones are associated with degenerative diseases including muscular dystrophy. Consistent with this, mutations in DNAJB6 cause Limb Girdle Muscular Dystrophy 1D. This proposal will explore DNAJB6 dysfunction using yeast, in vitro, and animal models. These studies will define the molecular pathogenesis and identify novel therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mycobacterium avium is an environmental bacterium that is capable of infecting humans and causing serious disease, requiring months to years of antibiotic treatment to cure. This proposal aims to use novel genetic tools to identify the bacterial genes that allow some strains of M. avium to establish chronic infection, and the pathways that allow M. avium to tolerate prolonged antibiotic exposure once infection is established. In doing so, this work will provide fundamental insights into how environmental bacteria evolve into pathogens, and lay a foundation for the development of improved therapies for this and other chronic bacterial infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative While >90% of the ~10 million TB cases that occur annually are curable, treatment is dependent on inadequate diagnostics that are currently based exclusively on detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) in patient sputum, despite the limitations of sputum as a diagnostic sample, as it is almost impossible to obtain from patients with paucibacillary TB, such as people living with HIV and children, and is not diagnostic for patients with extrapulmonary TB. Our long-term goal is to transform TB diagnosis with a blood test that accurately distinguishes patients with TB disease from latent TB infection and other pulmonary disorders regardless of co- infection with HIV. The objective of this study is to demonstrate the analytical and clinical performance of a novel assay for rapid diagnosis and treatment monitoring of TB that exploits the precise molecular affinity of CRISPR and promiscuous nuclease activity of Cas12a to detect ultra-low concentrations of Mtb cell free DNA (cfDNA) circulating in peripheral blood of patients with TB disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Irregular sleep schedules represent a common source of chronic sleep and circadian disruption in the contemporary world, but its impact on cardiometabolic disease remains poorly understood. This application combines traditional epidemiology with omics techniques and digital phenotyping to characterize the relationships between irregular sleep schedules and cardiometabolic disease risk. This research will advance our understanding of the mechanisms linking irregular sleep to cardiometabolic disease, and has potential to lead to new strategies for targeted prevention of cardiometabolic disease and reduce health disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Real-time spectroscopic photoacoustic/ultrasound (PAUS) scanner with simultaneous fluence and motion compensation to guide and validate interventions: system development and preclinical testing Narrative Real-time ultrasound (US) is commonly used to guide interventional procedures, but for injections of therapeutic agents such as ethanol, the drug itself cannot be directly visualized. Photoacoustics (PA), combining pulsed light delivery to the body with US detection of light absorbing structures within the body, has been proposed to bring a molecular dimension to US to help view molecular substances such as drugs, but its clinical translation has been greatly limited by both fundamental issues related to tissue motion and wavelength-dependent light intensity variations within the body and practical issues related to the size, speed, and expense of the laser systems typically used for imaging. Here we present a completely new approach integrating PA and US (PAUS) imaging to directly address both fundamental and practical issues limiting clinical translation, and will test it by developing and evaluating a clinical real-time PAUS system as a robust molecular guidance tool for interventional procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Hearing loss is largely irreversible because in most cases it involves the loss of cochlear hair cells, which in mammals are for the most part not generated past embryogenesis. As OHCs are much more vulnerable than IHCs, their loss due to age, noise or ototoxic drugs is the main cause of hearing loss, and hence the regeneration of OHCs will be most often needed to restore hearing. Our discovery of the central roles played by transcription factors INSM1, BCL11b and BCL11a in OHC development provides unique and novel means for elucidating how OHCs are generated and aligned, a knowledge that will guide and assist future therapeutic attempts via regeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative â Bupropion for the Prevention of Postpartum Smoking Relapse Postpartum smoking relapse affects the health of mothers and their children. Previous work suggests that bupropion may help prevent postpartum smoking relapse by targeting several relapse related risk factors prevalent in women during the postpartum period (e.g., smoking related symptomatology, weight gain, depressive symptoms). If our hypotheses are confirmed, the results from this work may be disseminated into clinical practice and will significantly impact the rate of postpartum smoking relapse, a major public health concern.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: HIV drug resistance (HIVDR) genotyping to determine the cause of antiretroviral therapy failure has long been established to improves patient outcomes and reduce HIV transmission, yet the persistent urgent and unmet need for resistance genotyping in low- and middle-income countries has not been met, thus prohibiting the appropriate allocation of subsequent HIV treatment options. This Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) program submission will commercialize the results of our Phase II SBIR where we leveraged the unique capabilities of PANDAA, our qPCR-enabling technology, to successfully develop the first diagnostic for simultaneous focused HIVDR genotyping of six resistance-conferring positions in the protease gene in addition to the K65R and M184VI DRMs. We will establish the regulatory and quality frameworks necessary to manufacture the associated product, a validated HIVDR that significantly reduces test complexity, time burden and costs without sacrificing accuracy, which can radically improve clinical decision-making in low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to investigate biological mechanisms behind the association between exposure to maternal psychological stress during the prenatal period and having increased risk for negative psychological outcomes in young children. Our long-term goals are to advance knowledge pertaining to early detection and prevention of these negative effects in young children. Through this proposal, we also aim to build research capacity and collaboration between South Africa and the U.S. to foster scientific discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Right ventricular failure (RVF) is a strong predictor of death for which there are no proven therapies and limited prior work investigating molecular mechanisms of RVF. This career development proposal will allow the candidate, a physician-scientist with a career objective to transition to an independent investigator of RVF biology, to examine a novel RVF-specific target that he identified by characterizing the human RVF gene expression signature. In this proposal, he will use complementary in vitro cardiomyocyte and in vivo RV gain and loss of function models to determine the mechanistic role of ROR2 in RVF pathogenesis, which could provide insight for novel RVF therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepcidin is the peptide hormone responsible for regulating circulating iron concentrations, making it clear target for diagnosis and monitoring of multiple hematological conditions. Next generation therapeutics capable of modulating serum hepcidin levels are under advanced clinical evaluation, and will likely require companion diagnostics to assess patient responsiveness and personalize dose ranges. Unfortunately, hepcidin has very low immunogenicity, making it extremely challenging to develop antibodies or immunoassays against the hormone. Using phage display biopanning and a proprietary sandwich assay format, Affinergy has developed a novel hepcidin-25 serological assay which will meet this urgently unmet need, impacting patients with a range of conditions including hereditary hemochromatosis and ï¢-thalassemia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will evaluate the individual and combined effects of high-intensity exercise and postural perturbations during treadmill training in people with multiple sclerosis. The effects of high-intensity treadmill training with postural perturbations on clinical and laboratory-based locomotor and balance outcomes, as well as changes in community mobility and participation will be demonstrated. This project meets a significant unmet need in the development of rehabilitation approaches in people with MS and has the potential for substantial public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to the increased lifespan of our population, problems linked to age-associated cognitive decline and neurodegeneration are becoming more important. It is recognized that many different molecular factors are at play in Alzheimerâs disease (AD) pathogenesis and dysregulations of these diverse molecules are not uniform throughout AD progress due to heterogeneity of the brain. However, most of the current studies involve homogenized tissues or biofluids without spatial information. To address this critical knowledge gap, this grant application seeks to create a region-specific biomolecule atlas of the AD brain of animal models and postmortem AD brain tissue using a suite of mass spectrometry imaging technologies in conjunction with machine-learning approaches. The proposed work offers a multifaceted approach and has strong translational potential that is highly relevant to human aging and human diseases.

PHR: Epilepsy is a devastating disorder that affects millions of people in the US alone. In this project we propose to study the cause of a certain type of seizure disorder mediated by high levels of a protein called UBE3A in the brain. We will use genetically modified fruit flies and mice to manipulate different types of cells in the brain that express this protein that is responsible for the seizures and then find the proteins involved in this type of epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Age, frequent exposure to loud noise, genetic disorders and more contribute to hearing loss, which affects half a billion people worldwide. In this proposal, we advocate for the use of the pig as a translational animal model to study non-invasive local drug delivery to the inner ear, given that the pigâs size, anatomy, and genetics is closer to humans than rodents. Using the pig as a large animal model will open translational opportunities to test new safe delivery approaches for hearing restoration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Millions of children are infected with the malaria parasite, and many die from cerebral malaria, partly because they lack antibodies to malaria. We will study antibodies to proteins from cells infected with malaria and on the parasites themselves, comparing findings in children with malaria infections that span the spectrum from asymptomatic to life-threatening cerebral malaria. We will undertake detailed antibody profiling and use advanced statistics to identify antibodies that protect against malaria, in the expectation that this might lead to new approaches to malaria prevention and treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Intestinal bacterial pathogens are a major cause of morbidity and mortality globally and a leading cause of death among children. The goals of this proposal are to understand how specific metabolites from bacteria regulate host epithelial cells to protect against intestinal bacterial infection. The outcomes of these studies will benefit human health because they will inform the design of new approaches for improving intestinal immunity to fight infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Even with reduced body burdens, human exposure to the highly toxic compound 2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzo-p- dioxin (TCDD) and other dioxin-like chemicals remain a public health concern, especially for vulnerable populations like infants. While most biological effects of TCDD are known to be mediated by the aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AHR), the identity of specific genes connecting AHR activation to toxic outcomes of TCDD exposure remains unknown. Here we propose to combine functional genomic experiments, computational modeling, and targeted epigenome editing to map AHR-mediated gene regulatory networks and predict TCDD-induced changes in gene expression in mouse vs. human liver and B cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Alzheimerâs disease (AD) is not exactly the same in women and in men, so that in order to design more effective surveillance, screening, preventive, and risk assessment programs, we need new methods that are sensitive and accurate enough to detect differences in how genetic variants are linked to AD risk in women and men. For this we propose a variety of new statistical and machine learning tools that will interpret the variants observed in human genomes from patients in light of the entire history of past evolutionary mutations and adaptations. The best candidate genes we find will then be tested experimentally in AD animal-models (mouse and Drosophila) to yield highly validated sex-specific predictors of AD status that could enable precise risk stratification, provide sex-specific biomarkers, highlight sex-differential disease mechanisms and reveal potential therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MicroRNAs are small non-coding RNAs that provide an important layer of gene regulation by negatively controlling the levels of a large fraction of protein coding genes. The research proposed in this grant application has three major goals. First, we want to determine the role of miRNA function during mammalian development, in tissue homeostasis, and during tissue regeneration. Second, we want to test whether that acute inhibition of miRNA function can serve as a novel and effective anticancer strategy. Finally, we want to understand what targets and pathways miRNAs control under these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance to Public Health Purinergic signaling (i.e., response to extracellular nucleotides) is involved in a wide variety of disease states and is the target of valuable therapeutic agents. While all organisms respond to extracellular ATP, many lack the canonical receptors found in animals; for example, plants possess unique, multifunctional plant purinoreceptors, P2K1 and P2K2. Through comparison, the research described will identify conserved, common components of purinergic signaling pathways, which may be additional targets for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 15% of two-year-olds are âlate talkers,â who have smaller vocabularies and learn different types of words as compared to typically developing peers, contributing to an increased risk for a language disorder. Because of the important role that verbs play in language development, this project explores whether differences exist between late talkers and their peers in how they learn new verbs and whether language processing abilities might predict success in verb-learning tasks. Results from this study will provide insight into how late talker language development differs from typical development and will support further research into interventions for those at greatest risk for language disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This decade has seen an explosive, devastating epidemic of opiate addiction in the U.S. Effective strategies to mitigate this epidemic must include both prevention (identifying addiction-prone individuals early and intervening effectively) and treatment, but few strategies for either currently exist. Using state of the art sequencing technology and robust rat models of heroin abuse and relapse, we ask how psychosocial stress early in life sex- dependently impacts gene expression networks to promote opioid use disorder (OUD)-like behavior, and potentially open new therapeutic avenues for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This project is an in-depth study on how phosphorothioate-base antisense oligonucleotides (PS- ASO) bind and are internalized by the scavenger receptors (Stabilin-1 and Stabilin-2). We will determine how these receptors internalize their ligands (including size select hyaluronan and custom synthetic heparin), what determines their escape from endosomes and associated molecules involved with cargo escape, and their pharmacokinetics through an animal model. The understanding of how these molecules are metabolized in mammalian systems will greatly aid the design and therapeutic use of such drugs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE An important signaling cue in regeneration is the endogenous bioelectric signal, in which electric fields (EFs) initiate a cascade of complex signaling events between cells in order to promote tissue regeneration. The proposed project aims to utilize multidisciplinary approaches to develop new tools in order to investigate the role of small extracellular vesicles (EVs) in transmitting the bioelectric signals by means of gene regulatory molecules between cells, and hence, promote neuroregeneration.

PHR: The overarching goal of the proposed Tisch Cancer Institute (TCI)-Mentored Medical Student Summer Scholar (TCI-MMSSS) Program is to inspire medical students to pursue careers in cancer research through engagement in an innovative, highly structured program of strongly mentored research projects and interactive curricular activities. Our program leverages institutional strengths in novel pedagogy and curricular innovation as well as the seasoned mentoring capacity and research expertise of the TCI Scientific Programs in Cancer Immunology, Cancer Mechanisms, Cancer Clinical Investigation, Cancer Prevention and Control, and Health Equity and Health Disparities. Our outstanding cadre of exceptional mentors, enthusiastic pool of diverse and compelling students and academically rigorous and innovative training environment will accelerate the development of the next generation of MD physician scientists committed to meaningful and clinically impactful cancer investigation.

PHR: Narrative Our proposed IRACDA program is a collaboration between the University of California at Santa Cruz (UCSC) and California State University at Monterey Bay (CSUMB), both Hispanic Serving Institutions in central California. The program aims to contribute to an increase in the number of underrepresented minorities in faculty positions in the biomedical field. UCSC postdoctoral scholars will receive rigorous research and teaching training by structured mentoring from UCSC and CSUMB mentors to ensure targeted career skill development; undergraduate STEM students at CSUMB will benefit from augmented mentoring by the IRACDA postdocs in classes and research settings, and by exposure to world class biomedical research.

PHR: This grant application will investigate how truncated O-glycans on oncogenic glycoproteins promote pancreatic cancer progression and metastasis. Specifically, it will elucidate the role of Core 1 Î²1, 3-Galactosyltransferase (C1GALT1) in aberrant glycosylation of membrane-bound mucins and cancer stem cell markers and induce the early onset of metastasis in pancreatic cancer. Success in this study can be translated clinically by developing therapeutics (glycopeptide vaccines), and quantitative evaluation of truncated carbohydrate antigens in pancreatic cancer tissue can predict disease severity and help better manage pancreatic cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Lyme disease remains an important public health issue. This work will identify the functional determinants of outer surface protein C, an essential virulence factor required for the ability of the Lyme disease spirochete to transmit from ticks and establish infection in mammals. The outcome of these analyses will enhance our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of pathogenesis for these important pathogens and provide information that can be exploited in the develop of improved preventive and therapeutic strategies for Lyme disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: CENTER OVERVIEW: PROJECT NARRATIVE This P30 renewal application from the Stanford Diabetes Research Center (SDRC) seeks support for its efforts to discover, apply and translate science about diabetes and it complications, with the goal of improving health by reducing the burden of diabetes. The SDRC was founded on a base of superb, collaborative investigators studying basic, clinical and translational problems in diabetes at Stanford University, which has a tradition and reputation for scientific innovation and clinical care, located in the heart of Silicon Valley, an epicenter of transformative discovery and calculated risk-taking. Renewal of this P30 application will leverage diabetes research at Stanford University by providing key resources to support Research Cores, maintain a highly successful SDRC Pilot and Feasibility Award Program, creation of a Regional Pilot and Feasibility Award program to foster innovative diabetes research at the University of California (UC) Berkeley and UC Davis, and Enrichment Programs focused on diabetes research, education and care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE In our groupâs CSER NYCKidSeq project, we found the diagnostic success rate for children with autism to be only ~25% despite performing whole genome sequencing. Our preliminary studies for the current proposal have revealed de novo variants in children with these conditions to be enriched in the cis-regulatory regions of glial and neuronal cells, near genes implicated in these phenotypes, defining candidate pathogenic non-coding variants. My project will test these de novo variants for their molecular regulatory and cellular effects, combining chromatin and transcriptional studies and neural cell characterization in GABAergic neurons edited to introduce these variants, the foundation for improving our ability to understand the genetic causes of children with autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dioxygen is natureâs most powerful oxidant. It is activated and used by a variety of enzymes, such as coupled copper-only or copper/iron metalloenzyme active sites, to perform a diverse range of essential oxidative processes. Redox active aromatic amino acids, such as tyrosine (Tyr) or tryptophan (Trp), can serve as the source of protons and/or electrons and may carry out different tasks in the overall enzymatic mechanisms and functions of many of these enzymes. This proposal aims to determine the governing factors associated with the diverse roles these Tyr/Trp side chains adopt in each enzyme.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative (2-3 sentence re: public health relevance) With an estimated 2.87 million TBI-related emergency department visits each year in the United States, and approximately 69.1% of children ages 6-12 participating in sports annually, there is an urgent public health need to identify the process by which mTBI and RHI can lead to neurological health problems later in life. Once this process and modifying factors are identified, a comprehensive approach can be employed to mitigate adverse long-term outcomes, such as preventative health behavior interventions and the development of therapeutic treatments. Given this, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH's mission to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative The study aims to utilize high content systems to identify novel therapeutics for the treatment of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), a devastating gastrointestinal disease of premature infants. Using a well-characterized human microphysiologic intestine-on-a-chip platform, we have developed preclinical models of NEC, using both organoids and a âNEC-on-a-chipâ model system derived from premature infant intestinal biopsies with patient- specific microbiota to recreate their cellular and microbial environment ex vivo. We will use these pre-clinical models of NEC as a neonatal gut-on-a-chip platform for high content drug testing and a precision medicine approach to this devastating disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic cancer has the lowest survival rates for any kind of cancer. The objective of this proposal is to understand the molecular basis by which RHAMMB promotes pancreatic cancer metastasis. PHR: Project narrative Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a debilitating, inflammatory skin disease with few effective therapies. There has been a lack of well-powered genetic studies of HS. In this proposal, we use large genetic datasets, novel bioinformatics methods, and cutting-edge functional assays to identify and characterize HS genetic variants, which may lead to the identification of new therapeutic pathways in HS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adoptive cell therapy (ACT) has demonstrated durable objective response in patients with solid tumors but has not been previously tested in patients with metastatic soft tissue sarcoma (mSTS). I will conduct a phase 1 trial of ACT in patients with mSTS where the safety of this regimen will be assessed as the primary endpoint and use tissue from this trial for laboratory investigations that evaluate the T-cell subsets responsible for tumor- specific activity and the genomic events of these tumors relative to the T-cell infiltration. I have also described career development goals that align with the scope of scientific work to ensure my successful transition from mentored junior faculty to independent surgeon-scientist with the ability to safely deliver clinical trials designed from my laboratory research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Women are dying from autoimmune disease at an alarming rate, and the National Institutes of Health identifies autoimmune disease as the top cause of morbidity among women in the United States. Current therapies for autoimmune diseases are dangerous and often ineffective, but development of new therapies is hampered by poor understanding of the mechanisms causing autoimmunity, including why women are so disproportionately affected. This project will define how the skin drives systemic autoimmune disease, identifying female-biased pathways and factors critical to autoimmunity in order to pave the way for new therapies to address this significant threat to public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the United States, with the major subtype being lung adenocarcinoma. The goal of our proposed research is to use genomic approaches to understand lung adenocarcinoma: how genome alterations in individual genes cause the disease, how we can find immunological targets, and how we can understand genome-wide structural alterations. I anticipate that the insights that we gain from this research could lead to new treatments for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Structural and mechanical deficiencies of the vaginal wall and supporting tissues are defining characteristics of pelvic organ prolapse, a common gynecologic condition. The aim of this study is to develop a mechanical and structural profile of vaginal tissue and use these parameters to inform design of a novel synthetic biomimetic graft for prolapse repair. We will perform experiments to phenotype the mechanical and structural properties of vaginal extracellular matrix, synthesize an elastomer-hydrogel graft that resembles healthy vaginal tissue, and examine cell attachment and differentiation on these grafts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to develop a pipeline to screen and prioritize libraries of potentially toxic man-made chemicals found in the environment for further analyses, with particular emphasis on per- and poly-fluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) of which there are over 5000 currently known. Current environmental exposure testing methods evaluate mammary gland development in live mice because the mammary gland is highly susceptible to chemical exposure; yet, such methods are slow and expensive. Our proposal uses mammary cell culture models in increasingly complex, tissue-like environments, in combination with high-speed 3D optical imaging techniques, and ultimately compare the platform with a few candidate PFAS against existing data in live mice, setting the stage for future high-throughput screening of potential environmental toxicants.

PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the clinical outcomes and episode spending of patients with lower extremity injuries treated at a verified trauma center in the State of Michigan. We will identify the structures and processes of care that are key to achieving high quality outcomes with lower costs in the treatment of these patients. The results will have the immediate impact of creating a feedback mechanism to the trauma centers to improve care as well as inform subsequent policy for trauma center verification guidelines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Ongoing gene therapy (GT) clinical trials employing AAV vectors to treat adult patients with hemophilia A (HA) have established the promise of GT for correcting hereditary bleeding disorders in adults, yet there are many advantages to offering these therapies early in life. The proposed studies will test the safety and efficacy of current GT approaches in the treatment of patients prior to birth and as neonates. If the advantage of this approach is unequivocally demonstrated, these patients could benefit from this important clinical option for treating genetic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Viral respiratory tract infections such as influenza and COVID-19 cause substantial suffering worldwide. Though screening diagnostics, which identify infected individuals quickly before they spread disease widely, are an effective containment strategy during outbreaks, no testing platform exists today that has the capacity to check hundreds of millions of people daily. This study aims to develop a novel screening diagnostic based on mass-manufacturable microscopic circuits that detect viruses, which will enable nimble widespread testing during future pandemics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The research proposed has significant relevance to public health because there are not many study systems to investigate the mechanisms underlying evolutionary genetic and phenotypic changes in host-parasite interactions. Parasitism by helminths (worms) is hypothesized to have driven population genetic changes in human, animal, and plant hosts, contributing to auto-immune pathologies and placing burdens on growth and development, but data obtained using a combination of evolutionary, genome-wide, and functional genetic approaches from genetically tractable host-parasite study systems is necessary to address this question. Thus, the research proposed pertains to NIGMS's research mission of understanding the principles, mechanisms, and processes that underlie living organisms, and NIHâs mission area of developing fundamental knowledge that will help to (1) sustainably reduce the burdens of parasitism and autoimmune pathologies and (2) advance our understanding of how selection shapes genetic and phenotypic variation in hosts and parasites over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE STATEMENT Thymus produces immune cells called as T-lymphocytes that are critical for protection against infections and cancers. However, with age, thymus is replaced with fat cells and its ability to produce T-cells is diminished. This research project will understand the effect of pro-longevity hormone FGF21 on rejuvenation of immune system of aged mice and to determine its mechanism of action in reducing inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Relevance Statement Adipose tissue physiology plays a central role in systemic energy homeostasis. We know that FGF21 expression in adipocytes exerts a profound positive effect on health- and lifespan. Here, we want to focus on FGF21-induced changes in adipose tissue that lead to systemic improvements in overall metabolic homeostasis. We will focus on immune-metabolic changes, how they translate into metabolomic and gene expression alterations, with a particular focus on the impact on leptin and adiponectin, and how these adipokines synergize and antagonize FGF21 action. Combined, this will delineate how a fat pad needs to be changed to exert o potently positive impact on health- and lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Several human illnesses such as chronic viral infection, cancer, autoimmunity, and neurodegenerative diseases are due to aberrant activation of innate immune responses and are associated with production of proinflammatory cytokines. We have identified a novel repressor complex composed of Capicua-Ataxin1 or 1L, which prevents aberrant expression of antiviral genes in the absence of virus infection; and, upon viral infection, this complex is rapidly degraded to turn on antiviral responses. Our proposed study will investigate the Capicua-Ataxin1 mediated regulation of innate immune responses in human cells and knock out mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Due to disparities in healthcare access, women in rural America and other low-resource settings worldwide are twice as likely to die from cervical cancer as their urban and high-resource counterparts. We will develop a paper- based sample-to-answer test that provides sensitive and specific detection of high-risk pre-cancer and invasive cervical cancer at the point-of-care. This test will enable rapid screening and reduce barriers to same-visit treatment, ultimately reducing cervical cancer disparities by saving the lives of patients whose disease would have otherwise be missed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Preventable, intraoperative technical errors harm 16,000 patients in the United States each year, resulting in neurologic injury, stroke, and other disabilities in up to 70% and death in up to 16% of affected patients. Without a systematic data source and method describing intraoperative actions, interventions to prevent intraoperative errors during neurosurgery cannot be rationally designed and implemented. The proposed research seeks to address this problem by constructing a clinical and video dataset of neurosurgical video and patient data, using advanced machine learning and computer vision techniques to âwatchâ recorded surgical video, automatically detect intraoperative actions, and predict upcoming adverse events using a model which integrates clinical data with surgeon movement metrics and visual features of the surgical field.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a new undergraduate research education program, NextGenPop, which aims to significantly increase the pipeline of scholars from underrepresented backgrounds entering the field of population science. It is a collaborative initiative that mobilizes five leading universities to train advanced undergraduate students in contemporary population research and demographic analysis though a brief but intensive summer residential program and ongoing remote and in-person follow-up. This effort will ultimately advance the body of demographic and public health knowledge to more fully reflect the diversity of human populations today.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The most common form of hearing loss is caused by the death of hair cells in the cochlea. Young mammals are capable of regenerating some hair cells, but this ability disappears by the time they are old enough to hear. In our proposal, we will use genetic reprogramming to drive cells of the inner ear to produce new hair cells, and to understand the mechanisms through which this reprogramming can happen in clinically-relevant conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because identification of the Parkinsonâs disease (PD) patients at a high-risk for developing dementia (PDD) is critical for better prognostication, correct identification of PDD in its prodromal stage to recruit in new disease-modifying clinical trials, and to better understand the pathophysiological processes underlining PDD. The proposed project identifies the best predictive biomarkers for PDD through examining the comprehensive Gaussian and non-Gaussian diffusion-MRI (dMRI)-derived white matter (WM) changes predicting PDD, examining the network-level discrepancies predicting PDD derived from dMRI-derived whole-brain structural connectivity and resting-state functional MRI (rsfMRI)-derived whole-brain functional connectivity, and developing a multivariate and multimodal statistical model by combining these sophisticated pathologically relevant neuroimaging measures with non-imaging measures such as clinical (disease duration and severity), demographics (age, sex, years of education), genetics (LRRK2), and CSF- measures (Î²-Amyloid, Î±-Synuclein, tau) to identify the best predictive biomarkers of PDD through machine learning approach. The machine learning algorithm developed in our proposal also has great potential for significantly advancing the understanding of other neurodegenerative disorders such as Alzheimerâs disease (AD) thereby helping to understand AD- and PD-specific neuroanatomical changes predicting dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV-1 infection causes chronic inflammation in HIV-infected persons who have high rates of substance abuse. This study will evaluate the role of cannabinoids in HIV-mediated inflammasome signaling in lymphoid tissue. This study will inform mechanisms of pathogenesis and novel therapeutic advances to improve the outcomes of HIV-infected persons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene editing technologies have progressed rapidly in humans and several efforts at clinical translation are ongoing. Recent experiments in translation in reproductive settings have emphasized the need for more values based and patient-centered governance mechanisms for translation of prenatal gene editing. We propose to conduct empirical and deliberative research to inform a governance structure that is in alignment with patient and clinician priorities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular differentiation is the process through which individual stem cells generate a multitude of cell types, each with distinct form and function. The proposed project aims to illuminate the mechanisms that drive differentiation through data-driven modeling of high-throughput single-cell data. A comprehensive understanding of such mechanisms will provide a basis to decipher the dysregulation in disease and significantly boost the potential of cell engineering to produce treatment-grade cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Molecular based blood tests provide an accessible and affordable option for screening high risk populations for many common cancers, leading to early detection with better outcomes. We propose to study the origins and molecular characteristics of cell-free DNA fragments in pre-neoplastic lung lesions and in treatable lung tumors with the aim of improving not only the ability to detect small early lesions, but also to identify which lesions are likely to progress to cancer. Through optimization of our molecular test in plasma, we plan to test and validate our approach in both accrued samples and a prospective lung cancer screening population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative Alterations in the nonspecific thalamus, a brain region crucial for consciousness, are recently implicated in the morphine effects and addictive disorders. Thus, resolving the mechanisms that regulate its activity is an important task in the pursuit of novel drug targets. This research proposal will provide the first comprehensive study on the role of T-type calcium channels in the nonspecific thalamus in the function of the morphine-mediated effects and opioid addiction, using ex vivo recordings of neuronal activity and behavioral experiments, coupled with a sophisticated genetic approach, thereby identifying these channels as a potential drug target for opioid use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse intrinsic pontine gliomas (DIPGs) are highly lethal pediatric brain tumors and a leading cause of cancer- related deaths in children. Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell immunotherapy has the potential to improve outcomes in adult and pediatric patients with brain tumors; however, CAR design must be optimized and carefully evaluated in DIPG mouse models that closely mimic human disease. In this study, we propose to enhance CAR Tâcell efficacy for DIPGs by optimizing the CAR co-stimulatory domain, silencing the negative T-cell regulators, and defining the inhibitory mechanisms in the DIPG tumor immune microenvironment that are activated by CAR Tâcell treatment.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE About 12% of reproductive aged women of all marital statuses in the US have impaired fecundity - with increasing age, ovulatory disorders, endometriosis, and tubal factor as leading causes. Those who conceive spontaneously or with fertility therapies are at increased risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes due mainly to implantation and placenta disorders. Our Center for Research, Innovation and Training in Reproduction and Infertility at UCSF brings together expertise in clinical medicine, basic and translational science, and advanced technologies focused on the inter-related roles of endometrial inflammation, epigenetics, and development as determinants of early pregnancy outcomes and provides a rich environment for trainees and outreach to the community about innovations in reproductive science and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental disorder with deficits in two core domains: social interaction and communication, and repetitive behaviors or restrictive behaviors. Mutations in many genes are associated with ASDs. This research project aims to discover a common pathophysiology induced by these mutations, which will provide invaluable information for development of effective therapies of ASD.

PHR: Project Narrative: Pancreatic cancer is highly lethal and current treatments such as chemotherapy and radiation are only minimally effective due to its profound therapeutic resistance. This proposal seeks to build on prior work from our group exploring metabolic dependencies in pancreatic cancer to understand how metabolic adaptations through cell autonomous and non-cell autonomous mechanisms are integrated to allow for continued growth in an austere tumor microenvironment. The results of these studies may have an important impact on the treatment of this disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a common disorder with a complex etiology that remains incompletely understood. In 2016, we demonstrated that in rodent models of T2D, normoglycemia can be restored for weeks or months in rodent models of T2D by central administration of fibroblast growth factor 1 (FGF1). With support from this program, insight into underlying mechanisms has grown considerably since then, and convergent findings point to a key role for AgRP neuron inhibition as a key mediator of FGF1 effects on both food intake and glucose metabolism. Proposed studies will investigate the roles played by distinct AgRP neurons projections and signaling molecules in FGF1-induced feeding and metabolic control, and identify mechanisms underlying sustained inhibition of these neurons by FGF1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: There is an urgent need to understand how diabetes and elevated blood sugar levels impacts health and risk of complications. This project aims to answer this question by using large-scale biobank data and genetic analyses to discover genes that increase risk and enhance the biological insights of complications of diabetes. Such insights into complications of diabetes may guide development of potential clinical predictors, strategies for prevention and novel drug targeted towards for treatment and prevention of risk of complications of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Systemic lupus erythematosus has been linked to excess preeclampsia in pregnancy and  preterm delivery, however promising preliminary data suggest that hydroxychloroquine may  protect pregnant women with lupus from these potentially catastrophic outcomes. This work  leverages three large population-based databases from around the world (United States, Israel,  and Sweden) with detailed prescription and clinical data to address threats to internal validity  common in pharmacoepidemiological studies such as confounding by indication and selection  bias while disentangling these outcomes from the effects of potential mediators such as  glucocorticoids and gestational diabetes. Finally, given that hydroxychloroquine is safe and  effective in pregnant women with lupus for managing their disease, we will work with patients  and providers to understand why pregnant women with lupus are either choosing not to use  this medication or are not being prescribed it in the first place.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research directly responds to calls from researchers, public health officials, and womenâs health advocates for new measures that better capture what individuals wanted for themselves before and after a pregnancy became a part of their lives. By producing a novel measure of post-conception pregnancy acceptability, we will expand our understanding of the links between the contexts in which pregnancy occurs and reproductive health outcomes. Ultimately, measures of pregnancy acceptability can be incorporated into epidemiologic surveillance of the USâs ability to meet its citizensâ reproductive needs in ways that intentionally center individualsâ lived experiences and inform development of more effective, evidence-based and person- centered interventions to improve reproductive health outcomes and equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the availability of effective mental health treatment, approximately 47% of Latinx adults with serious mental illness are not engaged in treatment. The main goal of this current study is to identify cultural and social factors contributing to mental health treatment hesitancy and engagement; culturally adapt a Motivational Interviewing treatment engagement intervention that is trauma informed and peer delivered for Latinx with SMI; and conduct a pilot study to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and engagement of target mechanisms associated with the culturally adapted intervention. The proposed project will provide the groundwork for an R01 to test the effectiveness of the intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Bacteriophage therapy is a promising new therapy for bacterial infections, including periprosthetic joint infection. The objective of this proposal is to determine how changes in Staphylococcus aureus wall teichoic acid glycosylation vary under different conditions and impact phage activity. This will contribute to our long-term goal to develop new treatment strategies for periprosthetic joint infection which includes an ongoing, independently funded FDA Phase II/III study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Our Research Program incorporates powerful combinations of mouse genetic models, pharmacology, patient- derived tumor models, and new developments in immuno-oncology to bring about tangible advances in cancer therapy and patient care. Specifically, we propose to build upon our success in developing effective treatments against specific subtypes of cancer and brain metastases by harnessing the power of the immune system to potentiate therapeutic strategies aimed to achieve long-term survival. The research we propose has the potential to significantly enhance response to therapy and decrease the development of therapeutic resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop a novel MRI-compatible robotic system for brain tumor biopsy and ablation. The proposed robotic system with an integrated MR imaging coil would enable in-bore real-time image-guided tumor biopsy and ablation. This platform would increase the targeting accuracy and safety of the procedures and reduce the procedure time to enable better patient care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the effectiveness of an online adaptation of a parenting program delivered in primary care for Hispanic youth in preventing/reducing depressive and anxiety symptoms as well as in reducing suicide behavior.
