The knowledge expected to be gained in this study has the potential to transform the way prevention programs aimed at promoting mental health are delivered in primary care settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Opioid addiction is a chronic, progressive disorder that has led to an epidemic of deaths due to overdose. The severity of the opioid withdrawal syndrome is a major disincentive for individuals to attempt to stop opioid use. Therefore, developing new methods of mitigating the opioid withdrawal syndrome will not only alleviate these severe symptoms but may assist addicts in making the decision to discontinue opioid abuse.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project explores the mechanisms by which streptococci produce endocarditis, a life-threatening infection of heart valves. It examines the complex interactions of these bacteria with sialoglycan sugars on host cells and proteins, and how these events are affected by the high flow conditions within the heart. This research will provide important scientific insights about how endocarditis is produced, and may lead to novel therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Mitochondria, commonly known as the âpowerhouses of the cell,â facilitate much of the energy production in cells, but how they respond to dynamic cellular cues is not fully understood. This proposal will test the hypothesis that phosphorylation constitutes an important regulatory mechanism in mitochondria. As kinases, the mediators of phosphorylation, are clinically relevant therapeutic targets, this project may reveal new pharmacological strategies to address mitochondrial dysfunction in human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in normal blood vessel function, or vascular homeostasis, are responsible for a variety of cardiovascular disorders that have a significant impact on public health, including atherosclerotic heart disease, cancer, high blood pressure, and septic shock, among others. This project focuses on a newly identified protein, Caskin2, that we have found to play an important role in regulating vascular homeostasis, at least in part through endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), a well-known regulator of blood vessel health. By determining Caskin2's mechanisms of action as well as its effects in models of different vascular diseases, these studies may ultimately lead to new treatments for numerous cardiovascular diseases that account for substantial death and suffering in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Animal studies have demonstrated that the regulation of food intake requires articulation among endogenous cannabinoids (ECs), fatty acid-binding proteins (FABPs), and a peroxisome proliferator- activated nuclear receptor (PPARa), but the macromolecular basis for appetite, satiety, and obesity is poorly understood. This project will probe the solution-state macromolecular structure and function of EC- FABP, EC-PPAR, and FABP-EC-PPAR complexes in vitro at near-physiological concentrations, determining affinities, metabolic fates, molecular binding interfaces, and conformational changes to test proposed mechanisms of EC metabolic signaling. Working as a team with research trainees, our work will help to understand health risks and design future therapies for heart disease, autoimmune disorders, and type-2 diabetes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) is a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) that is expressed on normal breast cells, where it regulates the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP) and calcium transport during lactation in order to coordinate maternal calcium and bone metabolism with calcium demand for milk production. This project will study how heterodimerization of the CaSR with the metabotropic GabaB receptors, GABBR1 and GABBR2, affects the ability of the CaSR to regulate PTHrP production and calcium transport into milk. These studies will advance the understanding of how the CaSR and the GabaB receptors affect the normal breast and have the potential to discover new ways to target the CaSR therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The muscle community at the University of Pennsylvania has established an outstanding training program in Muscle Biology and Muscle Disease, supported in part by the T32 mechanism. Members of the Penn community are known world-wide for excellence in muscle research, and this program facilitates collaborative training opportunities for predoctoral students and postdoctoral fellows. Our training program enables trainees to work in laboratories directed by principal investigators who are leaders in the study of the cell biology, genetics, physiology, and/or pathology of muscle.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: The lack of representation of samples from men of African ancestry (MAA) at preclinical and clinical research is believed to contribute to the higher incidence and mortality rates of prostate cancer among MAA. As cell lines are tools used to understand the biology of tumours from which they are derived as well as to develop theranostics, the under-representation of these need urgent rectifying. This project seeks to develop novel MAA cell lines that will aid in developing novel therapies from Jamaican natural products for MAA with PCa, a patient population with the highest incidence and worst mortality rates for PCa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative The misuse of both prescription and illegal opioids has led to a national crisis that affects public health and the economy. However, we have little understanding of the genes that contribute to prescription opioid use disorders. This application will combine a rodent model of oxycodone abuse with emerging genomics technologies to dissect the molecular mechanisms underlying the vulnerability to opioid addiction and to identify genes that can be targeted for novel therapeutics development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative â Overall Component Influenza is a major problem worldwide, and despite decades of research, many questions remain about the factors that affect transmission, particularly how various routes of infection contribute to transmission and disease severity. This U19 Project addresses a critical need to improve the understanding of influenza transmission in humans. To this end, our consortium of world-renowned virologists, immunologists, epidemiologists, aerosol scientists, computational fluid dynamic modelers, aerobiologists, and engineers is developing and applying state-of-the-art methods to examine transmission including the use of an experimental human transmission study and analytical models of bioaerosols.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study aims to decrease the burden of syphilis on vulnerable populations through implementation of an emergency department screening program that can be deployed in high-risk communities. This will have a huge potential impact on public health by decreasing complications of syphilis, interrupting the cycle of disease transmission and decreasing congenital syphilis. This work addresses NIH priorities to utilize implementation science to evaluate evidence-based practices for dissemination and implementation in real-world settings, as well as NIAID goals to develop innovative strategies to end the global epidemic of sexually transmitted infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Controlling platelet levels is central to management of various pathologies. Platelets develop from megakaryocytes in a bone marrow environment, the stiffness of which varies, with potential to generate mechanical constraints. Here, we propose an integrative approach to study specific megakaryocyte mechanobiological receptors, such as those termed Piezo proteins (called so from the Greek word for pressure), that sense the bone marrow matrix forces to control megakaryocyte adhesion and platelet biogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our knowledge of the full spectrum of genomic variation remains limited; this is particularly true of structural variation, which plays a highly important role in evolution, health, and disease. This proposed research will investigate the causes and consequences of structural variation focusing on three biomedically-relevant primate models. In addition to shedding new light onto disease pathogenesis, genome-wide comparisons across species will also provide novel insights into primate evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  Mobile genetic elements (transposons) are ubiquitous genetic elements capable of changing their physical location within the host DNA, thereby causing DNA damage and mutations, and interfering with the host genetic program. Animals have developed various defense strategies against transposons, including a sophisticated pathway that inhibits transposons in germ cells â the piRNA pathway, yet some tissues and developmental stages such as the early embryo appear to be relatively permissive to transposon activity. This proposal outlines a research program that aims to dissect the molecular mechanism of the piRNA pathway in germ cells and investigate the patterns and functional implications of transposon activity during development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Our genome wide association studies (GWAS) of childhood obesity have revealed key loci influencing risk for the trait, with the data increasingly pointing to central nervous system processes. However, at the individual locus level, GWAS only reports genomic signals associated with a given trait and not necessarily the precise localization of culprit effector genes. Given the need for `variant to gene mapping', we will utilize `3D Genomic' and CRISPR based screens in iPSC-derived neuronal cell types to pinpoint the causal gene(s) at each key childhood obesity GWAS-implicated locus.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment of renal osteodystrophy is impeded by the lack of practical and accurate tools to determine underlying bone turnover. Gold standard bone biopsy is not practical in the clinic for the vast majority of kidney disease patients and parathyroid hormone and bone alkaline phosphatase have insufficient accuracy for turnover type to safely and confidently guide treatment of renal osteodystrophy. In the present investigation, we will study a microRNA approach as a novel non-invasive biomarker of turnover for renal osteodystrophy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Osteoarthritis (OA), a multifactorial disease and understanding the complex pathophysiology of joint degeneration, knee and hip joint interactions, and the impact of gait biomechanics, are all critical to determine the mechanistic basis of hip OA. In this proposal subjects will be recruited for a longitudinal study (covering 5-8 year follow up) from our existing cohort and we will use novel, fully automated and translational methods to measure MRI-based measures of cartilage degeneration and determine the role of gait biomechanics on disease progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Dopamine plays a role in many processes ranging from movement and reward to the regulation of hormonal balance. This study will identify the site of D2- receptor dependent dendrodendritic dopamine transmission. Knowledge of how the activity of dopamine neurons is regulated by endogenous dopamine and the plasticity of this form of transmission will facilitate an understanding of the abuse liability of cocaine.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a critical need for clinical and epidemiological research to address the growing epidemic of noncommunicable eye disease among older adults in India, where blindness and vision impairment are the number one cause of years lived with disability in later life. This proposal builds on a longstanding partnership between the University of Michigan and Aravind Eye Care System (AECS) in South India. This multifaceted research capacity building program will provide graduate training in epidemiology to faculty at AECS, develop a supportive research ecosystem, and result in a long-term sustainable training program that will make vital contributions to vision research and to addressing the large burden of blindness and vision- related disability among older adults in India and beyond.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE The burden of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in the United States (US) is steadily increasing, in part due to the aging of the US population, increased prevalence of conditions such as diabetes, chronic kidney disease and the metabolic syndrome and the emergence of high-risk populations, i.e., racial/ethnic minorities such as African-Americans and Hispanics, and persons infected with HIV/AIDS. These increasing health needs underscore the importance of training basic scientists, clinical scientists and population scientists in an environment conducive to multidisciplinary team research in order to test more effective approaches to the prevention and treatment of hypertension and related vascular disease and other comorbidities. This Training Program addresses these goals, and is the only postdoctoral Training Program in the state of Alabama with a primary focus on hypertension and CVD.
PROJECT_TERMS: Cardiovascular Diseases;Hypertension
PROJECT_TITLE: Mechanisms of Hypertension and Cardiovascular Diseases
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: NHLBI Institutional Training Mechanism Study Section[NITM(JA)]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Impairment of goal-directed behavior (GDB), often labeled apathy, is the most common and disabling of the neuropsychiatric symptoms observed in behavioral variant frontotemporal degeneration (bvFTD). This study uses fMRI network analyses to investigate mechanisms in bvFTD by which degraded functional brain networks underlying GDB contribute to the syndrome of apathy. This type of study is necessary to develop more effective and targeted treatment for apathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The Yale Head and Neck SPORE is a team of clinical and laboratory researchers studying the problem of treatment resistance in head and neck cancer. Each of three projects brings a basic and clinical research leader together to study ways to overcome resistance to common therapies, such as cetuximab and cisplatin, as well as to find ways to make HPV-driven cancers more sensitive to immunotherapy. There are clinical trials to treat patients with HPV-negative and HPV-driven cancer before they go to surgery. The projects are supported by core facilities to provide administrative, pathology and statistical support, and there are funds to support new projects and new investigators.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: MAKERERE UNIVERSITY COLLEGE OF HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Africa is facing a triple burden of disease i.e. a high incidence of fatal infectious diseases, non- communicable diseases, and emerging epidemics (with pandemic potential). Addressing these will require a new thinking and approaches for generating and synthesizing evidence that can inform policy. Research training in LICs provides an avenue to build capacity for locally generated investigations aimed at preventing and controlling these diseases. Leveraging on existing infrastructure at Makerere University College of Sciences and international collaboration with Johns Hopkins University, we propose a plan for a comprehensive multi-disciplinary data science research-training program in Uganda.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major barrier to HIV cure is the presence of viral reservoirs, cells or tissues in the body where the virus can hide in an inactive state during treatment with antiretroviral medications. The kidney is a site of HIV infection, but it is unknown whether virus from the kidney is capable of reactivating in the absence of antiretroviral medications. This study will determine whether and how HIV can replicate and persist in the kidney, and whether HIV from the kidney can re-emerge in the urine or blood when antiretroviral medications are discontinued.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE A major challenge for improving the efficacy of EGFR targeted therapies (such as cetuximab) in HNSCC is to identify and address cellular mechanisms of therapeutic resistance. We have designed model systems at the molecular, cellular, and tumor levels to analyze cetuximab resistance and to test both antibody-based and small molecule-based therapeutic approaches that block this signaling axis. Combined with an analysis of cetuximab treated patient tumor samples, the overarching goal of this project is to evaluate mechanistically novel EGFR family-targeted treatments in preclinical models of HNSCC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative Head and neck cancers often mutate TP53 and CDKN2A, reducing G1/S checkpoints; this leads to resistance to some treatments, but creates tumor-specific vulnerabilities to drugs targeting G2/M checkpoints. We identified three drug combinations for which simultaneous application of two drugs targeting G2/M was much more active than either drug alone, with a lead combination showing strong efficacy and no toxicity in a mouse xenograft model for head and neck cancer. The project will establish the mechanism of drug combination effectiveness, identify response biomarkers, determine how various complements of TP53 and CDKN2A mutations affect response, and perform a clinical trial to assess combination drug activity in head and neck tumors in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative: Violence, substance use, sleep disturbances, and hypertension among women with HIV: A syndemic approach (VS2H2 Syndemic) Leveraging the resources of Womenâs Interagency HIV study and building on previous work related to the syndemic of substance abuse, violence, and HIV/AIDS, the objective of this proposal is to understand how syndemic factors longitudinally impact sleep disturbances and hypertension among women with HIV (WWH) who are confronting distinct social, neighborhood, and economic realities. We also seek to clarify the interaction, mediators, and directionality linking these multi-level syndemic factors and co-morbid health outcomes. The results of the study will generate important insights for policies and multi-sectoral interventions to alleviate social and health inequities among WWH both in the US and worldwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: NARRATIVE The number of head and neck cancers caused by the human papillomavirus are dramatically increasing, but current therapies can cause lifelong side effects, and patients with recurrent disease have few effective treatment options. We have identified that demethylation therapy increases immune response in these tumors, and that they are sensitive to demethylation dependent on expression of a cytidine deaminase, APOBEC3B, that ironically is required for survival of untreated cancer cells. In this project, we will conduct a trial and use trial samples to further determine if demethylation enhances response to immune checkpoint inhibitors as a new therapy for human papillomavirus-associated head and neck cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is one of the most common inherited childhood diseases, impacting 1 in 4,000 children born in the US (www.cff.org) and is caused by mutations of the CFTR protein that affect its 3-dimensional structure and function. While therapies now exist to treat the most common CFTR mutation, other common mutations do not respond to any of the drugs, so many CF patients are left without treatments. Through the development and use of new mass spectrometric methods, we aim to characterize the structural defects of CFTR variants that do not respond to current treatments and to understand the mechanisms of action of CF drugs to aid in the identification of new strategies of therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The urgent need for child neurology and epilepsy research focused on the low- and middle-income countries of Africa is illustrated by the genomic diversity of Africa, which exceeds the genomic diversity of the rest of the world combined, and the up-to-90% of children with epilepsy who remain undiagnosed and/or untreated in northern Nigeria. ABV will train a cadre of investigators from the six major cities of northern Nigeria, who long- term will form the first major child neurology and epilepsy research collaborative in Africa. Different levels of training designed to meet the needs of each junior investigator, ranging from a full-time training commitment to training to individual courses and focused mentoring, will be delivered.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative G protein-coupled receptors (GPCR) are therapeutic targets for complications that arise during pregnancy, including the regulation of labor. This project investigates how antibodies can be leveraged as tools to study fine details of GPCR signaling. Antibodies may provide new avenues to therapeutically target GPCRs in situations where high receptor subtype selectivity, specific tissue distribution, or extended circulation times are indicated, such as preeclampsia and other hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, and in assisted reproduction.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Ribonucleases are enzymes that act on RNAs to process them to their mature, functional form, or to degrade them when they are no longer needed by the cell. A newly discovered ribonuclease in the model microorganism, Bacillus subtilis, is the prototype for a large family of similar proteins that are found in many bacterial organisms. Elucidating the structure and function of this ribonuclease could lead to the design of antibiotics that inhibit this enzyme and thereby reduce bacterial virulence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Social disconnection peaks in middle and late life and leads to an increased risk of suicide, persistent suicidality, and poor response to psychosocial interventions. There is a critical need to develop a mechanistic understanding of the link between social disconnection and suicidality, identify biological targets, and address targets with scalable interventions. We propose a novel psychotherapy, Engage & Connect, aimed to improve functions of the Positive Valence System (PVS) that are impaired in suicidality through increased engagement in rewarding social activities. Our proposal applies state-of-the-art precision imaging methods and a novel social reward task to evaluate circuitry and behavioral changes in the PVS during Engage & Connect. Findings will inform our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the link between social disconnection and suicidality during treatment and guide personalization of psychotherapy to target individualsâ biological and clinical profiles.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Early Therapeutics Clinical Network (ETCTN) at The Ohio State University (OSU) will identify new agents  with promising laboratory studies and develop them into new drugs for the treatment of patients with advanced  cancer who have exhausted their treatment options. Physicians, nurses and research coordinators will carefully  monitor patients receiving these drugs to make sure that they are safe. Patients will also undergo sampling of  their blood and have their tumors biopsied. These tissues will be analyzed by modern methods to determine the  levels of the new drug in the bloodstream and test whether they are having the predicted effect on the cancer  cells. The aim of the clinical study may be to simply determine if the drug can be given safely (phase I) and in  other instances the goal of the study will be to see whether the new drug or drug combination can shrink the  tumor and enable the patient to live longer. The consortium will consist of OSU, the University of Kentucky and the University of Utah in order to bring the evaluation of novel agents to three states with a high burden of cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: This proposal seeks to investigate the extent, location, and mechanisms that give rise to new enteric neurons and glia, paving the way for a novel therapeutic strategy in congenital and acquired neuro-intestinal disease. This proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the mechanisms by which the enteric nervous system responds to injury is expected to result in identification of biomarkers and potential targets for intervention. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to develop fundamental knowledge that will enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability; in particular, our research pertains to understanding the causes, diagnosis, prevention, and cure of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative: Chronic inflammation, especially in middle age, may contribute to impaired brain function in depression by promoting the synthesis and entry into the brain of toxic, intermediary molecules known as kynurenines. Reducing the entry of kynurenines into the brain may reverse their toxic effects on the brain and behavior in depressed patients, while ultimately preventing long term consequences including neurodegeneration and dementia. In this study, we will examine if blocking the entry of kynurenines into the brain with the amino acid leucine will reduce brain toxicity and improve depressive symptoms in patients with midlife depression and chronic inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use studies in patient samples and in innovative preclinical models to delineate how clonal evolution contributes to malignancy and to the response to cancer therapies. We will model clonal evolution using novel in vivo preclinical models and perform functional studies to delineate the key networks and targets which govern malignancy. This work will delineate how mutational evolution contributes to cancer initiation and progression and use these insights to identify novel therapeutic targets which can intercept/prevent or attenuate malignancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hypersomnolence is the most common symptom encountered in the practice of sleep medicine, with population-based prevalence of hypersomnolence disorder estimates of 1.5% and large socioeconomical impact. The biophysical causes of hypersomnolence and how it reflects on sleep brain dynamics are not known, resulting in the absence of robust electrophysiological diagnostic criteria. Here we will leverage a highly specific hypersomnia dataset and advanced analytical techniques to identify biomarkers of hypersomnolence in the space-time dynamics of sleep oscillations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Aging of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) contributes to age-related blood diseases such as clonal hematopoiesis, myelodysplastic syndromes or acute myeloid leukemia, however, whether the aged bone marrow microenvironment drives the aging of HSCs and age-related hematologic diseases and the underlying mechanisms, remain unclear. Our preliminary data suggest that nociceptive innervation in the bone marrow is essential for controlling HSC aging, and that aged bone marrow microenvironment promotes the clonal expansion of genetically mutated HSCs over wildtype HSCs. The proposed studies will shed new light on the contributions of the aged microenvironment on HSC function, and will help to devise new therapeutic strategies to prevent or improve the course of age-associated hematologic diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plasmodium falciparum antigenic diversity is a major obstacle to vaccine development and contributes to the low observed efficacy in Phase III trials of the first licensed malaria vaccine. In this study, we propose to leverage our high resolution epidemiological and entomological longitudinal cohort, coupled with cutting edge human and parasite genetic techniques, to observe discrete, multi-strain transmission events and record strain-specific and strain-transcendent immune responses associated with protection. By elucidating a minimum set of antigenic variants able to confer robust, strain-transcendent protection, we will facilitate the development and delivery of the next generation of P. falciparum vaccines.

PHR: There is an urgent need to curb the emergence of novel SARS-CoV-2 variants. This proposal will provide insights into the frequency, risk factors, clinical presentations and viral features of persistent SARS-CoV-2 infections using an integrated research approach combining virology, immunology, bioinformatics, and genomics. This knowledge will allow the implementation of strategies suitable to prevent prolonged SARS-CoV-2 replication and limit the spread of neutralization-resistant viral variants in vulnerable patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regenerative treatments for patients suffering from heart failure could be enabled by comprehensive understanding of the cellular factors that facilitate successful cardiomyocyte regeneration. Here, we investigate the role of two proteins, Llgl1 and Shroom3, that influence establishment of proper cytoarchitecture and cell-cell junctions in CMs. The proposed studies will provide critical insight into the cellular mechanisms by which cardiomyocytes can enter a regenerative state and then re-integrate and contribute to a functional myocardium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The sum of cell fate decisions for all of organismâs hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), together with the lineage specifications of progenitor/precursor cells, determines the quality and quantity of its hematopoietic activity. Increasing evidence has shown that cellular metabolisms play important roles in HSC self-renewal, but precisely how specific modes of metabolism steer HSC fate remains unclear. This project utilizes genetic models, metabolic assessments, and single-cell approaches to elucidate the metabolic cues coordinating HSC fate decisions, with a focus on lipid metabolism. The resulting insights into the metabolic requirements of hematopoietic homeostasis will have a major impact on HSC research as well as current clinical practice and the treatment of hematological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Listeria monocytogenes is a model intracellular bacterial pathogen that uses actin-based motility to spread cell to cell and disseminate within the host. During intracellular infection, bacteria form long pseudopodia-like protrusions that extend from the infected cell and are taken up by neighboring host cells, facilitating direct cell- to-cell spread. The focus of the proposed studies is to determine the spatiotemporal requirement of Abi1, a host cell protein that localizes to L. monocytogenes-induced protrusions, for protrusion formation and cell-to- cell spread.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Retinoblastoma is an eye cancer that forms in the developing retina of young children; it is unique in that it cannot be directly biopsied, making tumor tissue unavailable. As a result, there is a lack of understanding of the association between the clinical behavior of this cancer and the mechanisms that drive its behavior. Thus, we propose to use a liquid biopsy of the eye aqueous humor for molecular characterization and prognostic biomarker validation of this cancer to help the design of future clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: NARRATIVE. Intradialytic hypotension and cardiac events are common in patients on maintenance hemodialysis and accurate prediction remains a challenge; leading to under-utilization of therapies. Electrocardiograms have rich waveform data and including them in predictive models can improve accuracy and clinical actionability. In this proposal, we examine the utility of deep and transfer learning using electrocardiogram waveform data for prediction of key cardiac outcomes in patients on hemodialysis, which will lead to new paradigms in clinical management of this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) is reaching epidemic proportions throughout the world and is a major burden to healthcare systems and societies worldwide. The objective of this proposal is to explore the novel hypothesis that geranylgeranyl isoprenoids and hepatic Rap1a regulate plasma low-density lipoprotein levels and contributes to the CVD development. Successful completion of these studies will reveal a new mechanism involved in the regulation of cholesterol homeostasis and may offer new therapeutic targets for hyperlipidemia-driven CVD.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes is the second leading cause of deaths after TB in South Africa and increases the risk of developing TB. The functions of IGF-1 in metabolism, genetics, and immunity in TB and TB/T2DM has not been studies comprehensively. Using advanced training in immunometabolism and immunogenetics this project will define the associations of IGF-1/IGF-1R in patients and assess an IGF-1R inhibitor as adjunctive therapy in vivo, to enhance our understanding of IGF-1 signaling in TB, T2DM and TB/T2DM comorbidity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brown adipocytes consume nutrient substrates to produce heat and increase energy expenditure, representing a potential therapeutic target to counteract human obesity. Mitochondria are central metabolic hubs and dynamically remodel their subcellular networks and membrane architectures to meet distinct metabolic demands. This proposal will elucidate the role of a novel mitochondrial inner membrane protein FAM210A in the regulation of mitochondrial cristae remodeling and brown adipocyte thermogenesis, and thus unravel an important signaling pathway that integrates mitochondrial biology into metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: A newly identified immune evasion mechanism has recently been described in Plasmodium vivax isolates from South-East Asia and concerns the gene amplification of the vaccine target PvDBP, raising the concern that implementation of a PvDBP vaccine may select for multi-pvdbp copy parasites. Through a combination of serological analysis of individuals living in malaria endemic areas of Ethiopia and Cambodia enrolled in a longitudinal cohort, rigorous in vitro phenotyping, and state-of-the-art genomic analysis, we propose here to determine the extent, dynamics and mechanisms of immune evasion conferred by PvDBP gene amplification. Our studies will provide a unique perspective on this newly described immune evasion strategy and will provide immediately-relevant information on how likely pvdbp amplification will compromise a PvDBP vaccine strategy and how to overcome it.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Apathy, defined as lack of enthusiasm or concern for previously exciting or interesting things, is a very common, debilitating, often refractory symptom, and is associated with poor outcomes in neurologic and psychiatric diseases. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), a form of non-invasive brain stimulation, is effective in treating depression but has had limited study in apathy. The current study will use a motivated behavioral task and electroencephalography (EEG) to investigate the use of TMS using Parkinsonâs disease as a disease model of apathy, which will have implications across neurologic and psychiatric diagnoses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Very little is known about the food and beverage-related environments that adolescents experience on their smartphones. We have developed a novel method for capturing everything that appears on smartphone screens. This study will provide the first comprehensive description of the food and beverage environment that adolescents experience on their smartphones and its relationships to their dietary intakes, setting the foundation for precision nutrition interventions and evidence-based policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Biomedical science increasingly relies upon sophisticated statistical methods to draw conclusions about biological processes and health outcomes. The aim of this proposal is to train the next generation of biomedical and neuroscience researchers to identify and avoid common pitfalls in designing and analyzing data, by developing three education units intended to be included in a larger curriculum. In particular, we will address the following three core issues: changing one's approach midway through a study, accounting for gaps in the scientific literature that arise from selectively publishing successful trials, and learning to question statistical analyses from a study.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to investigate an important and common class of cancer associated genetic lesions in which cancer driver genes (oncogenes) are amplified as part of circular extra-chromosomal DNA molecules (ecDNAs). There is substantial evidence that ecDNAs are involved in cancer pathogenesis, but progress in the field has been limited by the lack of effective means to induce the formation of specific ecDNAs model organisms. To address this important limitation, we have developed a novel strategy that we will use to study the biology of ecDNAs in normal and cancer cells, and to study their ability to promote cancer formation in genetically engineered mice.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome-Like, WASL, is a multifaceted cellular protein with essential roles in the regulation of cytoplasmic F-actin dynamics impacting cell invasiveness, migration, and cell responses to the environment. Additionally, WASL has unexpected functions in the nucleus where it acts to promote and shape transcription and differentiation. We have uncovered a surprising, and previously altogether undescribed role for WASL in regulation of skeletal growth and pattern that is conserved among vertebrates. Characterization of WASL signaling in development will reveal core regulation of patterning and differentiation during development.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Persistent low-level viremia (LLV) in persons with HIV who are on antiretroviral therapy (ART) is a barrier to achieving the goal of zero transmission and eradication of HIV, but not much is known about the impact of LLV on attaining the ART goal of viral suppression in West Africa. The proposed research will use pharmacoepidemiologic methods to assess the prevalence of LLV and impact on ART outcomes. The study will also use mathematical modeling to predict future LLV with adherence to ART measured by innovative pharmacological techniques.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mental and oral health co-morbidities associated with HIV and lifelong treatment could be driven by biological processes, including microbiota- or aging-mediated mechanisms. A better understanding of how these mechanisms contribute to neurocognitive impairments and oral conditions is needed to support interventions, particularly in adolescence. This proposal focuses on identifying oral microbial taxonomic and functional features, and epigenetic aging markers associated with neurocognition and oral health in adolescents with HIV.

PHR: Narrative Previous evidence regarding the efficacy of photobiomodulation (PBM) in the treatment of temporomandibular disorder (TMD) is inconclusive due to methodological weaknesses. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stroke prevention guidelines state that âan ideal stroke risk assessment tool that is simple, is widely applicable and accepted, and takes into account the effects of multiple risk factors does not exist.â We propose to address this gap by aggregating and harmonizing existing patient-level data collected as part of longitudinal cohort studies supported by the NINDS and NHLBI. We will extend the advanced machine learning techniques developed as part of our currently funded NIH BD2K award to develop and validate new risk prediction models for stroke and compare their performance to existing and simpler tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Considerable advancements have been made in the field of molecular biology by combining the knowledge base of multiple scientific disciplines in order to understand the structure, function, and relationships between nucleic acids and proteins. The overall goal of the SHaping of Authentic Practices by Engaging in Modeling of A Topic with Teachers to Explore Research in Science (SHAPE MATTERS) project is to engage high school biology and chemistry teachers in a rigorous professional development experience that will enable them to incorporate some of these advancements into their curriculum. From this, secondary science curriculum will be developed that is centered on authentic scientific practices, and the secondary students will showcase their learning with 3-D models and molecular stories in a community-based symposium event.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Several blood cancers arise during aging (including myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML)) in a process that progressively alters adult blood-forming stem cells. Molecular alterations that separate healthy aged stem cells from stem cells developing cancer, are vastly unknown, but hold the key for curative therapies. We will be the first to investigate the contribution of a highly specific form of autophagy (âself- eatingâ), which is the cellsâ waste and recycling system, to blood cancer formation and therapy resistance. Our study may provide a new therapeutic avenue for patients with MDS and AML, and potentially a paradigm for other currently incurable stem cell-derived cancers.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pool of primordial follicles present at birth represents the total population of oocytes available to a female during her entire reproductive life. Research proposed in this application will elucidate insulin signaling mechanisms regulating primordial folllicle formation. This research will make a fundamental contribution to the understanding of the establishment of the primordial follicle pool and shed light on female reproductive issues such as primary ovarian insufficiency, reproductive aging, menopause, and ovarian cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to develop a photoelectrochemistry-enabled multi-utility LOC system for sensing and actuation, namely the âoptoelectronic micro-gadgetâ (OMG). The study will pioneer a design, simulation, implementation, and validation of a mechanically flexible photoelectrode paired with an intensity-modulated illumination source to generate photocurrents for probing and manipulating the local environment in the biosystem at a cellular or sub-cellular dimension scale. The proposed research is relevant to public health because the envisioned system could enable bi-directional engineering technologies in biomedical investigation with minimized resources, improved efficiency, customizable operational modalities, and enhanced opportunities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Narrative  Severe muscle injury such as volumetric muscle loss (VML) can greatly compromise physical function and quality of life. This project aims to develop a novel piezoelectric scaffold that can actively recruit endogenous muscle cells by generating electrical signals upon ultrasound stimulation. Both in vitro and in vivo studies have been designed to evaluate the ability of ultrasound-stimulated piezoelectric scaffolds to restore muscle function following VML injuries and to provide insights into future bioactive tissue scaffold design.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: We have identified a novel PLCG2 splice variant that is increased in human brain by a polymorphism that is associated with the risk of Alzheimerâs disease. In this proposal, we will confirm these preliminary findings, test whether the PLCG2 isoform generates a stable and functional PLCG2 protein, and identify splicing modulators that improve PLCG2 splicing to reduce AD risk. Overall, this proposal will provide quantitative insights into PLCG2 expression relative to AD risk, test the role of splicing in PLCG2, and begin to translate our findings into a potential pharmacologic approach.

PHR: Project Narrative  Brucella spp. are bacteria that cause a debilitating, flu-like disease in humans, and these bacteria are classified as Select Agents due to their potential use as biological weapons. The proposed research will define a quorum sensing pathway in Brucella that may be targeted for vaccine and/or therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative  The neglect of children and adolescents is prevalent and imperils health and well-being throughout the lifespan. This project involves the careful conceptualization, development, and initial validation of a multidimensional youth self-reported measure of adolescent neglect, conceptualized as unmet adolescent needs (versus parental omission). The measure will make it possible for future research to rigorously study adolescent neglect and will provide the necessary conceptual foundation for effective intervention.

PHR: Project Narrative Public Health Relevance: The proposed research project will explore the utility of terahertz time-domain spectroscopic imaging to measure and map corneal hydration gradients. Patients afflicted with several corneal diseases experience perturbation to corneal hydration levels and its opacity, which in turn can impact vision acuity. Early detection and monitoring of such diseases is key to successful treatment, yet the sensitivity and specificity of clinical techniques are insufficient to provide diagnosis at the early stages.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: African Americans bear a disproportionate brunt of pancreatic cancer (PDAC) and both the incidence and mortality of PDAC are higher amongst them. Better understanding of the causes of these disparities will help develop novel strategies to address them and thus achieve racial health equality. In the current grant proposal, we will evaluate the differences in the mutational and transcriptional landscape between the PDAC in African American and Caucasians and will evaluate the contribution these differences to the disparities in pancreatic cancer incidence and outcomes between African Americans and Caucasians.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to understand the control mechanism underlying functional dynamics using cutting-edge manifold, control theory, and machine learning technologies. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative: Fentanyl and fentanyl analogs are involved in more than half of all drug overdose deaths, a statistic that has continued to rise over the last decade. However, the molecular mechanisms of neuroadaptations induced by such potent synthetic opioids are vastly understudied in the addiction field. This proposal will address that critical barrier by providing insight into both the immediate and long-lasting molecular consequences of fentanyl exposure on brain microRNA pathways and blood microRNA expression for biomarker analysis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Osteogenesis imperfecta is a rare disease related to defects in collagen type I - the most abundant component of bone - that are caused by mutations in several genes, including TMEM38B encoding TRIC-B, a potassium channel present in the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum, the intracellular organelle where collagen type I is synthesized. Little is known about the skeletal consequences of mutations in TRIC-B and no cure is available for osteogenesis imperfecta. In this project we aim to clarify the effect of mutant TRIC-B in the function of the osteoblasts, the bone forming cells, and on bone fragility to identify a target for therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE SARS-CoV-2 remains a threat due to continuously evolving new variants, and fully vaccinated people remain susceptible to infection by the newer variants of the virus. SARS-Cov-2 can infect cells including oral epithelial cells via ACE2-independent alternative receptors, and infection via alternative receptors (e.g. CD147) is resistant to anti-spike RBD, which is the target for several SARS-CoV-2 vaccines to block ACE2 binding. Our studies will address the role of alternative in SARS-CoV-2 infection and virus-mediated immune activation in region-specific oral epithelial cells and tissues. It is critical to understand the role of alternative receptors for SARS-CoV-2 in the oral mucosa, the potential portal of SARS-CoV-2 entry, to develop anti-viral therapeutics and strategies to dampen virus-mediated immune activation and disease outcomes, especially as regards emerging immune escape variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Asymptomatic infections are a main source of malaria transmission and a crucial challenge to elimination. In the frame of a cluster-randomized trial of spatial repellents in western Kenya, we will screen blood samples collected across three time points by qPCR to determine changes in prevalence of infection. We will compare parasite and gametocyte prevalence and density to vector density and sporozoite rates to determine changes in transmission. The proposed project will determine whether spatial repellents can reduce the asymptomatic reservoir of infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed studies will determine the extent to which aging of the colon in mice is associated with deficiency in cGMP signaling. It will test the ability of cGMP-elevating agents to normalize homeostasis, slow transit, barrier dysfunction and inflammation, that characterize intestinal pathology of aged mice. The project will also determine whether intestinal organoids from aged mice are a suitable model to interrogate mechanisms of aging in the gut.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Ubiquitous microbial surface fibers called type 4 pili are required for some bacteria that cause serious and potentially fatal disease for initial infection and subsequent illness. A molecular machine powered by an enzyme that converts chemical into mechanical energy extends and retracts these fibers, but how that machine works is not well understood. We will gain insight into the function of the enzyme by studying its structure and function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Children affected by substance misuse are a vulnerable and underserved population of youth. Supporting their healthy growth and development is of utmost importance. The proposed evaluation of a web-based training for mentoring program staff members and mentors working with substance misuse-affected youth (SMAY) fills an important gap in service needs for the field of mentoring. Mentor training has been shown to support the development of close, long-lasting mentoring relationships; however, few training resources specific to issues relevant to mentoring substance-misuse affected youth exist. The main purpose of this project is to evaluate Substance of Change: Building Assets in Mentees Affected by Substance Misuse (SOC), an interactive, multimedia, webâbased, asynchronous training for mentors and staff working with SMAY to determine its effects on mentor and staff outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative Airway stenosis resulting from various reasons including but not limited to endotracheal intubation, tracheostomy, autoimmune diseases and infection is challenging to treat because prolonged intubation often leads to high risk of respiratory and vocal dysfunction. This project aims to quantify improvements in wound healing and tissue biomechanics for airway stenosis using a novel dose-controllable, injectable therapeutic delivery loaded with corticosteroid and antimicrobial. The long-term goal of this research is to develop a platform to optimize wound healing of the airway through novel drug delivery approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) and subsequent glutamate excitoxicity can trigger a sequence of pathological changes that lead to post-traumatic epilepsy (PTE) with a delay that can be weeks to months after the initial injury, and this long latency presumably provides an opportunity to develop treatments that prevent PTE, but no such treatment exists. As clavulanic acid is already FDA approved for human use, positive data from our proposed studies may be rapidly translated to further development of this post-TBI treatment strategy, and to human trials. Beyond post-traumatic epilepsy, enhancement of glutamate transport may also prove useful following various other forms of brain injury, such as stroke or infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is an important locus in several neurological conditions. The classical mouse mutation meander tail reveals a compartmentation boundary between anterior and posterior lobes of the cerebellum but has resisted efforts at molecular identification for nearly 50 years. This application proposes to close this gap in knowledge using recent developments in genomic technologies to identify two meander tail mutations and their molecular consequences during brain development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a prevalent cause of heart failure and death, yet there are only a few approaches to its treatment and none based on reversing underlying disease mechanisms. This proposal evaluates the therapeutic potential of a novel signaling pathway discovered from genetic screening using human in vitro and mouse in vivo models of DCM. The proposed studies provide confirmation needed for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. This program provides new insight into a recently discovered primary metabolic pathway in bacteria, sphingolipid biosynthesis, which appears to bridge fatty acid biosynthesis in pathogenic bacterial species. Structural data developed from this program will provide critically needed information to understand the mode and mechanisms of protein â¢ protein interactivity that enable the progression of this pathway in pathogenic bacteria. While bacterial fatty acid biosynthesis is a validated antibiotic drug target, this discovery and data obtained from this program will serve as a critical next step towards understanding the fundamentals of associated lipid metabolism within bacterial pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Synapse loss caused by the accumulation of pathological tau is likely responsible for cognitive decline in Alzheimerâs disease. Within the central nervous system, the complement system (and specifically complement component C1q) coordinates the phagocytic removal of synapses by microglia, however the exact mechanisms by which the complement system can differentiate between healthy synapses and those needing pruning is currently unknown. The goal of this application is to determine the molecular mechanisms that coordinate the synaptic deposition of complement C1q in a model of tauopathy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Exposure to burn pits are a public health threat to those in the Armed Forces who are serving or have served in the Middle East and Africa. Our studies investigate the acute and chronic effects of exposure on lung health in studies of a mouse model that closely mimics the human exposure to burn pit toxicants, particularly the immune responses and the changes in the lung microenvironment that impact on the response. Our goal is to understand the critical pathways of the immune response that regulate the changes that occur during multiple compared to single acute exposure, with the expectation that mechanisms of lung resiliency and a therapeutically targetable pathway will emerge and will prove useful in modulating lung disease due to burn pit toxicants and to other environmental exposures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disorders of gut-brain interaction (DGBI, former known as functional abdominal pain disorders) like irritable bowel syndrome are highly prevalent worldwide in children and adults and are associated with significant morbidity like increased psychological distress (e.g., anxiety and depression) and impaired health-related quality of life. Based on clinical trials demonstrating consistent efficacy of psychological therapies especially when delivered remotely, we developed a patient-centered guided imagery therapy mobile application (GIT App) to treat children with DGBI; however, insight about how to implement such a therapeutic mobile app within pediatric clinics is unclear. Utilizing implementation science methodologies, this proposal aims to identify local clinic personnelâs perspectives about their perceived barriers and inherent facilitators that may impact the implementation of our GIT App intervention in pediatric clinics to ultimately increase access to an optimal psychological therapy and improve health outcomes for pediatric patients with DGBI.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The placenta is an essential organ for healthy maternal-fetal outcomes. However, molecular mechanisms of placental dysfunction in obstetric disorders are not well understood. We will conduct statistical analysis on data from observations of placental tissue (metabolites, proteins, transcript RNA, and histopathology), together with clinical data from patients' charts. This study of the underlying mechanisms of placental health and disease aims to find and help prioritize new areas of research for improving obstetric outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The translational gene therapy ecosystem faces several interrelated challenges: 1) obtaining sufficient evidence of safety/efficacy from clinical trials to justify regulatory approval of new gene therapies to treat inherited diseases, various cancers, and other complex diseases; 2) establishing cost and payer coverage policies so patients have access to affordable treatments; and 3) generating sufficient safety and effectiveness evidence of approved gene therapies when used in the clinical setting. The project will develop recommendations and issue/policy briefs to help stakeholders in the translational gene therapy ecosystem in their deliberations and decision-making about addressing gene therapy challenges and associated ethical and policy issues and to identify ethical and policy issues within the translational gene therapy ecosystem that warrant additional normative and empirical investigation by various stakeholders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric nonadherence to medication is a significant public health problem, and rigorous research repeatedly documents that nonadherence increases risk for hospitalization, healthcare cost, disease progression, and death. Our preliminary data documents that 93% of parents experience barrier(s) to medication administration. The goal of this study is to test the effectiveness of MedSupport, a novel multi-level intervention designed so address root barriers to pediatric medication adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While effective at suppressing HIV replication, current antiretroviral therapy (ART) does not eliminate the persistent HIV reservoir nor prevent HIV gene expression from âactiveâ reservoir cells, which can result in low- level chronic inflammation. This may be particularly problematic in aged people with HIV, who exhibit additional low-level inflammation due to the aging process itself. Here, using blood and tissue specimens from aged ART- treated men and women with HIV, we propose to characterize the phenotypic and transcriptional features of âactiveâ reservoir cells, to study the mechanisms by which ongoing HIV gene expression can promote viral persistence and chronic inflammation, and to identify and test novel drugs that prevent ongoing HIV gene expression.

Those that establish biofilms on and around implants such as catheters and joint replacements are particularly problematic. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative While the cellular causes of autism spectrum disorder and related neurodevelopmental disorders are unknown, several rare genetic variants correlate with its pathogenesis, including those resulting in either increased or decreased expression or function of proteins coded for by UBE3A. In this proposal we follow up on our discovery that in neurons, Ube3a associates with Golgi satellites (GSats), small mobile organelles that share many properties with the Golgi apparatus. Our goals are to determine how the association of UBE3A proteins with GSats alters the ability of GSats to regulate synaptic properties that are dysregulated in neurodevelopmental disorders.

In this proposal, we examine the pathway utilized by Neuromedin-U in restricting bone formation to inform and enable better strategies for future translational research.

PHR: Project Narrative This project is relevant to public health because it proposes a new strategy to treat prenatal and postnatal neurodevelopmental deficits in pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, one of the most common mitochondrial disorders in humans. Promising results from this project might transform patient care because available treatments are only prescribed after birth, which is too late to treat brain developmental abnormalities that occur in utero. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: NARRATIVE The ever-growing size of the aging population urges the identification of cell types and genetic programs that can be tapped into to treat age-related conditions. Here, we will leverage the power of the pioneering organism C. elegans to follow up on our exciting discovery that an anion channel expressed in glia controls aging. The functions of this channel and the cell types and genes involved will be deciphered using a multipronged approach. This work will expand our understanding of aging and may identify novel targets for the treatment of age-related diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The severe shortage of mental health clinicians plays a crucial role in the unmet need for alcohol use disorder treatment, creating an urgent and critical public health issue in the United States. To mitigate the clinician shortage problem, Congress has significantly expanded the National Health Service Corps (NHSC) since 2009, which is the largest public policy intervention to attract clinicians to practice in mental health professional shortage areas. This proposed project aims to examine whether the NHSC expansion reduced the unmet need for alcohol use disorder treatment and improved disparities in alcohol use disorder treatment and outcomes in mental health professional shortage areas.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will explore altered brain MRI features that are linked to cognitive dysfunction in congenital heart disease (CHD) from both a pre-operative infant and an adult cohort. Our study leverages these unique and comprehensive data with advanced neuroimaging analyses to bridge a crucial gap in our knowledge of how prenatal, postnatal operative and environmental factors could affect brain development and longer-term cognitive outcomes in patients with CHD. Understanding which factors most impact the brain at these life stages will provide insight into when and where best to target treatments toward improving outcome throughout the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our ability to treat anxiety- and trauma-related psychiatric disorders is limited by our ability to precisely control threat computations in a similar way across species. The goal of this project is to develop a translatable, naturalistic model for circuit-behavior linkages using the fear of heights which can be used to understand innate threat across species. Using neurotransmitter biosensors, head-mounted microendoscope calcium imaging, and computational modeling of virtual reality behavior will demonstrate the role of norepinephrine in the aversion to high places.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Growing evidence suggests a close link between cardiovascular dysfunction and progression of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and cardiovascular risk factors are associated with an increased risk of developing AD. There is a gap in our knowledge of the interplay between vascular and metabolic health of the brain and heart in AD, how those key functions may be improved by routine exercise to slow down AD progression, and any gender differences. In this pilot study, we will evaluate the feasibility of two advanced, non-invasive, and translatable imaging techniques in an AD model that rapidly recapitulates major features of AD amyloid pathology, with a moderate exercise remedy over time to monitor their metabolic and vascular functions in the brain and heart associated with amyloid pathogenesis, and gender differences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative:  The proposed work promises to develop the use of an important new tool for studying neurotransmitter release at healthy and ALS model mouse neuromuscular synapses. This tool will initially be applied to the study of heterogeneity of individual transmitter release site function by correlating active zone structure and function. Such an investigation promises to transform the ways in which we study and understand presynaptic physiology and modulation of neurotransmitter release in healthy and disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: ROSALIND FRANKLIN UNIV OF MEDICINE & SCI
PHR: Project Narrative Gene transfer using viral vectors for cellular delivery has emerged as a widespread and powerful tool for research and increasingly also for clinical therapeutic use. Selectivity of cell type targeting, referred to as viral tropism, is important for fidelity but is not absolute, leading to off-target effects that may, or may not, be mitigated by cell specific promoters driving transgene expression. We propose two lentiviral pseudotyping gene transfer strategies, one of which will allow specific targeting of any mammalian cell type expressing the avian TVA receptor and a second of which will specifically and exclusively target one glial progenitor cell type in the mammalian CNS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: A major complication of cataract surgery is the development of the lens fibrotic disease, Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO). The proposed studies will investigate the molecular mechanisms by which mitochondrial remodeling promotes lens fibrotic disease. The proposed research is relevant to public health, as findings from these studies are expected to lead to the development of new mitochondrial-targeted treatment strategies for mitigating or blocking the development of PCO.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement With forecasts of the annual economic burden of autism spectrum disorders projected to reach $461 billion by 2025 in the US alone, the importance of validating neural biomarkers to evidence-based interventions cannot be underestimated. This study uses well-established electroencephalography (EEG) measures of auditory processing to examine the neural mechanisms underlying pervasive sensory symptoms in autism. Results generated here will validate a novel model that determines the role of top-down attention on sensory symptoms in autism and provide a framework to determine the effectiveness of attention interventions in autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Phox2b is one of the four transcription factors that defines the development, differentiation, and migration of RTN neurons, a critical set of CO2/H+-sensing respiratory chemoreceptor neurons in mice, and its expression persists throughout the postnatal period. In human patients, mutations in PHOX2B are diagnostic of congenital central hypoventilation syndrome (CCHS), characterized most famously by disruptions in CO2-dependent breathing and arousal reflexes. The precise transcriptional role of Phox2b in RTN neurons, and how disruption/mutation of Phox2b expression leads to the clinical signs associated with CCHS have not been determined. In this application, we propose a viral-mediated approach to examine effects of Phox2b depletion and mutation selectively in RTN chemoreceptor neurons implicated in CCHS to determine effects on gene expression and on CO2-dependent breathing and arousal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Climate change will exacerbate cardiovascular (CV) and respiratory/pulmonary (R/P) morbidity through increasing extreme temperatures and periods of high levels of air pollution from wildfires. Certain cancer therapies can increase breast cancer survivors' propensity for CV and R/P disease, and may increase survivors' susceptibility to health problems from climate change. We will determine whether: 1) survivors exposed to extreme temperature and air pollution prior to diagnosis have a higher risk for therapy-related CV and R/P problems, and 2) if post-diagnosis short term exposure to extreme temperature and air pollution during treatment increases survivors' risk for CV and R/P problems related to climate change.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative: In the last 20 years, rates of diagnoses for autism have increased at an alarming rate, and yet little is understood about its causes and treatment options are limited. By examining two increasingly common risk-related environmental factors â namely asthma and wildfire particulate matter â we will challenge current paradigms and isolate mechanisms related to microglia that may contribute to pathophysiology of autism. This hypothesis-driven integrative study combines immune, complex real-world environmental exposures, and epigenetic approaches to address a major gap in autism research and will provide critical information on the consequences of environmental contributions to risk for autism, helping to translate epidemiological observation into a functional model that can be utilized for further investigations and identify possible paths for prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: RELEVANCE The invasion and rapid spread of Anopheles stephensi in Africa pose great threats to malaria control and elimination in Africa. Control of An. stephensi in Africa currently relies primarily on larviciding, yet the location of habitats, particularly in urban areas, and the optimal time for larviciding are not yet known. This project will provide policy makers with this critical information to guide the effective design and implementation of larviciding programs.
